DOC.HEAD: Charges Dismissed Against `Ill Wind' Figure
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge dismissed new charges against a figure in the defense industry probe Friday, saying a second indictment was an act of revenge because the man was appealing his conviction on earlier charges. Thomas E. Muldoon, a former consultant to Norden Systems, already had been convicted on eight felonies, including conspiracy and bribery of a public official. Soon after his attorney filed an appeal on that conviction, Muldoon was indicted on charges of trafficking in secret defense information. U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. in Alexandria, Va., wrote that there was ``a realistic likelihood of vindictiveness on the part of the United States in causing the return of the present indictment in retaliation for the defendant Thomas E. Muldoon's going to trial or noting an appeal for his prior conviction or both.'' Muldoon, 60, was sentenced to 27 months in prison and fined $10,000 for his conviction arising from the investigation of fraud in defense procurement, code named ``Ill Wind.'' Muldoon's lawyer, Albert J. Ahern Jr., told The Washington Post that the second indictment against his client was to send a message to other defendants in the case to ``take the plea agreement as tendered, or face a splitting of the charges and multi-count indictments as the certain consequence.''

DOC.HEAD: Mistrial Declared in Congressman's Fraud Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to DELETE reference to $1 million, since some of the loans were used to pay off others.
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared Friday in the bank fraud trial of U.S. Rep. Harold Ford after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked. The congressman was accused of taking political favors in the form of loans that prosecutors said he was never expected to repay to Tennessee banking brothers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr. Jury foreman H.O. Robinson reported the deadlock after U.S. District Judge Odell Horton removed one of the 12 panel members for failing to disclose a past felony conviction. That development did not figure in the mistrial. Ford, a 44-year-old Memphis Democrat, had been on trial since Feb. 12 on charges of conspiracy, bank and mail fraud. A conviction could have brought a sentence of up to 95 years. The congressman said he regarded the mistrial as a victory, though he had hoped for acquittal. ``I'm hopeful now that I can put this episode behind me,'' Ford said. But U.S. Attorney John Gill in Knoxville said there would be another trial. ``The only thing I can say is we had a case we felt we were obligated to bring based on the evidence we had,'' Gill said. Ford stood trial with former Butcher accountant David Crabtree and former Butcher lawyers Karl Schledwitz and Douglas Beaty. Ford, the state's only black member of Congress, has complained often since his indictment that he is the victim of racist prosecutors, an allegation the government has denied. The government called 29 witnesses in the case. The defense did not call any, and Ford said he decided not to testify because he regarded the government's case as weak. On Wednesday, after their first two days of deliberations, jurors returned to the courtroom to report they were deadlocked. Horton told them it was too early to give up work. Before the mistrial was declared Friday, assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Clancy asked Horton to question juror Juanita Ruffin because the government believed she had a criminal record that she did not disclose during jury selection. Every juror picked for the trial signed a form on which they answered a variety of questions, including whether they had ever been convicted of a crime. Horton confronted Mrs. Ruffin in the courtroom about her record and she acknowledged she had been convicted in 1970 in connection with the theft of $160. She said she was placed on probation for that felony offense. Mrs. Ruffin also said she was convicted twice for shoplifting in the 1970s. Horton asked her why she didn't disclose the felony conviction during jury selection. She said she thought she didn't have to because the offenses occurred more than 10 years earlier. While being questioned, Mrs. Ruffin said the jury was split on reaching a verdict by a vote of 9-3. She did not say if that vote was in favor of acquittal or conviction. The jury was down to 11 members when the mistrial was declared, but lawyers said the judge could have allowed the deliberations to continue. First elected to congress in 1974, Ford has faced little opposition since then for his 9th Congressional District seat. He was charged with 19 criminal counts in an indictment handed down by a grand jury in Knoxville in 1987. His co-defendants, accused of helping him get and hde Butcher money, faced charges of conspiracy and mail fraud, five counts for Crabtree and 16 each for Beaty and Schledwitz. C.H. Butcher Jr. was brought to a nearby jail in Wynne, Ark., but was never asked to testify. He and Jake, a two-time candidate for Tennessee governor, are serving 20-year prison terms for bank fraud. The 1983 collapse of their banking chain was one of the worst in U.S. financial history. The government said Ford and his family drew Butcher loans totaling more than $1 million between 1976 and 1982, but Ford put the total at $650,000. He said those debts were settled.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Wide Publicity, `Twin Peaks' Continues Ratings Drop
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Twin Peaks'' is continuing its downward slide in the ratings despite being one of TV's most written-about new shows this year, Nielsen audience estimates showed Friday. Ratings for Thursday's episode showed that it was seen in nine million fewer homes than the two-hour April 8 premiere of the David Lynch series. The premiere was seen in more than 19.4 million homes and ranked fifth nationally in ratings for that week. Although its 11.3 rating made the show second in ratings in its one-hour time period Thursday, it only drew 18 percent of the audience then, compared to 33 percent for the show's premiere. NBC's ``Cheers'' and ``Wings'' easily beat ``Twin Peaks'' on Thursday, averaging a 19.4 rating. CBS' ``Falcon Crest'' was a distant third with an 8.1 average. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. ``Twin Peaks,'' a surreal soap opera set in the Pacific Northwest, has been acclaimed by most critics. But it also has steadily lost audiences each week since its much-publicized premiere. ``I think what's happening is that the show is solidifying around its core audience'' of young adults, said Alan Wurtzel, senior vice president for research at ABC. He said he thought its ratings will stabilize now. The show has lost most of its viewers in two categories, women over 50 and men over 35, he said. But it also has lost occasional viewers of television ``who may have watched (the show) becase of all the hype and word of mouth'' about the series, he said. ``I think what you're seeing is the inevitable shakeout.'' Although the ``Twin Peaks'' premiere did much better than ABC had expected, ``to a certain extent I'm disappointed that it didn't hold the higher numbers'' in episodes shown afterwards, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Describes Escaping, Killing Man Who Raped Her
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old girl who said she was kidnapped, chained to a tree and raped repeatedly for three weeks told police she escaped and killed her captor with his own shotgun while he slept. Her escape prompted a search Friday for remains of two other missing girls after police found a crudely drawn map suggesting two girls had been killed and dismembered. The map was discovered at the LaRue County campsite of Phillip E. Clopton, 39, of Louisville, who was found dead Thursday after the Louisville girl called the State Police from a store several miles away. Kentucky State Police Detective Robert Foster said the girl who shot Clopton initially had left Louisville with him willingly. ``But there obviously came time when she wanted to get away,'' Foster said. The girl's 18-year-old sister, however, told The Courier-Journal of Louisville that her sister was abducted. ``She didn't run away,'' her sister said. ``Everybody thought she ran away, but she didn't.'' Another man, 41-year-old James R. Cable, was arrested Thursday night in Louisville and charged with first-degree rape and sodomy in connection with the case. Cable was being held in the LaRue County jail under $250,000 bond on each count. Edlin said Cable wasn't suspected in the killings but may have distributed the body parts. His relationship with Clopton, who had been previously imprisoned for sodomy and rape, was not immediately clear. A journal found at the campsite chronicled ``at least three homicides in ... Jefferson County,'' located about 50 miles northeast of the search area, said state police Lt. Wayne Edwards. It contained ``some names of missing juveniles,'' he said. The Louisville girl, who was returned to her father, told police she had been held against her will for three weeks, chained to a tree and raped repeatedly. The girl said she took a shotgun while the man slept in a tent and killed him with a single shot to the head. A police report didn't indicate how she freed herself, said LaRue County Sheriff Merle Edlin. ``Apparently he didn't keep her chained at all times,'' Edlin said. ``I think she stayed there under threats, under fear for her life.'' Authorities unsuccessfully searched a three-county area in central Kentucky on Friday for the bodies of the two other missing girls. They tried to follow a map roughly sketched in pen on a piece of typing paper with the girls' names and the spots in which various body parts supposedly were buried. The task was difficult because the map was ``not too detailed'' and covered areas in LaRue, Nelson and Hardin counties, Edlin said. At the campsite Friday, police found two footlockers full of canned goods and other supplies and a makeshift toilet. A nearby creek served as a cooler. There were also cooking supplies, sleeping bags, clothing and survival books.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia To Proceed With Presidential Elections Despite Candidate's Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT that earlier call claimed responsibility, later communique denied it, authenticity of neither verifiable; picks up 4th graf pvs, `The August...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BOG2
DOC.TEXT: With a third presidential candidate assassinated, Colombia's government refused Friday to put off next month's election and vowed to keep up the fight against drug traffickers. A telefaxed communique, purportedly from the Medellin drug cartel, denied responsibility Friday for the assassination of presidential candidate Carlos Pizarro, who died in a hail of bullets Thursday aboard a Colombian jetliner carrying 97 people. But on Thursday, within hours of Pizarro's assassination, a man had called the national radio network station Caracol and related in detail how the cartel had allegedly ordered the former guerrilla's killing. The authenticity of neither claim could be verified. That is not the first time there have been contradictory communiques, verbal and faxed, claiming and and then denying responsibility for assassinations and terrorist acts. Friday's telefax accused police of instigating violence in order to force the government to continue its crackdown on traffickers, and accused the police of putting out false communiques purported to be from the cartel. The August assassination of another candidate, Sen. Luis Carlos Galan of the governing Liberal Party, prompted the government to launch a U.S.-backed crackdown on Colombia's cocaine cartels. Since then, drug traffickers have killed more than 230 people, including judges, politicians, policemen, soldiers, newspaper employees and two other presidential candidates. Leaders of the leftist Patriotic Union Party, whose candidate was slain last month, urged the government to cancel the May 27 vote. But Interior Minister Horacio Serpa told reporters Friday that the elections will not be postponed or canceled. In a televised speech late Thursday, Serpa said the government will fight terrorists ``without rest.'' On Friday, thousands of men, women and children filed past Pizarro's coffin, displayed in an open patio in the Congress building. Supporters of Pizarro's M-19 movement burned buses and threw rocks at police in clashes in several cities. Hundreds of leftist guerrillas belonging to the M-19 rebel group laid down their arms last month and formed a political party with Pizarro as its presidential candidate. Government officials had said Pizarro could have helped mediate peace agreements with other leftist insurgents. Governing party candidate Cesar Gaviria, the presidential front-runner, suspended campaign activities following the Pizarro killing. In a radio interview, he condemned the killing as another act by ``powerful organizations'' trying to impose an ``empire of evil and crime.'' The other candidates are Alvaro Gomez Hurtado and Rodrigo Lloreda, both of the Conservative Party. Gomez, suggesting that Barco does not have the confidence of Colombia's military, urged the president Friday to name a three-man council to run Colombia's security forces. He said such a move would help ensure peace in the last month of the presidential campaign. Barco, through a spokesman, rejected the proposal. The Patriotic Union's presidential candidate, Bernardo Jaramillo, was fatally wounded March 22 at the Bogota airport by an assassin with a machine gun. Pizarro's killer, 25-year-old Alvaro Rodriguez, was sitting two rows behind Pizarro on the flight and apparently retrieved the machine gun from an airplane bathroom before returning to his seat, Capt. Fabio Munevar told Caracol. Minutes later, he stood up, pulled the weapon from his black leather jacket, leaned forward and fired at Pizarro's head from about a foot away, Munevar said. Pizarro's bodyguards immediately killed the assassin. The plane, en route to the Caribbean coastal city of Barranquilla, returned immediately to Bogota. Pizarro died about an hour later at a hospital. The Bogota morgue said he was struck by 13 bullets. Two men with machine guns were arrested at Barranquilla airport, a police spokesman there said. They apparently were part of an assassination squad with orders to kill Pizarro if he survived the flight, police said. In another development, church officials in Medellin said they had foiled a plan to kill Colombia's Roman Catholic prelate, Cardinal Alfonso Lopez Trujillo. The city's Catholic church said it discovered the plan to kill Lopez Trujillo after intercepting messages on a radio frequency used by the men plotting the crime. Three men disguised as police agents entered Lopez Trujillo's offices on Wednesday and Thursday asking for the prelate, but he was not in, said the church statement late Thursday. Lopez is archbishop of Medellin, the country's second-largest city, and chairman of Colombia's Bishops Conference.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Right-Wing Radicals, Confiscate Nazi Paraphernalia
DOC.TEXT: East German police blasted their way into three abandoned buildings to arrest 19 right-wing radicals, confiscating weapons and Nazi paraphernalia, the state-run ADN news agency said. The report said police had to use explosive devices to force their way into the blocked entrances of the buildings in East Berlin's Lichtenberg district on Friday. The report did not further describe the Nazi material. It said those arrested also had material from the extreme-right Republican party, which surpised West Germans last year by winning seats in several local elections. The party was banned from taking part in East Germany's first free elections on March 18. Officials suspect those arrested of taking part in a rampage a week ago in which passers-by were attacked in East Berlin's main square, Alexanderplatz, ADN said. Police at the time said about 300 soccer rowdies were joined in the melee by groups of neo-Nazi skinheads shouting tributes to Adolf Hitler on the 101st anniversary of his birthday. Two people were seriously hurt and four policemen suffered lesser injuries in the April 20 fracas.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Says Metaphysical Instructor Has Been Victim of Witch Hunt
DOC.TEXT: An instructor of metaphysics, questioned after nine people associated with her died during a 13-year period, has been the victim of a witch hunt, her attorney says. ``It's Salem all over,'' Fred Time, attorney for Terri Hoffman, said Friday. ``They've called her a Manson, a Jones in Guyana. It's crazy, without facts, and a defamation of character.'' Dallas County District Attorney John Vance said Thursday that prosecutors lack evidence to send the matter to a grand jury for a possible criminal indictment. The case had been set for presentation next week and subpoenas had been issued to witnesses, including Ms. Hoffman. Those subpoenas have been canceled. ``I have to remain calm and quiet,'' said Ms. Hoffman, who referred questions to Time. ``But one of these days I will tell my story.'' Prosecutors began looking into Ms. Hoffman's affairs after a former college professor and his wife who followed her teachings were found dead last fall. Police said two may have killed themselves. Four other followers of Ms. Hoffman have committed suicide, including two of her husbands. Two other followers died in apparent accidents, as did the housekeeper of one of the followers. Some accounts of the case have included mention of Ms. Hoffman's son, who died on the job in a construction accident. His death did not come up in the investigation. Some of the followers had given or bequeathed her money and property. Ms. Hoffman ran a concern called Conscious Development of Body, Mind and Soul Inc., through which she sold books and tapes. She ran classes on meditation and spiritual sessions. Assistant District Attorney Cecil Emerson, who directed the investigation of Ms. Hoffman, said earlier this year that he was trying to determine whether ``mind control'' could legally be blamed for contributing to a death. After Thursday's announcement, Emerson said: ``I would just hope that if something further presents itself, we will consider it.'' Ms. Hoffman still faces a civil lawsuit filed by two stepchildren, who claim she contributed to and profited from their father's September 1988 suicide and the deaths of six other associates. Trial is scheduled in August.

DOC.HEAD: June 3 Likely Date For Presidential Runoff Election
DOC.TEXT: The presidential runoff election between novelist Mario Vargas Llosa and agricultural engineer Alberto Fujimori will probably be held June 3, the National Election Board says. Official results of the April 8 general elections will be announced over the weekend, board spokesman Juan Chavez Molina said in a radio interview on Friday. Peru's constitution says at least four weeks must elapse between the release of the official vote count and the runoff election. Fujimori won a surprising 30 percent of the vote to Vargas Llosa's 32 percent in the April 8 balloting, and recent polls suggest Fujimori now has a strong lead. Both candidates have been in virtual seclusion since the April election. Vargas Llosa's aides have said he will probably begin campaigning next week.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Gerald McRaney, television's ``Major Dad,'' got a heady taste of real military adventure as a flyboy for a day. McRaney took to the skies Friday with the Navy's Blue Angels at the Marine Corps Air Station as the flying squadron prepared for a weekend air show. ``He loved it,'' publicist Beth Llewelyn said. ``In fact, he went up twice.'' McRaney isn't a pilot, but he held the controls of the FA-18 Hornet jet for a bit on the second flight, Ms. Llewelyn said. The actor portrays hard-nosed, soft-hearted Marine Maj. J.D. MacGillis, who marries a journalist with three daughters, on the the CBS-TV comedy ``Major Dad.''

Reggie Jackson knows the value of being Reggie Jackson. Who else has more than 100 baseball cards from his rookie year? The value of each card? ``I think it's up to $600 now. Something is worth what someone else will pay for it,'' Jackson said Friday. Jackson has a lot of memorabilia from his own career in his auto dealership showroom in Palo Alto, Calif. When it comes to collecting cards, he's interested in other baseball greats as well. ``I buy for investment,'' Jackson said. ``I buy Hall of Famers and players I like. I've got Aaron and Jackie Robinson and Campanella. I've got a 1951 Mickey Mantle card.'' Jackson, now a broadcaster for the California Angels, got his start with the Oakland Athletics in 1969 and finished with the A's in 1987. He played for the New York Yankees from 1977 through 1981 and with the Angels from 1982 through 1986.

Four cars belonging to comedian Redd Foxx, including a 1927 Model T, will be auctioned May 11 to help pay off his tax debt, the Internal Revenue Service says. Foxx and the IRS clashed over $755,166 in back taxes for 1983, 1984 and 1986, an agency spokeswoman says. All the IRS left was Foxx' bed when they raided his Las Vegas home in November. A truckload of his personal property was returned after his attorneys successfully argued in court that the possessions were protected under a bankruptcy reorganization plan. The IRS spokeswoman said a 1927 Model T, a 1975 Panther, a 1983 Zimmer and a 1978 Jeep Cherokee belonging to Foxx were not returned and will be auctioned in Las Vegas, along with his Vespa motor scooter.

Country music fans know singer Clint Black best for his single, ``A Better Man,'' and his album, ``Killin' Time.'' That's because he has no other tunes out there in radio land. The album, which contains the single, is Black's first. But the singer's mantel piece already is crowded with spanking new awards from the Academy of Country Music. The 28-year-old former ironworker earned four of the 12 major trophies passed out during the academy's awards show Wednesday night. Black was named top male vocalist, top new male vocalist and got single record of the year and album of the year. ``One thing I always felt was that I wouldn't go hungry with my singing. I knew that,'' Black said Wednesday night. And Black already has some advice for young singers and musicians. ``Make sure you've got a good manager,'' he said. ``You will end up with a good label and you'll have somebody to watch out for your life.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Figure to Join Top Leaders in Watching May Day Parade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gavriil is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A radical opposition politician will join President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other top Communist leaders Tuesday to view the annual May Day parade through Red Square, officials said. Gavriil Popov, the newly elected mayor of Moscow, will join officials viewing the spectacle from atop the Lenin mausoleum, Moscow Communist Party chief Yuri A. Prokofiev told a news conference Friday. Popov was elected on April 20 by the new city council, which was swept by his Democratic Russia bloc of reformists in elections in March. He is a leader of the Inter-Regional Group, the parliamentary opposition that Gorbachev frequently has denounced. In pre-glasnost days, the lineup of leaders on hand for the May Day parade was scrutinized by Kremlin-watchers, who speculated on which officials were in or out of favor according to where they stood. The Communist Party will help organize May Day events but not dominate planning as in past years, Prokofiev said, and the columns of marchers will gather freely to converge on Red Square instead of being tightly controlled by party committees.

DOC.HEAD: Regents to Discuss Sobol Plan to Revise Curriculum
DOC.TEXT: Education officials approved a plan for rewriting New York's elementary and high-school history lessons to include more about the contributions of minority Americans. The plan calls for appointment of a 20-member committee of academics and others to decide on such matters as teacher retraining and selection of textbooks for the nation's third-largest public school system. It was approved Friday by the state Board of Regents at the request of Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol, who said his staff has already held talks with educators in other states about approaching textbook publishers. The board approved the idea of rewriting the history curriculum in February and on Friday endorsed Sobol's blueprint for getting the job done by 1992. The vote followed more of the acrimonious debate that erupted following release last summer of a report by another Sobol-appointed committee, which charged the state's textbooks were filled with ``hidden assumptions of white supremacy.'' That report said New York's history courses minimize the contributions of minorities and largely ignore the wrongs committed against nonwhites by whites. One of the reasons minority children do poorly in school is because they don't read about their ancestors in history texts, the report said. Without naming the review committee, Sobol set strict guidelines on who it would include: elementary, middle and high school teachers, school administrators, department heads, college professors and scholars in social studies. Committee members will be appointed on the basis of ``racial and ethnic diversity,'' Sobol said. The 17-member committee that delivered the original critique of state's curriculum included one white member. One regent, former teacher Adelaide Sanford of New York City, worried that the new committee would water down recommendations made by last summer's task force. She accused the regents of retreating from a commitment to wipe bias from schools because of concern about inflammatory language in the report. A representative of New York state's largest teachers union urged a careful approach to the rewrite. ``I have grave concerns that we maintain the theory that we as Americans share a common culture,'' said Antonia Cortese, first vice president of New York State United Teachers. ``Our very basis for a democracy is tolerance for other people. It's not separatism.'' The regents approved the plan on a unanimous voice vote. Sanford sat silent. Sobol said in February that he had begun discussions with educators in other states, including California, about presenting a common front in requesting changes from textbook publishers. Ahead of New York, Texas has the nation's largest school system and California's is second.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Sought to Take Away Discretion on Targeting Unfair Traders
DOC.TEXT: Some members of Congress, upset over President Bush's removal of Japan from a ``hit list'' of unfair traders, are introducing legislation to take away the president's discretion in the matter. The bill is just one example of the firestorm created by the administration's decision Friday to remove Japan from a list of countries deemed to have erected the most offensive barriers to the sale of U.S. products. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., took to the Senate floor to declare that he was ``thunderstruck'' by the action. ``Excuse me, Mr. President, but this boggles the mind,'' he said. ``Letting Japan off the hook is a serious mistake and I think Congress ought to take a look at it.'' The dispute involves the toughest section of the 1988 trade law, known as Super 301. It required the administration to target countries in 1989 and 1990 for intensive negotiations aimed at removing trade barriers. If the negotiations were unsuccessful, then the administration had the power to retaliate with higher U.S. tariffs on imports from the offending country. Last year, the administration named Japan, Brazil and India. But this year, Bush said he was retaining only India because of that country's refusal to remove its barriers to foreign investment and foreign insurance companies. The administration dropped Japan and Brazil from the list because of market-opening moves they have made. While the Super 301 provision was due to expire after this year, several members of Congress said they planned to push for it to be extended indefinitely, thus forcing the administration to face the question of targeting Japan in future years. Two senators, Democrat Carl Levin of Michigan and Republican Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, said they planned to introduce a bill taking away the administration's discretion over whether to target Japan. Their measure would require the president to target any country for negotiations if its trade surplus accounted for 15 percent or more of America's overall trade deficit. Last year, that provision would have only applied to Japan. America's $49 billion deficit with Japan accounted for 45 percent of the total U.S. trade deficit of $109 billion. Owen Bieber, president of the United Auto Workers, supported a move to limit the president's discretion, saying that the administration's decision Friday added ``insult to injury by reaching the preposterous conclusion that Japan suddenly deserves a clean bill of trade health.'' But the administration defended its action, saying that targeting Tokyo again would have undermined the efforts of Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to reform his country's trade practices. ``We believe that the most effective way to achieve results is through cooperation, not confrontation,'' said U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said the message to Japan was: ``Congratulations on a job well done to date.'' The administration pledged to keep pressure on Japan to live up to its commitments including insisting that monitoring provisions be placed in an agreement reached April 5 to attack a broad array of structural barriers blocking American and other foreign companies from doing business in Japan. But many members of Congress accused the administration of making a serious tactical error. They said removing Japan from the target list took pressure off Kaifu's government. ``When we have a persistent $49 billion trade deficit with Japan and that nation will not abide by a variety of agreements, freeing them from the threat of trade sanctions makes no objective sense,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt. A year ago, Japan was cited for barriers to sales of U.S.-made supercomputers, satellites and wood products. In the past month, U.S. and Japanese negotiators have reached market-opening agreements in all three areas. Brazil was targeted for restrictive import licensing practices. Hills said recently enacted legislation in that country should meet U.S. concerns in this area. But India, which was cited last year for a ban on operations of foreign private insurance companies and for controls on foreign investment that distort trade, has refused to make concessions. The 1990 target list names those barriers again. The Indian government issued a statement saying it would continue to refuse to ``negotiate bilaterally under threat of sanctions.'' Members of Congress said it made no sense to target India, with its modest $850 million trade surplus with the United States, and neglect Japan, whose trade surplus is more than 50 times higher. In a separate action Friday, the administration said it was not targeting any country for possible sanctions relating to violations of U.S. copyright and patent protections. However, it placed four countries _ Brazil, India, China and Thailand _ on a ``priority watch list'' as countries deserving ``special attention.'' Another 19 countries with lesser problems were placed on a watch list. They were Argentina, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Egypt, Greece, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Spain, Taiwan, Turkey, Venezuela and Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Erred in Rejecting International Aid, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a Soviet parliamentary delegation says he will try to find out which Soviet official rejected offers of international aid after the 1986 explosion at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor. With the full dimensions of the Chernobyl disaster now becoming clear, the Supreme Soviet has reversed course and is urgently seeking scientific, medical and material aid from the world community. At a news conference at the Soviet Embassy on Friday, five Soviet parliamentary deputies said the official secrecy that shrouded the aftermath of the April 26, 1986, fire and explosion at the Chernobyl reactor was a damaging mistake because it masked the scope and scale of the disaster. In addition, they said efforts to clean up radiation contamination and deal with the medical effects of the accident might have been far more advanced by now if most foreign assistance had not been rejected. The radiation that spewed from the plant poisoned millions of acres of farmland and forests in the Ukraine alone. It is now believed to pose a potential health threat to at least 4 million Soviets, especially children, pregnant women and the elderly. Delegation members said cases of leukemia and thyroid cancer are appearing. And scores of thousands of homes and apartments will have to be found _ and new jobs as well _ for those evacuated from contaminated regions. ``I know there were offers of help from foreign organizations, but they were turned down,'' said Kakimbek S. Salykov, the delegation leader and chairman of the Supreme Soviet's Committee on Ecology and Rational Use of Natural Resources. ``We are going to investigate who was the person who ruled that such offers be turned down,'' he said. Salykov contrasted the aftermath of Chernobyl to the earthquake that devastated large sections of Soviet Armenia on Dec. 7, 1988, and triggered an outpouring of aid from around the world. He said he believes the difference in the official attitude was caused by the fact that Chernobyl occurred at the beginning of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness. ``The earthquake occurred when the policies of openness and reform were quite well developed,'' he said. ``So all offers were accepted.'' Lev A. Kuznetsov, a member of the delegation, said it is now clear that in the case of Chernobyl, ``The assistance required from the world community will be required for a long period of time.'' ``It is very sad for us that it is four years after the catastrophe that we parliamentarians have to talk to you like that,'' he said. As to the Chernobyl reactor, it is considered obsolete and ``accident prone'' and will be shut down permanently either this year or in 1991, said Yuri N. Shcherbak, another deputy from the Supreme Soviet. ``But it will not be closed today or tomorrow,'' he said. ``Very great preparatory work is needed.''

DOC.HEAD: Auditors Cite Potentially Lethal Problems at Arms Plant
DOC.TEXT: Managers of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina put some of its workers at an unnecessarily high risk of ``gross contamination'' by plutonium, according to an Energy Department audit report. Plutonium, a key ingredient in nuclear warheads, is one of the most toxic elements known. Lethal lung doses of plutonium are measured in the billionths of a gram. The defense contractor that runs the plant, Westinghouse Electric Corp., said Friday it was taking action to correct the problem. It was discovered during a two-month probe of health, safety and environmental conditions at Savannah River, which makes plutonium and other special materials for nuclear weapons. The audit ended March 23 and results were made available Friday at the Energy Department, which owns Savannah River and 16 other major nuclear arms plants and laboratories. The audit team of federal officials and private contractors said they found a potentially dangerous combination of problems at a building called the SED Facility, which is on the grounds of Savannah River's research laboratory near Aiken, S.C. Dean Hoffman, a Westinghouse spokesman, said the SED Facility performs classified work and that he could not comment on it beyond saying the problems were being fixed. The auditors said they were concerned about conditions in an area of the facility that contained glove boxes, or work stations that allowed workers to handle plutonium with lead-lined gloves inserted through the side of the box. They said the gloves were severely deteriorated. This was particularly troubling because the gloves were contaminated with plutonium and were in the vicinity of combustible objects, including plastic, plywood, cardboard and plexiglass, the report said. Making matters worse was a lack of adequate fire protection in the building, the auditors said. ``The combination ... results in a high potential for the spread of plutonium contamination to surrounding areas and their occupants,'' the report said. At another point the report said the result could be ``gross contamination'' of the SED Facility and the unspecified number of people working in it. The nuclear weapons makers learned a painful lesson about the dangers of plutonium processing 33 years ago. In September 1957 at the Rocky Flats weapons plant in Colorado, plutonium shavings ignited spontaneously in a plexiglass glove box, creating a huge fire that quickly went out of control and spewed unknown amounts of plutonium into the atmosphere just 16 miles from Denver. The problems at the SED Facility were rated at ``category 2,'' which the Energy Department defines as ``a significant risk'' but not presenting a clear and present danger to workers or the public. Problems of this type are serious enough to require considering whether to shut down the facility until corrections are made. The auditors also said the problems had the ``potential for causing a severe occupational injury, illness or fatality'' or destruction of the building. In all, the audit found 11 sets of problems at Savannah River in the ``category 2'' level. Besides the SED Facility, they included inadequate procedures for evacuating workers from a high-level nuclear waste storage area in the event of accidental releases of radioactivity from nearby processing buildings. The auditors also gave a ``category 2'' rating to their finding that operators and supervisors at Savannah River's waste management facilities _ which are among the largest in the nation _ have not been properly trained to operate the facilities. Hoffman said all 11 of the ``category 2'' concerns are being addressed, and that most of them already have been corrected.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Hostage to Undergo Biopsy
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Robert Polhill may remain hospitalized for as long as three or four weeks and will undergo a biopsy soon to determine the nature of a growth on his vocal cords, an Army doctor says. Dr. Russ Zajtchuk, deputy commander of clinical services at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, said Friday that Polhill is not considered strong enough yet to have the general anesthesia that is necessary for the biopsy. He said it probably will be performed ``about Monday.'' Polhill, 55, a diabetic, lost 25 pounds during his three years and three months in the hands of Shiite Moslem extremists in Lebanon. Zajtchuk said the growth on Polhill's left vocal cords could be a tumor or an infection. An infection could be an outgrowth of his captivity, but a tumor most likely would not be, he said. Zajtchuk said Polhill also has ``some extent'' of tingling and numbness in his hands as a complication of his diabetes. He said the ex-hostage had told other physicians that his captors supplied him with insulin to treat his condition. A Shiite physician, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press in Nicosia, Cyprus, that the militants holding Western hostages sometimes bring in doctors from Iranian-funded hospitals to care for ailing captives. ``The hostages have common health problems such as diabetes, high blood pressure or high levels of uric acid,'' said the physician. ``Medicines for such health problems are not a problem. They can be obtained anywhere in Lebanon.'' Zajtchuk said Polhill ``appears to be in reasonably good spirits considering the ordeal he has undergone.'' ``There is no evidence that he was beaten,'' the Army doctor said. He said Polhill had indicated to other physicians that he was not. Polhill was released Sunday and flown to Washington on Thursday from Wiesbaden, West Germany, where he spent three days in another Army hospital. Seventeen Western hostages, seven of them Americans, are still held in the Middle East. The longest-held of the U.S. hostages is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. Zajtchuk appeared at a news conference along with Polhill's Lebanese-born wife, Ferial, who said her husband ``is physically weak, but mentally very, very strong.'' Polhill did not appear at the news conference, but his wife read a statement from him, saying, ``I regret that, at the moment, I am unable to thank you more directly and personally. But my voice decided to go on vacation before I did. However, I do want you to know how very much I appreciate the warmth and sincerity of your welcome and the support you've given my wife and family, who join me in hoping that this is the beginning of the end to the hostage situation.'' ``I am, happily, now free to join you in your continued support for the loved ones of those who remain in captivity and in welcoming the hostages home in the very near future,'' Polhill said. ``Let's show the world that we, the American people, want to leave the past behind us, look positively to the future and, once and for all, close the file on the hostage issue.'' Polhill was abducted with two other American educators on Jan. 24, 1987, from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College. The other two remain among the seven American hostages. Mrs. Polhill said her husband had told her that both of them, Alann Steen and Jesse Turner, ``are doing very well.''

DOC.HEAD: American University Staff and Students `Sad, Baffled and Worried'
DOC.TEXT: American University will survive the resignation of its president amid an investigation of obscene phone calls because ``no institution is dependent on one person,'' the university provost says. AU President Richard Berendzen resigned earlier this month, citing exhaustion. However, authorities said later that Berendzen was being investigated for allegedly making obscene telephone calls. No charges have been filed against Berendzen. Provost Milton Greenberg, who has assumed the duties of the president, said Friday the school had ``undergone an unbelievably extraordinary turn of events filled with human tragedy, legal complications, media interest and the blessed but complicated expectations of openness.'' ``We won't pretend now that we are not sad, baffled and worried,'' he said. ``No institution is dependent on one person,'' Greenberg said at a meeting in the campus athletic building. Berendzen, who is being treated at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore, issued an apology Thursday through his lawyer. Berendzen did not describe the nature of his treatment. ``I cannot begin to convey my embarrassment, or my torment,'' he said in the three-paragraph statement. Berendzen, a former astronomy professor with degrees from MIT and Harvard, came to American University in 1974 as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences. He became provost three years later and president in 1980. ``We are affected. We are hurt by what has happened,'' staff member Haimdat Sawah, 28, said after Greenberg's speech. ``But I don't think the integrity of the university has been diminished that much, or the quality of the degree has diminished that much.'' Several students said they were disappointed Greenberg didn't discuss specifics of the allegations against Berendzen. ``I just feel that a lot of things weren't cleared up about what happened,'' said sophomore Susan Demel, a native of Puerto Rico. ``I think he (Greenberg) was very vague.'' Andrew Bloom, a sophomore from Chicago, said the university was withholding facts. ``They are trying to protect the university's reputation and they are going about it all wrong,'' Bloom said. Officials said Berendzen resigned after he became the subject of an investigation based on complaints to police in suburban Fairfax County, Va. Fairfax Commonwealth Attorney Robert Horan is expected to complete the investigation in a few days, but he refuses to detail allegations against Berendzen.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Aid Bill Delayed by Death Penalty, Abortion Tiffs
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders hope to send an aid package for Central America to President Bush next week, but lawmakers first must resolve disputes over abortion and the death penalty that are slowing the bill. The Senate was unable to make much progress with the $3.4 billion spending bill on Friday. The measure's centerpieces are $300 million for Nicaragua and $420 million for Panama, which both have new democratic governments. But unrelated provisions and dozens of potential amendments have slowed work on the bill. Much of Friday's session was spent debating language permitting the District of Columbia to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women. The bill survived two attempts by conservatives to remove the language, 51-45 and 54-42. Work on the bill bogged down again after senators gave preliminary approval, 60-27, to an amendment allowing the death penalty for drug-related murders in the District of Columbia. When the vote ended, capital punishment foe Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., pulled out a 1,000-page study entitled, ``The Case Against the Death Penalty.'' He announced that he was prepared to debate at length on the issue. After 40 minutes, the Senate agreed to postpone debate on the bill until Monday. The delays provoked expressions of frustration from Senate leaders, who had hoped to send the legislation to Bush for his signature earlier this week. ``This is supposed to be an urgent supplemental bill for Panama and Nicaragua,'' lamented Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``We've forgotten that because we want to debate abortion all day. We have a responsibility to the president'' to expedite aid to the two fledgling democratic governments, he said. Surveying a list of dozens of amendments proposed by both Democrats and Republicans, Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, added: ``I don't think either side has displayed any restraint.'' When passed, the measure still must go to a conference with the House to work out differences with that chamber's $2.4 billion version. The money is for the rest of this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. The aid to Panama and Nicaragua, as well as money for a number of domestic programs added by members of Congress, is being paid for largely through cuts in the Pentagon budget. From Bush's original request for $870 million, House and Senate add-ons pushed the total price tag of the bill to roughly $3.4 billion. Domestic spending initiatives ranged from $8 million to wage war on grasshoppers in the upper Midwest to $185 million for a West Virginia FBI fingerprint lab. Also included by Congress was hundreds of millions of dollars to make up shortfalls this year in a variety of programs, including veterans' benefits, food stamps, Forest Service firefighting and disaster relief. Among amendments adopted Friday was a requirement that the government study how foreign aid can be used to promote the fortunes of American businesses overseas, proposed by Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va..

DOC.HEAD: EPA Ordered to Explain Acid Rain Position
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency is under orders from a federal appeals court to explain why it has not written regulations to reduce acid rain. In a separate but related decision, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia rejected Friday an industry challenge to current standards for smoke, dust and soot. The court gave EPA 60 days to explain its acid rain position. The issue could become moot, since revisions to clean air legislation now before Congress are expected to include new controls on acid rain precursors such as sulfur dioxide, the pollutant at issue before the court. Longstanding EPA ``primary'' regulations aimed at protecting public health govern the permissible concentration of sulfur dioxide in the ground-level atmosphere around pollution sources such as power plant smokestacks. The agency also may issue so-called ``secondary'' standards aimed at protecting economic and other assets without regard to health. Sulfur dioxide may be transformed chemically in the atmosphere into sulfuric acid, which may fall in rain hundreds of miles from the pollution source. The acid may form a haze in the atmosphere that reduces visibility. The National Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, and several Northeastern states argued that the agency must issue a secondary sulfur dioxide standard aimed at acid rain. One asset to be protected was visibility, the plaintiffs argued. ``EPA has taken no formal action indicating that it is moving in the direction of making a decision whether or not to establish a secondary standard'' on acid rain, wrote judge Patricia Wald. While the ruling implies ``no conclusion as to the merits of EPA's lack of movement,'' the court directed the agency ``to provide us with clear and cogent reasons why'' it has taken no action. ``We're very pleased that the court agreed with us that the EPA had not satisfactorily explained why it was continuing to refuse to address acid rain,'' said James Sevinsky, a lawyer in the office of New York state Attorney General Robert Abrams. David Doniger, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said: ``In one sense this is vindication. In another sense, it's a sad commentary on how the legal process works.'' In the Reagan administration, EPA argued that more study was needed before acid rain could be addressed. The Bush administration favors action and is supporting a far-reaching provision in Congress to require a 10 million ton reduction in annual sulfur dioxide emissions, almost half the current annual total. The American Iron and Steel Institute challenged as arbitrary and capricious EPA air quality standards for particulate matter _ smoke, dust and soot _ on the grounds that they were based on inadequate scientific data. The court found the federal agency's standards conclusions reasonable, based on the available data. The industry group had asked the court to delay its decision, saying that the National Institutes of Health is investigating allegations that an author of some studies relied on by the EPA had suppressed evidence of errors. But those studies were only part of the evidence the EPA used, said the appeals court. The significance of the opening of the investigation is ``too speculative to provide grounds'' for delaying its decision, said the court.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman's Bank Fraud Trial Ends With Hung Jury
DOC.TEXT: A federal court jury ended the bank fraud trial of U.S. Rep. Harold Ford in deadlock, but a prosecutor says the government will try again for a conviction. A mistrial was declared Friday after nearly two months of testimony over political favors Ford was accused of performing in exchange for loans from two fallen banking brothers. The Democrat said he considered the mistrial a victory, but had expected an innocent verdict. ``I'm hopeful now that I can put this episode behind me,'' Ford said. U.S. Attorney John Gill had a different idea. ``There will be a retrial,'' Gill said from his Knoxville office. ``The only thing I can say is we had a case we felt we were obligated to bring based on the evidence we had.'' Ford, Tennessee's only black congressman, has complained often since his 1987 indictment that he is the victim of racist prosecutors. The government has denied the allegation. Ford, 44, was accused of taking political payoffs disguised as loans from former bankers Jake Butcher and his brother, C.H. Butcher Jr. The Butcher brothers in 1983 set off one of the worst banking collapses in U.S. financial history. Both brothers are serving 20-year prison terms on guilty pleas stemming from their banking empire's collapse. Ford was indicted in Knoxville on conspiracy, bank and mail fraud charges. The trial was moved to Memphis at his request. He was charged with 19 counts and faced up to 95 years in prison if convicted. Federal rules require a retrial within 70 days, but Gill said pretrial motions could push back the date. Ford stood trial with former C.H. Butcher Jr. accountant David Crabtree and former lawyers for both brothers, Karl Schledwitz and Douglas Beaty. Crabtree, Schledwitz and Beaty were accused of helping Ford get and hide Butcher money and faced charges of conspiracy and mail fraud _ five counts for Crabtree and 16 each for Beaty and Schledwitz. The government's trial witnesses outlined a complicated string of loans to Ford and said few, if any, payments were made on them prior to the Butchers' financial collapse. The government said Ford and his family drew Butcher loans totaling more than $1 million between 1976 and 1982, but Ford put the total at $650,000. He said those debts were settled. The trial began Feb. 12. Testimony began March 1 and the government called 29 witnesses. The defense did not call any witnesses, and Ford said he decided not to testify because he regarded the government's case as weak. U.S. District Judge Odell Horton removed one of 12 jurors earlier Friday for failing to disclose a past felony conviction, but lawyers said the trial could have continued with 11 jury members.

DOC.HEAD: Bruce Lee Producer Basking in Latest Success: Ninja Turtles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Michelangelo in 4th graf; Also moved in AMs
DOC.TEXT: Movie mogul Raymond Chow recalls his initial response to a suggestion he produce a film called ``Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' ``It's quite impossible! What is this?'' Chow responded. ``When you hear the title it is difficult to relate the four words to each other. To make sure I heard it right, I really had to ask the guy to spell it out for me,'' he said during a recent interview at his studios in Hong Kong. But Chow, 62, refused to dismiss the movie out of hand when the suggestion was made two years ago. He agreed to produce the movie based on four crime-fighting, human-sized turtles who devour pizza, speak surfer lingo (Cowabunga!!) and are named after the Renaissance artists Raphael, Leonardo, Michelangelo and Donatello. ``My gut feeling told me we should give it a try,'' said Chow, whose Golden Harvest Group first landed on the international movie-making map with martial arts idol Bruce Lee. ``It's very weird, very unique and very interesting. ... You have to be unique these days to be a big success,'' he said. The rest is Hollywood history. The idea that was rejected by U.S. studios eventually became ``Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' and smashed box office records to become the top-grossing independent film in the United States. The movie's box office should reach $100 million this weekend and could hit $150 million in the United States alone, with much of the receipts coming from children buying half-priced tickets. Tens of millions more will be earned as the radioactive reptillian warriors head to other countries later this year. The movie, which cost $15 million, stands to earn Golden Harvest at least $25 million. It isn't the first time movies about martial arts heroes have been kind to Chow's studio. In the early 1970s, Golden Harvest made five Bruce Lee movies including ``Enter the Dragon,'' which was co-produced by Warner Bros. and grossed nearly $50 million in the United States, according to one studio executive. Chow, a former Voice of America reporter, has many smaller successes among the more than 300 films he has made since 1970, most low-budget films made for the Asian market. Popular kung fu sagas, action comedies and ghost stories are market staples. That formula for success has made Chow's studio a target of critics who say he is only concerned with making money, not quality films. But Chow rejects the arguments and says both the Bruce Lee and Ninja Turtles movies carry social messages. ``Most of our films have a general good message, sort of the Buddhist belief that good guys will be rewarded and bad guys will be punished. So everybody should be a good guy,'' he said. Another company in this British colony is joining in the golden harvest from the terrapins. Playmates Holdings Ltd. has seen its sales and profits rise dramatically as the licensed manufacturer of Ninja Turtle toys. ``We are amazed at this tremendous response,'' its finance director, B.F. Chu, said from the company's showroom. Also in the showroom was Retromutagen Ooze (the turtles mutated after contact with radioactive sewer slime), a Turtle Blimp and many more of the dozens of turtle-related toys made at factories in China and the nearby Portuguese territory of Macao. After suffering a loss of $4.8 million in 1987, Playmates' turtle toys went on the market and helped the company earn $2.3 million in 1988 and $21.4 million last year. More than 70 percent of the company's sales came from the turtle line last year, and Chu said orders have further jumped since the movie came out a month ago. Playmates expects sales to increase again this year. The good fortune may just be starting for the company. A new line of licensed Dick Tracy toys is about to be released in conjunction with the Warren Beatty movie on the famed comic cop, scheduled for release in June.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Offers Offenders a Choice of Fines or Learning
DOC.TEXT: Judge Erwin Alderson offers petty offenders who are illiterate a choice: crack the books or pay the price. The municipal court judge will reduce or suspend fines if offenders take part in a 20-week literacy program at Oil Belt Vo-Tech. Alderson, whose rulings range from fines of $85 for violation of a local leash law to hundreds of dollars for driving while intoxicated, got his idea last year when he attended the kickoff of a program at a local school that uses computers to help teach illiterate adults to read. ``I believe in trying innovative things,'' he said. And the criminal justice system, particularly municipal court, is a good place to locate people with literacy problems, he added. ``There's no question that people who are involved in lives of petty crime, a lot of the reason for that is because they don't have anything to do, a lack of alternatives, lack of self-esteem, hopelessness,'' he said. ``But it has been hard,'' he said, because of ``the natural reluctance of a person to admit in front of others that they cannot read, plus the fact that we're learning. We don't have many precedents to follow.'' One defendant who declined Alderson's offer is Otis King, a 60-year pulpwood cutter from Louann in Union County who never learned to read or write. King decided in November to pay a $90.25 fine for public drunkenness because, he said, ``I don't have no transportation, no way of getting back and forth up there.'' From an early age, King went to work to support his mother, and acknowledges that poring over books would be frightening. ``I've worked all my life around sawmills and in the woods, ever since I was big enough,'' he said. ``At the time, it would have been nice if I could have (learned to read), I wanted to. But a man at my age, no, I just can't see it.'' Authorities in some other states also have been trying to get offenders to better themselves. In Virginia, a new ``no read-no release'' Learning Incentive Program requires state prison inmates to read above sixth-grade level to be eligible for parole, and offers programs at 52 Department of Corrections schools. The prosecutor's office in New York's Bronx borough began offering jail inmates a range of educational services about four years ago. Those who appear in Alderson's court are read their rights and must sign a waiver saying they understand them. ``I use that as kind of a primitive way of screening,'' Alderson said. ``It's real easy when I see an X (signature). More often than not, though, it's someone who cannot read and struggles signing their name.'' Alderson recommends participation in the learning program ``based on instinct.'' Wanda Sturdivant, an assistant municipal clerk, said ``everyone he's sent through has needed the program'' at Oil Belt, but none has completed the course. One man fined for having a dog at large wanted to attend but had no transportation, she said. Another man who attended for a while and quit may be getting help on his own, she said. Still, Alderson said he was convinced the program eventually will succeed. ``Each and every one of God's creatures is terribly important, and if one person can learn to read because of something we might have done here, I think it's a success,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Telescope Eyepiece Used by Edwin Hubble is Riding on the Shuttle
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The shuttle that put the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit also carries an instrument used in the 1920s by astronomer Edwin Hubble: the eyepiece from what once was the world's most powerful telescope. ``It's a great pleasure to have something of such historical significance and something that so directly symbolizes Edwin Hubble's fundamental contributions to astronomy,'' astronaut Kathy Sullivan said Friday as she circled the Earth in space shuttle Discovery. The eyepiece from the Mount Wilson Observatory's 100-inch Hooker Telescope was carried into orbit by Sullivan. After she brings the eyepiece back to Earth, it will be placed on display at the observatory. ``It's basically a symbolic gesture from the past of astronomy to the future of astronomy,'' said Lyn McAfee, spokeswoman for the Mount Wilson Institute. The Pasadena-based group runs the observatory, located in the San Gabriel Mountains outside Los Angeles. ``The discoveries made by Hubble on the 100-inch telescope at Mount Wilson gave us a giant leap forward in our understanding of the universe,'' McAfee said. ``We believe the Hubble Space Telescope will do the same thing.'' The Hooker Telescope was the world's most powerful telescope from its construction in 1918 until 1948, when the 200-inch Hale Telescope was placed in operation at Mount Palomar Observatory northeast of San Diego. Using the Hooker Telescope, Hubble was the first to determine the distance to a galaxy outside the Milky Way, the institute said in a statement. ``This crucial discovery provided the first definite proof that other galaxies existed far beyond the confines of our own local galaxy,'' the institute said. During the 1920s and 1930s, Hubble and an assistant used the Hooker telescope to take thousands of photographs of faint galaxies, showing that most of them were moving away from each other very quickly. ``This provided observational evidence for the concept, suggested by Einstein's Theory of Relativity, that the universe is expanding,'' the institute said. Hubble's work helped convince scientists the universe was created in a giant explosion, called the ``big bang,'' an estimated 15 billion years ago. The Hooker Telescope was mothballed in 1985 by the Carnegie Institution, former operator of the observatory, in a money-saving move. The institute hopes to obtain funds to reopen it.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Honors Giraffe Project
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today named the Giraffe Project of Langley, Wash., as a ``daily point of light'' for recognizing and encouraging bold community service. Founded in 1983, the organization rewards people who ``stick their necks out for the common good,'' even if doing so means risking losing a job or being ostracized by neighbors, the White House said in a statement. So far, 483 individuals have been given giraffe rewards that praises them for ``courageous actions,'' the statement said. Bush names an individual or group each day for exemplifying his ``thousand points of light'' theme of volunteerism. Recipients get a plaque and a letter from the president.
DOC.HEAD: Michigan Sausage-Makers Recall Links
DOC.TEXT: Sausage made by two Michigan food processors is being recalled voluntarily because the meat may contain sulfite. Dave's Sausage Factory in Detroit recalled 3,000 pounds, and Mancini Sausage Co. in Harpers Woods 500 pounds, the Agriculture Department said Friday. ``Sulfites can pose serious health risks for people who are sensitive to these compounds,'' said Lester M. Crawford, head of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. The sausage links produced by Dave's are sold under the names ``Wisbisky's Polish Sausage,'' ``Vetro's Italian Sausage'' and ``Dave's Pork Links.'' The first two products are sold in clear plastic bags and weigh about 1{ pounds each. The label shows the product name and has ``Est. 10198'' printed inside the USDA inspection seal. ``Dave's Pork Links'' are repackaged by stores and may be sold under a private brand name, Crawford said. All three products are distributed to grocery stores, delicatessens and restaurants in Michigan. The Mancini Sausage Co. product is sold only to delicatessens under the name, ``Polish Brand Sausage'' and is also in clear plastic bags, with a weight of 1{ pounds each. White printing on the bag shows the product name, ``Est. 10210'' printed inside the inspection seal, and the words ``produced by Mancini Sausage Company.'' Consumers with question about the recall may phone the toll-free USDA hot line at 1-800-535-4555 Monday through Friday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: Charges Dropped in `Ill Wind' Probe
DOC.TEXT: Federal charges against a figure in the defense industry probe have been dismissed by a federal judge who said the indictment may have been an act of retaliation. Thomas E. Muldoon, a former consultant to Norden Systems, already had been convicted on eight felonies, including conspiracy and bribery of a public official. Soon after his attorney filed an appeal on that conviction, Muldoon was indicted on charges of trafficking in secret defense information. U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. in Alexandria, Va., wrote Friday that there was ``a realistic likelihood of vindictiveness on the part of the United States in causing the return of the present indictment in retaliation for the defendant Thomas E. Muldoon's going to trial or noting an appeal for his prior conviction or both.'' Muldoon, 60, was sentenced to 27 months in prison and fined $10,000 for his conviction arising from the investigation of fraud in defense procurement, code named ``Ill Wind.''
DOC.HEAD: Rostropovich Attacks Restrictions On Aid To Arts
DOC.TEXT: The arts should not be subject to censorship or bureaucratic restrictions on government funding, Soviet-born symphony director Mstislav Rostropovich told Congress. Rostropovich, artistic director of the National Symphony Orchestra, told a Senate hearing Friday on financing for the National Endowment for the Arts that it was Soviet censorship that drove him to the United States. He argued for reauthorization of the NEA, without restrictions intended to prevent federal aid for obscene art. ``Art and literature should be judged by the conscience of the creator, his peers in his field and all of the people, not be a separate bureaucracy, artificially compressing the arteries and veins of this life-sustaining circulation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Earthquakes Hit SF Bay Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 7 grafs with aftershocks, power outages, quotes; pick up 5th graf, `An earthquake ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two moderate earthquakes struck the San Francisco Bay Area on Friday night, causing scattered power outages and shaking Candlestick Park during a baseball game. There were no reports of damage or injuries. The largest earthquake struck about 9:40 p.m. and was centered in the Walnut Creek area, about 25 miles east of San Francisco, and had a preliminary reading of 4.6 on the Richter scale, said Lou Page, a spokesman for the U. S. Geological Survey. An aftershock with a reading of 4.3 struck at 9:47 p.m. followed at 9:59 p.m. by a 2.5 shake, Page said. The quakes occurred along the Concord fault and is one of a recent swarm of tremors there, Page said. ``We really felt it. There was a sudden crack and then a rolling that goes on and on,'' said Mary Bacon, nursing supervisor at Mt. Diablo Hospital in Concord. ``Some of the patients and some of the employees were shook up and were sick to their stomachs.'' Pacific Gas & Electric reported 1,300 customers in Concord lost power, and scattered outages were reported in Alamo, said Brad Thomas, PG&E spokesman. The first quake was felt at Candlestick Park where the San Francisco Giants were in the sixth inning of a game against the St. Louis Cardinals. An earthquake measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale struck the San Francisco area on Oct. 17, killing 67 people and causing an estimated $7 billion in damage. That quake struck moments before the start of a World Series game at Candlestick between the Giants and the Oakland Athletics; the series was delayed more than a week. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Mauled By Same Dog Who Apparently Attacked Brother Two Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old boy was in stable condition after he was mauled by his family's pit bull, the same dog that apparently attacked his brother two years ago, authorities said. Bruce Scott Herrin suffered deep bites on his face, shoulders and chest when the pit bull, Kone, attacked him as they played in their back yard on Thursday. His mother, Athena Herrin, pulled the 90-pound animal off her son, carried the boy into the house, called rescue workers then shot the dog to death, said Lake County Sheriff's Capt. Glen Perkins. The boy underwent five hours of surgery Thursday night, and on Friday his condition was upgraded from extremely critical to stable. In the summer of 1988, the dog apparently attacked Bobbie Herrin, then 2, when the boy tried to hug the dog as it slept, said Dennis Burke, Lake County animal control officer. The boy suffered cuts and a fractured skull when his head hit the table. The dog then was locked up until an investigator reported that Kone was calm and friendly and showed no signs of aggressive behavior.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Hits Panama
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook a province near the Costa Rican border, knocking out electricity in one town and snapping a gasoline pipeline. However, no major damage or injuries were reported, fire department personnel told The Associated Press by telephone. The quake, which measured 6.1 on the Richter scale, struck Chiriqui province, 275 miles west of Panama City, Friday night. Electricity was cut off for a few minutes in Puerto Armuelles, along the Costa Rican border, and a gasoline pipeline broke but was quickly repaired, a fire department employee said. Physicist Jaime Toral of the University of Panama's Seismic Institute said by telephone that the epicenter of the quake was near Golfito, Costa Rica, along the Panamanian border. He said it struck at 8:24 p.m. and that an earlier tremor registered 4.3 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means the ground motion is 10 times greater. An earthquake of 6.0 can cause severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Visiting Nurses Say Inner-City Care Dangerous
DOC.TEXT: Caring for the sick and homebound in America's inner cities has become increasingly hazardous, and many visiting nurses won't venture into crime-torn neighborhoods without a security escort. But some nursing organizations say they're having a tough enough time collecting adequate health-care insurance reimbursements without having to worry about forking out money for security guards. In Providence, the Visiting Nurse Association of Rhode Island has threatened to stop taking on new patients in areas of the city it considers dangerous. The need for security escorts has grown dramatically, but the city cannot be persuaded to kick in money for protection services, said its president, Jane A. Mackenzie. The threat may be drastic, but no choice exists, she said. Several weeks ago, one nurse, Mary Seccareccia, was making her rounds at a housing complex in the city when someone fired a shot as she got out of her car, shattering the rear window, Mrs. Mackenzie said. ``I have never seen the same degree of personal threat in my whole time in public health nursing,'' said Mrs. Mackenzie, who has worked in nursing for 40 years. ``I think we've avoided a lot of problems by having the escort with the nurses.'' Val Halamandarias, president of the Washington-based National Association of Home Care, said violence is rife in some drug-ridden neighborhoods and nurses are increasingly getting caught in the crossfire. ``It's a huge problem nationwide, particularly in the big urban centers,'' she said. ``I can't think of a city over a million (population) that doesn't have a problem.'' In Providence, security escorts have helped. No nurses have reported being physically assaulted since the Visiting Nurse Association began using unarmed security escorts almost a decade ago, said VNA spokeswoman Cheryl Lisi. But as the violence has escalated, so has the need for security _ and for money to pay for guards, Mrs. Mackenzie said. Insurance once paid for health care to patients, while support from philanthropists and charitable organizations covered administrative costs for interpreters and security escorts, she said. Now, insurance companies don't always cover all of the health-care costs and the VNA has to dip into its pot of administrative money for patient care. Last year, she said, Medicaid and Medicare payments to the VNA fell short of covering the actual costs of the services provided by $460,779. The association has turned to the city for help. If it doesn't get $156,000, it will stop taking clients in dangerous neighborhoods, Mrs. Mackenzie said. Providence is the only community in Rhode Island that does not help fund the association, she charged. But the city's administration director, John Simmons, said Providence gave the association $22,000 from a federal grant this year, and he also questioned whether its financial or security concerns were as bad as the nurses claim. ``We're not sure at this time that the VNA needs money,'' he said. ``There are other agencies that go into the city and do not need escort services.'' Simmons said city officials would be happy to work with the VNA to find new ``approaches in how you provide services.'' Providence is not alone in its funding difficulties, and home health services around the country have had to try to tap other sources to stay afloat, Halamandarias said. The Visiting Nurse Society of New York turned to Broadway earlier this month, sponsoring a benefit performance of ``Cat On A Hot Tin Roof'' to raise money, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Pneumonia-Stricken Actress Moved From Intensive Care to Private Care
DOC.TEXT: Actress Elizabeth Taylor, who was gravely ill last weekend in her three-week battle with pneumonia, is improving and was moved from a hospital intensive care unit to a private room, officials said. ``According to her physicians she is responding well to treatment for pneumonia. She continues to improve and her condition is listed as stable,'' said a prepared statement issued Friday by St. John's Hospital and Health Center. The actress was moved to a private room Thursday evening, it said. A ventilator used to help Miss Taylor breathe earlier this week was removed Wednesday. Miss Taylor, 58, entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a persistent fever and sinus infection. Her condition worsened and she was transferred April 16 to St. John's. She had been in serious condition in the intensive care ward at St. John's since last Sunday. Doctors said that at one point last weekend she nearly died. The Oscar-winning star of ``Butterfield 8'' and ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf'' has been troubled with health problems for years, particularly recurring back troubles. She suffered a nearly fatal bout of pneumonia in 1961 and in 1983 acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and pain killers prescribed for a wide range of health problems. Miss Taylor has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse problems at the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Kremlin Again Turns Down Lithuania Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with Prunskiene comment on potential compromise, coal supplies cut off; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin has again rejected Lithuania's attempts to open formal talks with the Soviet government about the crisis over the republic's independence drive, according to Lithuania's Vilnius Radio. The radio, monitored by the BBC in London on Friday night, quoted Bronius Kuzmickas, the deputy chairman of Lithuania's Supreme Council legislature, as saying that a parliamentary delegation had met with some high-ranking officials in Moscow. But the officials reiterated President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's position that no talks with the government would take place unless Lithuania rescinded its March 11 declaration of independence, the radio said. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said her government still hopes to begin talks without rolling back on independence decisions, but it is considering a proposed temporary freeze on secessionist actions as the maximum concession it might offer Moscow. ``This is a compromise which should be viewed as the maximum. This is the limit,'' she told a Friday night news conference, according to the Soviet news agency Tass. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis has said the republic's legislature, the Supreme Council, will consider the freeze proposal, which came from the leaders of France and Germany. The legislature is scheduled to reconvene Wednesday. A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman in Moscow, Vadim Perfiliev, said Friday he had no official reaction to the French and German suggestion. Lithuania wants an immediate dialogue, Landsbergis said Friday, and ``a termination of the Soviet economic blockade against Lithuania would be beneficial to the atmosphere of this dialogue.'' The Kremlin has imposed a blockade on gas, oil and other supplies to Lithuania to pressure its leaders to rescind their March 11 declaration of independence. Tass reported today that coal had been added to the embargo list. Much of the coal Lithuania consumes is imported from Poland, and the republic owes about $1.6 million for coal supplies, so they have been stopped, the news agency said. Vilnius Radio reported that medicines including antibiotics were in short supply, but that the situation was not believed to be critical. On Friday in Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Mrs. Prunskiene had been granted a U.S. visa for unofficial, business travel and said she was expected to visit sometime next week. The United States and other Western countries have refused to impose sanctions on the Soviet Union for its efforts to stop Lithuania's independence drive. On Thursday, 52-year-old Stanislovas Jamaitis died of burns suffered when he doused his clothes with gasoline and set himself ablaze in front of the Bolshoi Theater in central Moscow to protest the Kremlin pressure. Jamaitis left suicide notes to his wife, Stasala, and to Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. The Supreme Council released the texts on Friday, said spokeswoman Rita Radzavicius.
