She translated them from Lithuanian to Russian and read them by telephone. Tass also reported the existence of the note to Jamaitis' wife, saying it ``spoke of an impossible family life and a desire to commit suicide.'' The version released by Lithuanian authorities apologized for ``something bad'' in his marriage, but stressed political motives. ``I went to Moscow to set myself on fire in Red Square,'' he said in both notes. The Bolshoi is a few blocks from Red Square, where security is heavier. ``The occupiers have cut off energy supplies and people are being thrown out of work,'' Jamaitis wrote. He would kill himself to ``let Gorbachev know that Lithuanians will not live in a Lithuania that is not independent,'' said the note read by the spokeswoman. Kremlin officials have said Lithuania may become independent, but at a slower pace and within the framework of the Soviet constitution. A new law calls for a referendum and a maximum five-year period to negotiate specifics of secession. Many non-Lithuanian residents of the republic oppose independence and on Friday they staged a truck blockade during rush hour in Vilnius, the capital. Supporters of the Lithuanian popular front Sajudis dragged the trucks from the streets with tractors, Tass said. The blockade was organized by members of a Lithuanian Communist Party splinter still loyal to the Kremlin and by members of Yedinstvo, consisting mostly of Russian residents of Lithuania, Ms. Radzevicius said. Just over 80 percent of the republic's population is Lithuanian, and some Russian, Polish and other minority residents fear their rights will be violated after independence.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Evacuated From Indian Reservation Amid Gambling Feud
LaserPhoto XMTL2
DOC.TEXT: Factional fighting between Mohawk bands who disagree over whether gambling should be allowed here sent hundreds of residents fleeing the reservation straddling the U.S.-Canada border. The St. Regis Mohawk Reservation had the look of a war zone Friday. Burned cars lined the roads, many buildings had bullet holes or broken windows and residents, including children, were armed with guns or baseball bats. Gov. Mario Cuomo so far has refused to send New York State Police or National Guardsmen to restore order, despite pleas from one Indian leader and some outsiders. ``We want this situation resolved,'' Cuomo said. ``We're working very hard to figure out how to do it. I think what we've done so far, what the state police have done so far, has been appropriate.'' Residents of the reservation just south of the St. Lawrence River have been divided for months over the presence of gambling casinos and bingo halls on the American side that draw thousands of non-Indian visitors. The U.S. government has declared the gambling halls illegal, but the Mohawks don't recognize federal or state jurisdiction on the reservation. In recent weeks, the feud has exploded into violence, with gambling opponents setting up armed blockades of roads leading to the reservation and sounds of gunfire nightly. Pro-gambling Mohawks tore down the blockades in a bloody battle Tuesday night. On Thursday night, four opponents of gambling were injured, one seriously, when they were beaten with baseball bats. Authorities said another person, an observer invited by anti-gambling forces, was missing. Amid further violence, about 400 evacuees were taken on barges Friday to Cornwall, Ontario, where they were housed overnight in an army transport center. About 5,000 Mohawks live in the Canadian sector of the reservation and authorities estimated that at least 2,000 will be evacuated. The reservation's total population is about 14,000. Police said the reservation was quiet Friday night. But this weekend the casinos are to reopen for the first time since the roadblocks were removed, and authorities feared violence would flare anew. Mike Mitchell, chief of the Canadian Mohawk Council, said he decided to evacuate women, children and the elderly from the reservation Friday because of the previous trouble. ``Everybody was in a state of fear,'' Mitchell said. ``I couldn't see another night of putting people through that. ... Violence all night, machine gunfire ... every five minutes gunfire all over the village.'' Security was tight on a bridge across the Canadian border leading to Cornwall. Local police armed with shotguns stopped cars leaving and entering the bridge, asking for identification and searching suspicious vehicles for weapons. Cornwall Constable Scott Hanton said police had heard reports that weapons might be smuggled into the evacuation center. ``We're in a heck of a situation,'' he said. ``We don't have any jurisdiction on the reservation, and we're stuck in the middle of it.'' On the American side of the bridge, state police and U.S. Customs officials also stopped cars and checked for weapons. Barbara Barnes, an opponent of gambling, said some of the residents of the American side of the reservation were also scared. ``I think anybody who has bullets coming at them should be scared,'' she said. ``It's been a very harrowing experience.'' Barnes said some people had voluntarily left their homes and gone to live with friends or relatives off the reservation. Barnes criticized the governor for refusing to get involved. ``We have to have law enforcement here,'' she said. ``We can't continue with this lawlessness. Any non-Indian community you wouldn't have what's happened here.'' The Canadian Embassy in Washington has contacted the U.S. State Department Thursday to underline concerns about the violence and the lack of U.S. policing on the reserve. ``We made no specific suggestions, but our government finds the situation alarming and we are concerned that something needs to be done,'' said Patricia Low-Bedard, a spokeswoman for the Canadian Department of External Affairs. On Thursday, U.S. Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the select committee on Indian affairs, wrote Cuomo expressing his concern about the ``most grave situation'' at St. Regis.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian President Vows to Double Anti-drug Forces
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco pledged to double the size of an anti-terrorist police force following the assassination of a presidential candidate that authorities blame on drug traffickers. Carlos Pizarro, a former guerrilla leader turned politician, was shot to death Thursday aboard a jetliner carrying 97 people. His bodyguards then gunned down the assassin. The slaying was the latest of many blamed on the country's leading cocaine cartel in the city of Medellin, and it prompted two political leaders on Friday to call for a reorganization of the military to help keep order before the May 27 elections. In a nationally televised speech Friday night, Barco said he will double the size of the anti-terrorist police force, which now has about 3,000 members. Acknowledging that political candidates are afraid to appear in public, he said the government will order more free television time for them and also provide free radio time. Government-controlled television now allows each candidate a half-hour of air time during the entire campaign. Barco didn't say how much more time they would get. Pizarro was the third presidential candidate assassinated in the past eight months. He was a former leader of the M-19 guerrilla movement. Hundreds of leftist guerrillas belonging the group laid down their arms last month and formed a political party with Pizarro as its presidential candidate. Other assassinations in the last six years have included a justice minister, an attorney general, several judges, journalists, students, professors and union leaders. A man called the Bogota radio station Caracol within hours of Pizarro's death and said the Medellin Cartel had ordered his killing. However, a faxed communique Friday supposedly from the cartel denied reponsibility. It accused police of making phony statements purporting to represent the cartel. Presidential candidate Alvaro Gomez, suggesting Barco lacks the confidence of the military, said the president should name a three-man council to run the army to avoid a military coup. In a written statement, Gomez said: ``Never has there been such a great and pathetic image of anarchy.'' Former president Alfonso Lopez Michelsen said the entire armed forces must be reorganized. ``The credibility of the authorities is on trial, and the successive display of inefficiency shown by the deaths of three presidential candidates forces us to consider reogranization of the army and other security forces,'' he said. Lopez, of the governing Liberal Party, was president from 1974 to 1978. A Barco spokesman, Minister of Government Horacio Serpa, flatly rejected Gomez's suggestion of a triumvirate to run the military. As for Lopez's idea, Serpa said Barco would reorganize the armed forces if it becomes necessary. The August assassination of another candidate, Sen. Luis Carlos Galan of the Liberal Party, prompted the government to step up its crackdown on the cocaine cartels. Since then, drug traffickers have killed more than 230 people. About 100 ticketed passengers Friday refused to board a domestic Avianca flight in the coastal city of Barranquilla when they learned that a leftist congresswoman and her heavily armed security contingent would be traveling with them, radio reports said. It was on a flight to Barranquilla from Bogota that Pizarro was shot to death. The radio chains Caracol and RCN said that in Friday's incident, the plane stayed on the ground for 2{ hours until about 50 passengers finally decided to board. The plane then departed.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Everybody was in a state of fear ... Violence all night, machine gunfire ... every five minutes gunfire all over the village.'' _ Mike Mitchell, chief of the Canadian Mohawk Council, on why he decided to evacuate women, children and the elderly from the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation, hit by violence between two bands over gambling.
``We hope to impress the Congress. We hope to impress the nation.'' _ Dr. J.C. Willke, president of the National Right to Life Committee, sponsor of Saturday's anti-abortion rally in Washington.

``When we have a persistent $49 billion trade deficit with Japan and that nation will not abide by a variety of agreements, freeing them from the threat of trade sanctions makes no objective sense.'' _ U.S. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, upset over President Bush's removal of Japan from a ``hit list'' of unfair traders.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguans Complain of Devaluation Of Currency
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan tempers are flaring over the new government's devaluation of the national currency, which has caused prices to shoot up in an economy already plagued by soaring inflation. ``This new government will be good for nothing. Everything is more expensive,'' a housewife with two children in tow said Friday to nobody in particular as she walked among the stalls at a Managua market. She was one of only a handful of customers at the sprawling market, which is usually packed with shoppers. Francisca Guevara, a vendor, said she had raised only the price of cooking oil because it was imported from Guatemala and she needed to buy dollars to obtain it. ``But I'll have to raise the price of everything else, too, this afternoon,'' she said. ``I first have to figure out my costs.'' Other vendors already had raised their prices. The 2-day-old U.S.-backed government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro slashed the value of the cordoba in half. Prices for many items increased, while the wages of most Nicaraguans stayed the same. Many earned just $30 a month before the devaluation. At the new prices, a pound of rice, one of beans and one of beef would cost a total of 205,000 cordobas, or $1.46. Mrs. Chamorro inherited an economy damaged by more than a decade of mismanagement by her leftist Sandinista precedessors, war with the U.S.-backed Contra rebels and a U.S. trade embargo that has now been lifted. Inflation was a world-record 36,000 percent in 1988. The Sandinistas managed to bring it down to 1,800 percent in 1989 with their own austerity program. The exchange rate of the cordoba went from 70,800 to 140,000 per U.S. dollar in the so-called parallel market. Thus, anyone buying dollars at the legal exchange houses that constitute Nicaragua's parallel market had to pay twice as much Friday as Thursday. The official exchange rate had been 53,800 cordobas to the dollar since the last devaluation April 17. The official market sells a limited amount of dollars set aside for importing only crucial goods such as medicines, oil and fertilizer. The parallel market provides a greater but still limited amount of dollars for less crucial imports, but at a higher price. The black market meets the rest of Nicaragua's demand for dollars. The devaluation was a blow to Nicaraguans who buy dollars to import goods. But that was the idea: to make it more expensive to import goods and cheaper to export Nicaraguan items. The government hopes the move will help cut the country's trade deficit, which was $413 million in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Bill Heads To Governor
With PM-Anti-Abortion Rally, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Johnsen is cq, 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut is set to become the first state to guarantee a woman's right to choose abortion under state law even if the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion is struck down by the Supreme Court. The state Senate on Friday overwhelmingly approved a bill that effectively codifies into state law much of Roe vs. Wade. It also repeals the state's unenforced criminal anti-abortion statutes. The bill now goes to Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, who has said he will sign it. Dawn Johnsen, legal director for the National Abortion Rights Action League, called the bill an important victory for abortion-rights forces. ``This is the first state law that says a woman has a right to choose an abortion, not just under the Constitution, but under state law,'' she told The New York Times. The New Hampshire legislature recently passed similar legislation, but Gov. Judd Gregg vetoed it. The Pro-Life Council of Connecticut also claimed victory, however, because the bill requires girls under 16 to get counseling before getting an abortion and encourages them to tell their parents. The Connecticut Right To Life Corp. firmly opposed the measure. In a slight variation on the Roe vs. Wade decision, the bill allows abortions late in pregnancy, when the fetus is capable of living outside the womb, only when the life or health of the mother is in danger. The Senate approved the bill by a 32-3 vote after about 45 minutes of debate. The House endured five hours of debate on the bill last week. States have taken a more prominent role in the abortion issue since the Supreem Court last summer decided in a Missouri case to let pass more restrictive abortion laws. The court indicated it might modify or reverse Roe vs. Wade. ``Even if the Supreme Court were to reverse Roe v. Wade ... this statute would be the governing standard for the state of Connecticut,'' said Sen. Richard Blumenthal, the Democratic vice-chairman of the Judiciary Committee and a co-sponsor of the bill. ``I think what the Supreme Court is saying in effect to the states ... is we're going to turn this issue over to you. Connecticut has taken the gauntlet and said we're ready to face that issue and we're going to be pro-choice,'' he said. The Senate easily rejected three Republican amendments. One would have restored criminal sanctions against anyone performing an abortion and permitted the father or grandparent of the fetus to sue for $10,000 in damages. Another would have required minors to notify parents before an abortion could be performed. ``It's a sad day in the state of Connecticut when we would intervene to deny parents fundamental rights,'' said Republican Sen. Thomas Scott, a sponsor of the parental notification amendment. Allowing a child to make such a decision on her own, Scott added, ``is unconscionable.'' But some Republicans criticized Scott for the amendment. ``I don't think we can mandate morals or conscience or anything else ... and that's what we're trying to do'' with such amendments, said Republican Sen. M. Adela Eads.

Floodwaters in north-central Texas were receding early today, while the northwestern tier got snow and rain dampened parts of the South and Midwest. Tornadoes spawned by thunderstorms touched down Friday near Magee, Miss., and near the Texas towns of Waco, Coolidge, Groesbeck and Hearne, the National Weather Service said. At least 200 homes in the Texas community of Horseshoe Bend, which is ringed by the rain-swollen Brazos River, remained under water Friday, authorities said. Water stood 4 feet deep in the streets of Brownwood, Texas, receding slowly. Lake Brownwood couldn't handle 16 inches of rain since Wednesday, authorities said. ``It's going to be a long-term thing, two or three weeks minimum before businesses are back in operation,'' Brownwood Mayor Bert Massey said. ``It's the worst disaster to ever hit Brownwood. We're talking about millions upon millions of dollars in damages in the business district alone,'' he said. Hail also battered Texas, including hailstones nearly an inch in diameter southeast of Dallas and north of Kerens. Hail the size of golf balls fell on Hillsboro and several other Texas cities. Rain early today fell in St. Louis, Des Moines, Iowa, Little Rock, Ark., Nashville, Tenn., Birmingham, Ala., Boise, Idaho, Medford, Ore., Spokane, Wash. Rapid City got snow. The National Weather Service posted a winter storm warning for today over the western mountains of Montana. Snow advisories were posted today elsewhere in Montana and parts of Idaho, Washington state, Oregon and Wyoming. Unseasonably cold temperatures, with snow in higher elevations, were predicted today for the northern Sierra Nevada region and the northern mountains of California. Utah could receive a foot of snow in higher mountains by Sunday night. High temperatures Friday from the northern Atlantic Coast to the upper Great Lakes were milder than usual. The weather service said more than 36 high temperature records for the date were broken or tied. The new temperature records include a high of 86 degrees in Bridgeport, Conn., 89 degrees in Cape Hatteras, N.C., and 92 degrees in Boston. The high Friday in the Lower 48 states was 105 degrees in Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: His ticket from the Minnesota Lottery showed the man had won $1,000, but when he left the lottery office, he owed the state money and had the police on his trail. The lottery winner, whose named was not released, checked into the suburban Roseville lottery office with a winning $1,000 ticket last week, lottery spokeswoman Judy Hohmann said. Office employees looked through his records, however, and found he owed the state more than $1,000. To close its transaction with the unlucky winner, the state issued him a check for $0.00 _ and a tax form. Even though the winner didn't receive the money, he did, for a fleeting moment, have income to offset his debt, Hohmann said, so he wound up owing tax on a jackpot he never saw. The man threatened a guard before he left the office, and police were looking for him in connection with the threat, Hohmann said.

DOC.HEAD: Papp Raises Enough Money After Rejecting NEA Grant
DOC.TEXT: Producer Joseph Papp has received pledges of more than $60,000 after rejecting a $50,000 federal arts grant because he doesn't like the Jesse Helms-inspired strings attached to it. Donations to Papp, director of the New York Shakespeare Festival, ranged from a $50,000 pledge from television producer Mark Goodson to much smaller pledges, The New York Times reported today. Papp rejected a $50,000 National Endowment for the Arts grant because NEA recipients now must sign a form saying they agree to abide by federal anti-obscenity legislation. The legislation was sponsored last fall by Helms, the Republican senator from North Carolina, who objected to government funding for exhibits by Robert Mappelthorpe and Andres Serrano. ``I cannot in all good conscience accept any money from the NEA as long as the Helms-inspired amendment on obscenity is part of our agreement,'' Papp wrote in a letter to the NEA on Thursday. Papp said that while he was happy with the private pledges, ``an institution like mine needs the continuity of support that the NEA provides. But maybe this will create a climate in which this obscenity issue can be dealt with in a different way.'' The NEA money was supposed to be used for Papp's annual Festival Latino, a month-long showing of theater, movies and music from Latin American cultures. Papp said the festival would be sponsored from private foundations. Papp said his organization has applied for $550,000 in grants for the 1990 season. But he told the NEA, ``We are prepared not to accept this money should it be awarded while the Helms restriction remains in force.'' The law says NEA grants cannot be used to fund works that depict ``sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific merit.''

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Curtails Milk-Producing Synthetic Hormone
DOC.TEXT: The governor of the nation's No. 1 dairy state signed into law a 14-month restriction on the use of a synthetic hormone that increases milk production when injected into cows. The moratorium, the nation's first prohibition of a product of genetic engineering, forbids commercial use of bovine somatotropin (BST) until June 1, 1991, allowing it only for research. Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who signed the legislation Friday, vetoed an alternative bill that would have forbidden use of the protein until six months after its commercial use is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Thompson said he did not want the moratorium to extend later than 1991 because BST use by farmers in other states could put Wisconsin's dairy industry at a market disadvantage. The Minnesota Legislature approved a bill Thursday establishing a one-year moratorium if the Wisconsin legislation became law. Supporters of the hormone warned that Wisconsin dairy farmers could be hurt if the state became an ``island'' surrounded by states that permitted its use. Opponents contended increased production could push milk prices down, thus driving smaller dairy farmers out of business. Democratic Sen. Russell D. Feingold, a leader of the Legislature's campaign against BST or bovine growth hormone (BGH), called the bill ``the first moratorium ever on BGH in the nation.'' ``It's more than a victory. It's a start of what will be a national movement,'' Feingold said. Democratic Rep. Barbara Gronemus said that although the new law temporarily prevents farmers from buying the drug, the Republican governor's vetoes may not prevent marketing of milk from test animals. ``It appears that the milk from these test herds could be used,'' she said. ``I'm really disappointed about that aspect of it. To allow the byproducts to go into the food chain is really unacceptable to me.'' The moratorium stems from concern by the Legislature that consumers will be leery of milk from treated cows, reducing sales of cheese and other dairy products important to Wisconsin's economy. Some farm organizations argued the drug's ability to increase milk production as much as 20 percent would help corporate farms with large herds to dominate the market, putting smaller family farms out of business. ``It's not feasible for ourselves to build a wall around this state and prevent new technology from coming in here,'' the governor said. ``It's going to be a sad day in Wisconsin when we stop research.'' The diet given treated cattle contains more fat than usual. Critics say the process means added production expense that only big farms can afford. Jeffrey Remsik, a spokesman for the Animal Health Institute, said chemical companies that are developing BST are disappointed with the moratorium. The new law damages the Dairy State's chances of attracting biotechnology research, Remsik said. The governor's action ``tends to undermine the traditional federal regulatory system and sends a strong message that Wisconsin is not interested in new technologies,'' he said. Remsik said a court may have to decide whether the measure Thompson signed actually triggers the Minnesota moratorium.

DOC.HEAD: Would-Be Burglars Die in Bricked-Up Chimney
DOC.TEXT: Two would-be burglars died when they became stuck in the bricked-up chimney of a grocery store, police said. The owner of the store in the Bronx borough noticed a smell coming from the chimney and police found two decomposed bodies in it, police spokesman Fred Weiner said Friday. The bodies had been there about a week. ``They found one body at the base of the chimney and underneath they found a second body,'' Weiner said. ``It was an apparent burglary that went wrong.'' The corpses were not identified.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Jolts SF Bay Area But Causes No Injuries Or Serious Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Susanne in 2nd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A sharp earthquake jolted the eastern San Francisco Bay area, rattling windows and sending merchandise tumbling from the shelves of stores. The quake, which measured 4.6 on the Richter scale, occurred at 9:41 p.m. Friday and was centered in Walnut Creek, about 25 miles east of San Francisco, according to the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park. The quake and two aftershocks, one at 9:47 p.m. measuring 4.3 and another at 9:59 measuring 2.5., occurred on the Concord fault and were part of a swarm of mild quakes that shook the normally placid fault earlier this month, said USGS spokeswoman Lou Page. There were no reports of injuries or serious damage, but the quake spilled items into store aisles in several communities. Susanne Desser, a waitress at the Denny's restaurant in Danville, said that while some customers ``kind of get a kick'' out of earthquakes, others lose their appetites. ``A lot of people ordered, the quake hit and they didn't want to eat,'' she said. In Concord, the six-story Mt. Diablo Hospital ``really shook,'' said nursing supervisor Mary Bacon. ``There was a sudden crack and then a rolling that goes on and on,'' she said. ``Some of the patients and some of the employees were shook up and were sick to their stomachs.'' The quake knocked out power to 1,300 customers in Concord, east of Walnut Creek, and scattered outages were reported in nearby Alamo, said Pacific Gas & Electric spokesman Brad Thomas. The Bay Area Rapid Transit district stopped service to check the tracks, but trains resumed running at 10:05 p.m. Mild shaking also was felt at the press box at Candlestick Park, where the San Francisco Giants were in the sixth inning of a game with the St. Louis Cardinals. Tremors of up to 5.5 on the Richter scale were felt in the Bay Area on April 6 and April 18. None caused any major damage. The 7.1-magnitude quake that hit the region Oct. 17 claimed 67 lives and caused about $7.1 billion in damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage in the local area, a 5 considerable damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Paralyzed Woman Allowed to Die
DOC.TEXT: A paralyzed woman stricken with an incurable disease died within an hour of being taken off a respirator after she convinced a judge she wanted to be allowed to die. Albert Stussy said his 51-year-old wife, Thelma, was disconnected from a respirator at 4:20 p.m. Friday and died between 5:05 and 5:10 p.m. He and their teen-age son and daughter were at her bedside at Neumann Medical Center. ``We made sure she knew we loved her,'' Stussy said Friday night. ``She was sedated very well with Valium. They gave her a shot every 10 minutes and made sure she wasn't in any pain.'' Mrs. Stussy had suffered from Lou Gehrig's disease, or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, for two years and was admitted to the hospital in late December. The degenerative disease destroys the nervous system and paralyzes its victims. Mrs. Stussy was paralyzed from the neck down and had been in constant pain. She could not speak, but communicated by blinking to answer ``yes'' and moving her head slightly from side to side to answer ``no.'' In an emotional bedside hearing Wednesday, Mrs. Stussy blinked once to tell Common Pleas Court Judge Nicholas M. D'Alessandro that she wanted to be taken off the respirator. In a two-page ruling the next day, the judge granted her wish, giving the hospital one week to comply. The ventilator was turned off by hospital staff, not by her regular physician, Dr. Leonard M. Popowich. ``He had some emotional hang up,'' Stussy said. ``I didn't realize it until today.'' Popowich testified Wednesday that he had no objection to taking Mrs. Stussy off the respirator, but said he did not want to do it personally. She and her family had asked to have the respirator removed, but hospital officials, fearful of a lawsuit on criminal charges, asked the judge to decide. Hospital attorney Claire Obade added that the hospital also was forced to go to court because Pennsylvania has no statutes and only a handful of legal precedents to guide it in right-to-die cases. In asking the court for permission to remove Mrs. Stussy from the respirator, Obade cited a 1987 case in Philadelphia involving a woman in a similar situation. The woman, known only as ``Jane Doe,'' was granted her request.

DOC.HEAD: Police Storm Korean Shipyard, Setting Off Street Battles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE injured to 24 from 20, arrested to 499 from 300; fighting continues late today, plans to end broadcast strike, ADDS details; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ULS2
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of police backed by armored vans stormed the world's largest shipyard by land and sea today to crush a three-day strike. Police said at least 24 people were injured, including 10 policemen, in the dawn raid on the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co., and 499 were arrested. Arrest warrants were issued for six fugitive union leaders. Thousands of workers later battled police wielding clubs and shields in hand-to-hand combat near the shipyard in Ulsan, a port city about 200 miles southeast of Seoul. Some estimates said as many as 20,000 workers were involved in the street protests, including many from affiliated Hyundai companies in the area. As evening approached, the numbers of protesters dwindled to several thousand. The riot police stormed the closed shipyard to rout about 2,000 workers holed up there. Authorities fired hundreds of tear-gas shells from at least 10 armored vans as bulldozers tore down 9-foot-high barricades erected by the workers. An estimated 10,000 riot police rushed in, wearing gas masks and helmets and carrying clubs and shields. Hundreds of workers retaliated by throwing firebombs, steel bars, rocks and pieces of metal. Strikers fired several rounds from at least one of about a dozen homemade canons, but it was not known if anyone was injured from the blasts. About 600 combat police arrived in two patrol boats and surrounded buildings along the shipyard's four-mile seafront. Three police helicopters hovered overhead, urging workers to give up peacefully. About 100 workers climbed up a crane to throw firebombs and metal pipes at police below. Some strikers ran into buildings and threw debris, firebombs and rocks from windows. Columns of black smoke, small fires and clouds of tear gas filled the shipyard and surrounding area for several hours. Most of the strikers inside the shipyard fled during the morning attack. Police said late today that only pockets of resistence remained. ``Get out, police! Police, get out!'' chanted about 150 workers who climbed a 240-foot crane erected on the docks. After today's raid, thousands of workers gathered in the streets to denounce the police action, and some threw stones and firebombs and fought with police. Protesters damaged or destroyed 22 police vehicles, including two buses and five fire engines, police and news reports said. Hyundai had requested government action to end the strike, which threatened to spread to other industries. Negotiations broke down just hours before the raid. The strike was not over wage issues but involved workers' demands for the release from jail of four union leaders charged with starting earlier protests. The company said the matter was a judicial issue and out of its domain. The government issued a statement defending the shipyard raid, saying ``the survival of the national economy was at stake.'' Opposition politicians demanded a special session of the National Assembly to investigate labor unrest. ``It is extremely regrettable the government carried out a military-style operation to suppress the worker's strike,'' said Kim Tae-shik, spokesman for the opposition Party for Peace and Democracy. He called on the government to release the four jailed union leaders. Last year, about 12,000 police firing tear gas stormed the shipyard to end a 109-day strike. The Hyundai Group, owner of the shipyard, is one of South Korea's largest conglomerates. It produces cars, ships, electronics and other products. Shipyard sales last year were $1.5 billion, the company said. About 20,000 of the shipyard's 24,000 employees are unionized. According to the Japan Shipbuilding Industry Association, it is the world's largest, capable of building 14 large ships simultaneously. Union leaders at other Hyundai subsidiaries issued a joint statement threatening to stage sympathy protests. Hundreds of radical students protested today at campuses in Inchon and the provincial city of Kwangju denouncing police action against strikers, the South Korean news agency Yonhap said. In a labor dispute in Seoul, Ahn Dong-su, union leader at Korean Broadcasting System, said operations would return to normal April 30, ending a 17-day strike over a new government-appointed president. Ahn said he had received assurances the president would resign ``at an early date.'' Workers claimed the president was restricting their press freedoms.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Cheer U.S. Trade Decision
With PM-Trade Targets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government today applauded a U.S. decision to drop Japan from a list of unfair trade partners, but it said the Bush administration was wrong to single out India as a violator. President Bush announced Friday he would cite only one country, India, as a ``priority nation'' under a provision of a U.S. trade law that provides for mandatory economic retaliation if foreign trade barriers are not removed within a fixed period. A leading group of private businesses in India today called Bush's action an ``unfortunate and an avoidable development.'' The group, the Associated Chamber of Commerce and Industries, said both the United States and India could have shown greater flexibility in dealing with the trade issue. In a statement in Tokyo, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said, ``The government of Japan welcomes the decision by the U.S. government not to name Japan a `priority foreign country' and regards this as the proper one.'' ``It has been the policy of the government of Japan that economic issues between Japan and the United States should be resolved through dialogue in the spirit of cooperation and joint efforts,'' he said. Kabun Muto, minister of international trade and industry, also welcomed Bush's announcement, but he expressed concern about the naming of India. ``The (United States) one-sidedly cited India as a priority nation, and I must say this may impair the framework of the multilateral free-trade system,'' he said. The dropping of Japan from the list, however, came as a relief to Japanese business leaders. Tokumasa Yoshida, president of Mazda Motor Co., told the nationally circulated Asahi Shimbun newspaper that it was reasonable for the United States to appreciate recent Japanese efforts to lessen trade barriers. But many commentators said the relationship could turn hostile unless the Japanese continue efforts to open their markets to U.S. products. In today's editorial, the Asahi Shimbun said U.S. retaliation may still come if Japan cannot show significant improvement in allowing foreign competition. India has steadfastly refused to modify its restrictive trade policies, which are designed to protect domestic industries by limiting foreign investment and imposing high import duties. India has an $850 million trade surplus with the United States, compared to Japan's surplus of $49 billion. The Japanese surplus represents 45 percent of the total U.S. trade deficit of $109 billion. The United States is India's largest trading partner. India's exports consist primarily of clothing, diamonds, crude oil and cashew nuts. Its chief American imports are fertilizers, chemicals, electronic parts and industrial materials. Under the 1988 U.S. Omnibus Trade Act, Washington can levy tariffs of up to 100 percent on goods imported from a nation judged as an unfair trader.

DOC.HEAD: Precede TOKYO
Japan Sends Accused Hijacker Back to China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with suspect arriving in China
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese man who said he hijacked a plane to Japan to escape political repression flew back to China today under heavy police custody. A traveler on the same Air China flight said Zhang Zhenhai was brought onto the plane before the other passengers and taken off last, with police surrounding him on each end. He and his guards sat in first class. The traveler, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he could not tell if Zhang was handcuffed. China's official Xinhua News Agency reported Zhang's arrival but did not say when he would be tried. Zhang, 36, hijacked a New York-bound Air China flight on Dec. 16 and demanded it fly to South Korea. The pilot landed in Fukuoka, Japan, when Seoul refused landing rights. Zhang asked for political asylum, saying he took part in last year's pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing that ended in an army attack, and would face the death penalty in China. But Japan's high court said it doubted Zhang had been a dissident and ordered his extradition. Japanese officials handed him over to Chinese police earlier today. Human rights groups in Japan and abroad, including Amnesty International, criticized the extradition order. They said Zhang should be tried in Japan for the hijacking. Zhang's wife and child accompanied him during the hijacking but did not appear to understand what was going on. They were returned to China shortly after, and Chinese officials have refused to comment on their fate.

DOC.HEAD: Six Mexicans Arrested In Abduction of Doctor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with newspaper report that informer arranged kidnapping with approval of DEA agents. No pickup. ^LaserPhoto MO2
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have jailed six Mexicans for questioning about the abduction of a doctor taken to the United States to face trial in the murder of an American drug agent, the government announced. Officials also said that an informer for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration had masterminded the kidnapping. The Los Angeles Times today quoted the informer as saying he did so with the approval of two DEA agents. Washington has denied that the DEA was involved in the kidnapping or that U.S. officials had paid bounty hunters to abduct the doctor. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and other Mexican officials contend the April 2 kidnapping of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain violates Mexican law. Mexico has threatened to stop cooperating with the United States in drug enforcement if it is proved that the DEA was directly involved in the abduction. The Guadalajara gynecologist, abducted from his office and flown to the United States, awaits trial in Los Angeles for alleged involvement in the 1985 torture and murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena. Seven other Mexicans were being sought in the kidnapping case, government spokesman Fernando Arias said late Friday. Reading from a prepared statement, Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said that the people who carried out the kidnapping were armed and told the doctor they were Mexican federal police. When the doctor arrived in El Paso, Texas, ``10 people surrounded the plane, showed their Drug Enforcement Administration credentials, and took Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain off the plane,'' the attorney general said. ``The kidnapping of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain was organized by Antonio Garate Bustamante, a self-styled DEA agent or informer who has been sought by Mexican authorities since 1985,'' Alvarez del Castillo said. He did not provide details of any earlier charges. He said a warrant has been issued for the arrest of Garate Bustamante and six others. The Los Angeles Times today quoted Garate Bustamante as saying he arranged the abduction with the approval of two DEA agents. The kidnapping was carried out by 10 Mexicans, including Mexican federal policemen, who were promised a total of $100,000 to deliver Alvarez to U.S. authorities, the Los Angeles Times quoted Bustamante as saying. It identified him as a former Mexican policeman. Garate Bustamante, who said he is paid $4,000 a month by the DEA, lives in a fortified apartment in the Los Angeles area and keeps automatic weapons at the ready, the Times reported. The DEA has denied published reports it paid bounty hunters to capture the Mexican doctor and bring him to the United States, but today Times' report quotes two unidentified DEA officials as saying Garate Bustamante helped arrange the abduction. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said last week that DEA agents were not involved in Alvarez Machain's capture in Mexico. On Friday, leading law-enforcement officers from 33 nations meeting in Mexico City announced an agreement to exchange more information and increase cooperation in the worldwide fight against the drug trade. Speaking at the end of the three-day conference, acting DEA administrator Terrence Burke said, ``We have agreed that we need to improve on sharing more information, so we know what we are facing in terms of production.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Agree to Brief Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces agreed to a 21-hour cease-fire today to allow residents of the embattled hinterland to check on their property. Police said the truce went into effect at 9 a.m. in the eastern flank of the Kesrouan province northeast of Beirut. The rival forces have been battling for three months for control of the Christian heartland. The truce, mediated by Maronite Catholic priest Bulos Naaman, was enforced mainly to allow the displaced population of the mountain villages of Daraya and Kleiat to check their homes and property. Kleiat is controlled by Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces, a right-wing coalition of Christian militias. Troops of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun control Daraya. The cease-fire also will allow civilians trapped in the two mountain resorts to leave, according to a police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations. That indicated more fighting was expected on the Kesrouan front between Aoun's loyalists, estimated at 19,000, and Geagea's 6,000 irregulars. Elsewhere in the 310-square-mile enclave, the rival forces skirmished with automatic rifles, police said. No casualties were reported today. Police say the showdown for mastery of the enclave has killed 916 and wounded 2,441 since Jan. 30. The power struggle, the worst inter-Christian confrontation of the 15-year-old civil war, has inflicted damage estimated at $1 billion and forced 400,000 people to flee from the enclave, which housed about 1 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Vargas Llosa Breaks Long Silence, Criticizes Fujimori
DOC.TEXT: Mario Vargas Llosa says he'll oversee radical economic reforms if elected president, and the first-time candidate accused his opponent of not having enough political experience to be Peru's leader. The nationally televised speech Friday was the first by the rightist candidate since he was nearly beaten by centrist contender Alberto Fujimori in the first round of presidential elections April 8. Vargas Llosa, an internationally known novelist, said his poor showing in the first round was ``a good lesson, and I hope to profit from it.'' He won 32 percent of the vote, but Fujimori, a virtual unknown whose popularity surged in the final weeks before the election, took 30 percent. Recent polls predicted Vargas Llosa, who has never held a political office, would lose the runoff to Fujimori by 51 percent to 38 percent. In the speech, Vargas Llosa said his policies ``were not understood by many'' Peruvians. He promised to explain them more clearly in the weeks leading up to a runoff election, likely to take place June 3. The novelist's economic ``shock'' plan calls for privatization of Peru's huge state enterprises, elimination of agricultural and industrial subsidies, and drastic cuts in import and export tariffs. In his speech he criticized Fujimori _ an agricultural engineer who has never held political office _ for his inexperience and his lack of a political platform. Fujimori is ``not in a condition to confront the grave threat President (Alan) Garcia will leave as the inheritance of the next government,'' Vargas Llosa said. ``The present situation is a time bomb set to explode at the beginning of the next term.'' Fujimori failed to produce a political platform 10 days ago, as promised. The next president will face a huge challenge in governing Peru, which suffers from hyperinflation and a rapidly shrinking economy. The Maoist Shining Path rebels are waging war with the government and control much of Peru's mountains and jungles. More than 18,000 people have died in the 10 years since the Shining Path took up arms, the government says.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Astronauts Say There Was No Time For Talk During Hubble Deploy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Informatively, PM-Space Shuttle, a0467, will be led by 10:15 a.m. EDT to UPDATE with detail from briefing on status of Hubble and incorporate some of following material.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1
With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: The Discovery astronauts breathed ``a little sigh of relief'' after they finished the tricky task of putting the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit. During a news conference this morning from space, the five crew members said there was little time for talk or celebration Wednesday when the telescope was released from the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm. ``You have to realize that had we just spent a pretty tense time with a $1.5 billion telescope and we have a couple billion-dollar orbiter and we just separated the two and we're still within inches of each other,'' Discovery Commander Loren Shriver said. ``Saying something was the last thing on my mind.'' Mission specialist Steve Hawley, who gently guided the robot arm as it hoisted the Hubble out of the cargo bay, said he didn't really think about the accomplishment until after it was all over. ``Only later in the day when we got a chance to take a breath and maybe give out a little sigh of relief and think, `Gee, we actually got it done.' And at that moment I think we were all very pleased and satisfied to be part of the team that did this,'' he said. Hawley added that there was really only one tense moment during the telescope's deployment: ``Just the part from beginning to the end.'' The crew members took time out today to answer questions radioed to them from reporters at the Johnson Space Center in Houston and Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. They were spending most of the day stowing their gear and experiments and testing the shuttle's control systems in preparation for Sunday's landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan were prepared to perform an emergency space walk Wednesday if there had been trouble deploying the telescope. They had trained for such a procedure for years, but one wasn't necessary. ``Either one of us was trained and ready to work,'' Sullivan said. Both astronauts already have walked in space on previous missions, but McCandless admitted to being ``a little disappointed not to have an EVA,'' for extra-vehicular activity, or spacewalk. The astronauts agreed that the mission was a special one since Hubble will enable astronomers to search the heavens for new worlds and clues to creation itself. ``Almost everybody seems to be familiar with what the telescope is and what it was designed to do,'' Shriver said. ``It's hard to go somewhere and find someone who has never heard of the Hubble Space Telescope,'' added pilot Charles Bolden. ``It makes little kids' eyes light up. It makes little kids want to learn how to add and subtract and study science. ``And that's extremely gratifying to know that you're part of a mission that seems to have excited the nation as well as the world about something.''

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl Pilot Receives Bone Marrow Transplant
With PM-Chernobyl-Aid, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The life-giving...', to CORRECT hometown of donor to Besancon sted Paris.
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet pilot suffering radiation poisoning from his efforts to stem the Chernobyl nuclear disaster was stable early today after undergoing a potentially life-saving bone-marrow transplant. Anatoly Grishchenko, 53, who has been hailed as a hero in the Soviet Union for his work to put a cement cap on the Chernobyl reactor, suffers from a pre-leukemia condition. The life-giving marrow, from a donor in Besancon, France, was carried in an ice cooler and rushed to Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center after arriving at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport on a commercial flight at 5 p.m. Friday. Bone marrow can lose its effectiveness after 24 hours. The relatively simple transplant began at 6:53 p.m. and ended at 2:40 a.m., center spokeswoman Susan Edmonds said. ``He is stable. He handled the transfusion very well and there are no problems,'' she said. ``The next step is to see if the marrow will grow.'' Doctors should know in about three weeks whether the new marrow will save Grishchenko's life, Edmonds said. The procedure follows two weeks of treatment for Grishchenko at the cancer center, including radiation therapy. Edmonds said starting the procedure was as simple as hanging the bag of about one quart of marrow and connecting it to a catheter leading to Grishchenko's heart. She said a sterile environment was being maintained in his hospital room, where he would be expected to stay the next 35 to 40 days. The marrow, donated by a 42-year-old woman, arrived one day after the fourth anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the Ukraine. Grishchenko was honored as a hero for making five flights over Chernobyl in the four days following an explosion and fire at the reactor on April 26, 1986. He flew through the hot, intensely radioactive gases spewing from the plant to survey the damage and to dump tons of sand and wet concrete onto the wreckage. According to official figures, 31 people were killed. Unofficial reports said at least 250 died. The blast scattered radioactive cesium, strontium and plutonium isotopes across much of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia and sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world. In September 1988, Grishchenko was found to have the medical condition, typified by low counts of blood platelets needed for clotting and of white blood cells to fight infection and disease. Grishchenko is the first Chernobyl victim to receive medical care in the United States. He has up to a 75 percent chance of survival without a recurrence of the condition for five years, said Edmonds. The transplant was arranged by Cap Parlier, light helicopter testing and evaluation director for McDonnell Douglas Corp., who said he had spoken to Grishchenko a few times by telephone since the Soviet civilian helicopter test pilot arrived at Hutchinson on April 11. The transfusion culminated a drama that began shortly after daybreak Friday at the Jean-Minjoz hospital in Besancon in east-central France. Dr. Patricia Stewart of the Hutchinson center arrived by helicopter at the French hospital's transfusion center and watched two French doctors extract nearly a quart of marrow from the donor, a woman who wanted anonymity, in a two-hour procedure similar to drawing blood. After the liquid was filtered and packaged for travel, Stewart and the container were rushed by helicopter to Geneva for a commercial jet flight to Seattle via London. In Seattle, Stewart was met at the door of Fred Hutchinson Center by Grishchenko's wife, Galina. The French donor was located in a search of bone marrow registries in the United States, France and seven other countries. Her marrow was found to be a near perfect match. Grishchenko, who has two sons and a granddaughter, was issued lead-lined clothing and the copters were equipped with extra lead shielding. He was treated soon after the Chernobyl flights for radiation sickness.

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope Resumes Operations; Shuttle Crew Prepares for Landing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with quote from news conference, telescope's instruments still on hold, other detail from briefing; and to CORRECT spelling of Olivier sted Oliver in 6-7th grafs pvs. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `The telescope problems...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Hubble Space Telescope was awakened from its self-induced sleep today but it was still without the use of its high-speed antennas, and its science instruments were on hold, unable to begin any observations. ``We are out of the `safe-mode' right now,'' said Steve Terry, a supervisor of the engineers controlling the telescope. He said the telescope was running on a ``normal control-all mode,'' where its own computers and sensors guide where it is pointing. Discovery's astronauts, meanwhile, packed their gear for a return to Earth Sunday, made some last-minute observations of Earth and talked with ground-based reporters about their flight. Pilot Charles Bolden said he was especially upbeat about the widespread public awareness of the telescope, which is expected eventually to look back 14 billion light years _ nearly to the birth of the universe. ``It's hard to go somewhere and find someone who has never heard of the Hubble Space Telescope,'' said Bolden. ``It makes little kids' eyes light up. It makes little kids want to learn how to add and subtract and study science.'' The telescope's big eye has remained open, but Hubble had been in a ``safe mode'' with all motion stopped because of earlier problems in linking the high-speed dish antennas with a relay satellite. The antennas are the primary links for relaying scientific data to the ground. Terry said that even in the safe mode, one of the tape recorders in the telescope reads telemetry signals from all its systems and that these would be played to Earth and analyzed when the antennas are working properly. ``We expect to use that data to investigate what happened,'' he said. Engineers are able to send commands to the telescope via its secondary antennas but the communications system is not useful for scientific data, which must be transmitted at a high rate of speed. ``We're putting the scientific instruments in a hold mode, in effect a standby mode,'' he said. Shortly after 6 a.m. EDT, controllers at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., completed a series of commands that took the telescope out of its safe mode and then began to run a 12-hour computer program to monitor Hubble's health. It will take another day before the $1.5 billion telescope is operating the way it was supposed to at this point in the startup process, said Hubble deputy project manager Jean Olivier. ``We're backing up to a very deliberate and slow and careful approach to these problems,'' Olivier said Friday. ``This is not the time to do anything dumb.'' The telescope problems have put the flight center several days behind, but the five astronauts who deployed it earlier this week were sticking to their schedule. Landing is scheduled for 9:48 a.m. EDT Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., but flight controllers were keeping a close watch on the weather. Winds were predicted to be about 20 mph with gusts up to 29 mph. Mission rules dictate that headwinds cannot exceed 29 mph at touchdown. The shuttle carries enough supplies to stay in orbit three days beyond Sunday if necessary, NASA said. Mission Control awakened the crew members at about 1:30 a.m. EDT today by playing the song, ``Cosmos.'' ``Thanks for the wake-up music, it's pretty appropriate for today,'' said Commander Loren Shriver. ``The song was selected in honor of Hubble Space Telescope, which is now open for business,'' said Mission Control commentator James Hartsfield. The astronauts were to finish up their experiments and photography today and pack for the trip home. They also planned to hold a news conference from space with reporters at the Johnson Space Center. Shriver and pilot Charles Bolden were to run through a series of tests to make certain the shuttle's computers and control jets were ready for return to Earth. The crew deployed Hubble on Wednesday but they had stayed close to the telescope in case there was trouble opening the aperture door. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan were prepared to perform a space walk today to crank it open in orbit 380 miles above Earth. But that proved unnecessary when the door was opened Friday morning, exposing the telescope's finely polished 94.5-inch eye to starlight for the first time. Two of Hubble's four position-stabilizing gyroscopes stopped working when the door opened, but engineers later got them back on line. The gyroscopes were knocked out by the motion and that, too, kept the telescope in the safe mode, said Dave Drachlis, director of orbital verifications at Goddard. A colleague, Steve Terry, said Hubble's systems were set at conservative limits for the first operations and that caused many malfunctions. There also were two communications outages totaling several hours. Hubble is designed with safe modes so it can be ``the master of its own destiny'' in case contact with an orbiting communications system is lost for extended periods, Terry said. NASA had planned to release its first test image from the telescope on Tuesday, showing an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. But Terry said that would be delayed because of the antenna problems. Scientific data will follow in a month or two. The telescope, named for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, will enable astronomers over its 15-year working lifetime to look back 14 billion years and possibly determine the age of the universe. The universe is believed to have been created about 15 billion years ago in a cosmic explosion. Hubble provided the basis for the big-bang theory of creation. He discovered during the 1920s that the universe is expanding and that the farther the galaxy is from Earth, the faster it is moving away.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman and His Father Killed in Natal
DOC.TEXT: A black police constable and his father were killed by gunmen, police reported today, and a police general said the nation's crime rate has reached alarming proportions. Police said five gunmen broke into the house of 24-year-old Constable J.F. Zuma in Mpumalanga outside Durban on Friday night, demanded ammunition, then shot him twice in the chest. Police said Zuma's father, in another room, heard the attack and tried to flee from the house but was also shot and killed. The constable's wife and young children escaped, and the gunmen took a shotgun and two pistols when they left, police said in their daily unrest report. Police also reported several incidents of arson and the stoning of trains and police vehicles in black townships over a wide area of the country during the 24 hours from Friday to this morning. Officers used used shotguns, rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse crowds in black townships. There were several injuries and arrests, but no deaths reported in the incidents. Gen. Jaap Joubert, head of the police Criminal Investigations Division, told a seminar in Natal province that crime had reached alarming proportions with almost 1.5 million serious crimes committed last year. He said there were 4,037 a day and 186 every hour, with fewer than 8,000 detectives to deal with them. On an average day in South Africa, Joubert said, there were 32 murders, 56 rapes, 199 robberies, 160 cases of car theft and more than 500 cases of house-breaking. The national police force is also experiencing a drain of officers, with an average 22 a day resigning during the first three months of this year. The government recently announced a pay raise for police and ordered that policemen can no longer belong to any political party or movement. Meanwhile, about 3,000 people gathered in Atteridgeville township outside Pretoria today for the funeral of Pan-Africanist Congress leader Jeff Masemola. Masemola, who died in a car crash two weeks ago, was freed in October from a life prison term after serving 27 years for sabotage. Police set up roadblocks at entrances to the township, turning away some vehicles and questioning people headed to the funeral. Pan-Africanist Congress leaders said more mourners would have come if not for the police action. The Pan-Africanist Congress broke away from the African National Congress in the 1950s and disagrees with the ANC's policies of negotiating with the white government and recognizing white ownership of land. Cunningham Noxukwana, general secretary of a PAC-affiliated union organization, spoke at the funeral, criticizing the ANC's plans to hold talks next week with President F.W. de Klerk. ``Our choice is to fight on,'' said Noxukwana. ``A sellout is very thick in the air.''

DOC.HEAD: Families of Kidnapping Victims March in Rome
DOC.TEXT: Led by the father of an 8-year-old girl who was held by kidnappers for 78 days, about 2,000 people on Saturday marched through Rome demanding that the government step up its battle against abduction. The marchers included relatives of the five people still in the hands of kidnappers. ``We want to show we are united,'' said Imerio Tacchella, a leading sportswear manufacturer whose daughter, Patrizia, was freed by police April 17. The marchers, who met with Interior Minister Antonio Gava, carried signs reading ``So That Patrizia May Be The Last.'' Three people were arrested for her kidnapping, and police are investigating evidence they were involved in previous abductions of young people. The marchers also included 20-year-old Cesare Casella, who was held as a hostage for more than two years in the mountains of southern Calabria. ``So many people did things for me, this is the least I can do today,'' Casella said.

DOC.HEAD: 2,000 POWs Freed From Prisons Under Amnesty
DOC.TEXT: Uganda has freed more than 2,000 former guerrillas from prisons after they pledged not to resume fighting government forces, the government said Saturday. Their release raises to 5,000 the number of former rebels released from detention in the past 18 months, Interior Minister Ibrahim Mukiibi said. The latest prisoners to be set free were captured by government troops in the eastern border areas three years ago. They were fighting for separate guerrilla armies under former defense minister Peter Otai and former prime minister Otema Allimadi. The rebels seek the overthrow of President Yoweri Museveni, who seized power in a 1986 coup. About 100 other rebel prisoners have been kept in detention and will face charges they committed war crimes, Mukiibi said.

DOC.HEAD: How the Fortune 500 Became Environmentalists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing. Also moved in advance April 27 as b0652.
DOC.TEXT: Some of it is hype, some of it is genuine commitment and some is begrudging acceptance of reality. Whatever, American corporations are becoming environmentalists, or at least environmentally conscious. This year's crop of glossy annual reports sent by corporations to stockholders every spring is green with environmentalism. Firms are eager to tell about their good citizenship on planet Earth. Texaco brags that mussels taken from its offshore oil rigs are served in the finest California restaurants. Dow Chemical touts the environmental awards it has won. Carolina Power & Light tells how conservation has saved 1.75 million kilowatts. Even the tiny Central Vermont Public Service Corp. wants stockholders to know that it has invested in a power generating plant that burns waste wood. Not so long ago, business was hostile to environmentalism. It saw the movement as an advocate of restrictions that would impede operations, require big, non-revenue generating outlays, undermine competitiveness. Environmentalists were looked on in corporate boardrooms as ``pointy headed liberals that really didn't know business,'' says Bruce Smart, former Commerce Department official in the Reagan Administration. ``We had a lot of name-calling, a lot of rhetoric on both sides,'' says Alexander Trowbridge, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers and former oil executive. But as it turned out, he says, ``environmental improvement has been a corollary to economic growth.'' Still, there's some grumbling. Marco, Inc., in the business of producing coal and natural gas and transporting natural gas, complains in its annual report, ``Each of our business segments has the potential to be impacted adversely by the environment issues being debated both in Washington, D.C. and in states throughout the country ...'' ``We believe that many of these issues are being addressed politically rather than with a more deliberate approach based on a sound, rational review of scientific data.'' And Inland Steel Industries, in its annual report, says a Democratic clean air bill in the Senate would have imposed standards ``unscientific and unattainable for steel and other affected industries.'' But they are exceptions. Most companies which make a potentially polluting product or use a polluting process, have become environmentally prideful. ``Mussels are especially sensitive to pollutants, yet they thrive on the legs of Texaco's Habitat platform off the coast of California,'' says Texaco's annual report. ``When a marine firm discovered that the water around the platform exceeds stronger state water quality requirements for growing mussels, it arranged with Texaco to gather the mussels from the platform and sell them to gourmet restaurants from Los Angeles to San Francisco,'' Texaco says. Phelps Dodge Corp., which produces one billion tons of copper a year, tells of plans to cover a 60-year-old pile of tailings with a golf course. ``Simply complying with environmental regulations is not enough,'' the company says. ``Papermaking is a water-intensive process. It takes thousands of gallons to make a ton of coated paperboard,'' says the Mead Corp. So how much extra water will be pumped from the river for use in Mead's new 1,000-ton-a-day coated board expansion in Alabama? ``None, thanks to the fact that water once used only for cooling will be recycled and used in the manufacturing process.'' Dow Chemical tells one of its secrets: ``Dow gives plant managers a direct incentive to reduce waste by charging each plant for all waste management costs.'' Dow brags it has reduced its plants' air emissions by 85 percent since 1974 and seeks to cut them another 50 percent in five years. ``Nearly 75 million pounds of polyethylene milk bottles became drain pipes, lumber replacements and recycling containers in 1989.,'' says Dow. ``Nearly all the scrap from Dow's plastic foam production is recycled or sold rather than being disposed of in landfills.'' McDonald's Corp., which had been taking a public relations beating because of all that greasy waste paper and polystyrene it generates, fills its annual report with conservation messages. Inside, McDonald's reprints a letter received from Dan Getty, 11: ``If we stop wasting resources, our land will be clean. If we don't stop, we won't have anything left.'' Perhaps in response, McDonald's came up with a McSolution: ``McRecycle,'' a $100 million plan to buy high chairs, wastebaskets, insulation from recycled materials and to use paper bags made from recycled newspapers. Its first step was to ballyhoo the program in full-page newspaper ads.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has covered the news in Washington for 22 years.

DOC.HEAD: European Leaders in Summit on Political Union, German Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more on three-stage process for bringing East Germany into the EC. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: European Community leaders today opened talks to consider French and German appeals for faster movement toward a political merger of their 12 nations. French President Francois Mitterrand, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl joined a stream of prime ministers and their aides at the medieval Dublin Castle on an overcast day in Dublin, the Irish capital. The Western European nations, who already plan to form a single open market by the end of 1992, are now beginning to discuss ways of bringing their political systems into closer alignment. Reacting to the profound political changes in Eastern Europe, Mitterrand and Kohl are urging faster movement toward a political union. Mrs. Thatcher was expected to oppose their calls for a political union of the Economic Community trading bloc by 1993. EC officials were also expected to discuss plans for reunification of the two Germanys, the original reason for today's meeting before the French and German appeals for political unity surfaced. Also on the agenda is a plan to forge closer relations with the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and draw them closer to the West. Before discussing political union, the leaders endorsed a three-stage plan for bringing East Germany into the European Community. The agreement would benefit East Germany's backward economy by bringing it into a trade bloc of 320 million people. West Germany is already an influential EC member. The first stage calls for an interim adjustment period starting July 2, when the two Germanys merge their currencies. The second stage begins with formal unification of the two Germanys, which is planed for late next year. From then on community laws will apply to what is now East German territory. But it will be allowed certain exemptions, for example on rules about state subsidies and environmental regulations. In the final stage, for which no deadline has been set, all European Community rules would apply. Security was tight in the city's center for the gathering. Authorities banned aircraft from flying over the 13th-century castle and deployed the Rangers, an elite anti-terrorist unit. Mrs. Thatcher is a prime target of the Irish Republican Army, which tried to assassinate her with a bomb in 1984. The IRA is fighting to rid Northern Ireland of British rule and unite the province with the Irish Republic. The officials' talks could be heated at the one-day summit. ``We hear a great deal about political union,'' a British government spokesman said on condition of anonymity today. But he told reporters Mrs. Thatcher ``will try to get behind the words and get their meaning.'' Mrs. Thatcher has resisted radical plans for the economic and monetary unity. Analysts say a political merger of the EC countries probably would include a common foreign and security policy. Some predict the EC countries eventually will become a kind of United States of Europe but still maintain their distinct languages and cultures. Some leaders in the trading bloc like the Mitterrand-Kohl proposal. Ireland's prime minister, Charles Haughey, told reporters Friday, ``Look at the speed of change in Europe in the last few months. Are we to be stranded on the beach of inactivity?'' ``I am keen on moving to political union, and I want to take the summit as far forward as it can,'' he said. Haughey said Mrs. Thatcher was not alone in her concerns, however. ``Not just the British but other member states have, perhaps, reservations, or at least questions that they want to ask,'' he told RTE, the Irish state television. The community already is pressing to remove by late 1992 the many barriers preventing the free flow of money, goods, services and people among the countries. Moreover, it has begun a drive for an economic and monetary union, which would lead to a single currency and system of central banks. A special conference will open in December to change the EC's founding treaty to permit the creation of new institutions. The European Community members are Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilians Split Over Economic `Shock' Plan
DOC.TEXT: Business and organized labor say Brazil's economic ``shock plan'' is driving the nation toward recession, but the poor think President Fernando Collor de Mello has the right idea. ``I hadn't eaten meat in so long, I'd forgotten what it tasted like,'' said Derly Rosa Perreira dos Santos, 25, who works as a maid and lives in a shantytown of Rio's poor North Zone. ``Now I can afford it twice a week.'' Record annualized inflation of 4,854 percent has fallen dramatically since Collor announced his ``New Brazil'' plan March 16, one day after taking office as the country's first democratically elected president in 29 years. It put an 18-month freeze on savings deposits of more than $1,200 and limited withdrawals from money market funds to $600 or 20 percent of the value, whichever was greater. About $115 billion was frozen, 80 percent of all bank deposits in Latin America's largest economy. Collor also cut spending, imposed new taxes and promised to sell many of the 188 state-owned companies to eliminate the $31 billion federal budget deficit. There is disagreement over the inflation rate for April _ the government says zero and several independent institutions estimate 25 percent _ but all agree the threat of hyperinflation is gone. ``Food and medicine are cheaper and the bus fare has stopped rising every week,'' said Mrs. dos Santos, who has two children and rides the bus to work. ``I've even been able to save a little money the past month.'' Spending on cheap housewares and appliances has surged. ``Our stores in poor areas are selling about 10 to 15 percent more,'' said Fernando Martinho of the TeleRio chain of appliance stores. ``Our outlets in middle class and wealthy areas report stagnant sales, or even a small drop.'' Mrs. dos Santos said that, if inflation remained low, she hoped to buy a mattress for her children, who sleep on blankets on the floor of the family's concrete hut. Poor Brazilians have little sympathy for wealthy people with frozen bank accounts, now referred to in the press as ``nouveau poor.'' More than half the workers in Brazil earn $150 a month or less, while the richest 10 percent of the country's 150 million people live in luxury. Nilda Modena da Silva praised Collor for freezing the accounts and said: ``While I had no money to buy bread, the rich threw food in the trash.'' She is not happy about zero inflation, however, because that means pay will not go up, and ``how can he (Collor) freeze a mother's salary?'' Mrs. da Silva works as a janitor and supports her two children on the minimum wage of about $75 a month. Opinion about the economic plan seems evenly divided in the middle class, but Collor gets low marks from the rich. A survey by the respected firm Research International found a sense among the upper 10 percent of reduced social standing, ``loss and humiliation.'' Antonio Ermirio de Moraes, president of the Votorantin group, Brazil's biggest private company, said on a television talk show he considered emigrating after having $500 million caught in the freeze. Many businessmen feel betrayed because they supported Collor against socialist Luis Inacio Lula da Silva in the December election. They accuse the president of reneging on promises of free-market reform. ``We are living in an economic dictatorship,'' said business consultant Alexandre Barros. ``Never in the history of this country has there been so little economic freedom. ``The name of the game is no longer to be an effcient entrepeneur, but to be a political operator who can pressure the government into releasing your money. There are no market criteria at all.'' Organized labor agrees with management in this case. Official figures say unemployment has grown from 3.5 percent to more than 9 percent since March 15. The huge, foreign-owned auto plants that ring Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, have put 80 percent of their employees on furlough and about 300,000 construction workers have been laid off. ``This plan will lead to a depression far worse than the hyperinflationary spiral which it was supposedly going to save us from,'' said Jose Olivio Miranda of the Central Workers Union, the largest labor federation, which represents about 12 million workers. Layoffs have led thousands of people who migrated to the industrialized south to return home. In mid-April, buses from Sao Paulo to the poor northeast carried 1,700 passengers a day, twice the usual number. Gustavo Franco, an economist at Rio's Pontifical Catholic University, said a downturn was necessary to curb inflation. ``Once the cost of living comes down, it is relatively simple to restart growth,'' he said. ``We have a very strong economy with a solid industrial base.'' Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira, a former finance minister, said: ``The government has taken necessary steps to permanently bring down inflation. First we need to stabilize the economy, then the government should implement ... policies to help the poor.'' Herbert de Souza, director of the Brazilian Institute of Social and Economic Analysis, is less sanguine. ``With the poverty we've got, Brazil can't take a deep recession,'' he said. ``The first impact of the plan may have helped the poor, but that is temporary and will be erased with a recession. The measures are now popular because people are looking at the immediate impact and not consequences.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Free in the Spring, 1st Add, a0498,0878
DOC.HEAD: HAVANA: normal size.''
DOC.TEXT: Enter Maria, a doctor in Havana, who was a 28-year-old widow in 1985. A cousin of Mustelier, who lived in Miami, was Maria's close friend. The cousin asked her to write Mustelier, because no one else did, and to mail him reading material and money for incidentals. She agreed, never thinking the relationship would develop. ``He never thought about love,'' she said. ``He had had two marriages that did not work out. He had this idea of dedication to the fatherland, and he did not think about romance. ``I would write every week. He would say he looked at the world through my eyes. I would tell him how things were on the street, about fashion, what I saw on TV. ``The affection that developed between us was first a great and powerful friendship, and later a love developed. ... I didn't think he would fall in love with me through letters and, of course, when he told me, I was in shock.'' For much of their correspondence, he had never even seen her photograph. Mustelier, who is white, did not know she was black, Maria said. Racial issues intrude on personal relationships in Cuba, although not nearly so much as in the United States.
