She tried twice to visit him in the prison at Santiago, 600 miles from Havana, but was turned away because she was not a close relative. In the spring of 1987, Mustelier and some other inmates were moved to a prison in the capital. She will never forget the day they met: June 12, 1987. Three months later, they were married in a two-hour prison ceremony, with about 20 people in attendance. The wedding banquet was ice cream, soda and snacks. After that, she could see him every 21 days. Each time, she said, ``Since early morning my heart was pounding, because I knew I was going to see him.'' Her husband knew she had no time to eat before the visits, so he sometimes saved his meager lunch for her. ``He would bring me his lunch, his piece of chicken, his piece of meat,'' she said. On one visit, two years ago, the male guards strip-searched Maria and sexually abused her. Mustelier was enraged and refused to eat for 19 days. In addition to the consequences of hunger strikes, Mustelier said he suffers from the results of cruel treatment. Castro has claimed there never has been an instance of torture in more than 31 years of the Cuban revolution, but here are some of Mustelier's complaints: _For two years, he was held in a white cell with nothing but a 500-watt electric bulb. The constant glare made him nearsighted, and the condition is becoming progressively worse. _Loud horns blown by guards to keep him from sleeping cost him 40 percent of his hearing. _His arms and legs bear the scars of bayonet attacks by guards, and his jaw was broken once. Mustelier's legs still are inflamed from the last hunger strike. He once was handcuffed to two other inmates and placed in a cell six feet high, six long and three wide. If two of them lay side-by-side, the third had to lie on top because of the handcuffs. After 24 hours, Mustelier managed to remove the handcuffs. The guards threatened to put them back on, but he said: ``For you to put the chains back on, you'll have to kill us.'' An officer sided with the inmates and, although the three were kept in the cell several more days, they were not handcuffed. Despite his prison ordeal, Mustelier looks surprisingly healthy, perhaps younger than his 47 years. Seven weeks after ending his last hunger strike, he has gained 40 pounds and worries about becoming fat. If he is embittered, he doesn't show it. Laughter often punctuates his stories of life in prison, even his description of being overrun by roaches and mosquitos. ``We used to say they were the big allies of our jailers,'' he said. Did he ever count the days during his 105-day hunger strike? ``No, because after counting them, you worry and this weighs on you,'' he said, and laughed again. Yoga and an hour of physical exercise every day helped Mustelier endure the long confinement. Like Maria, he found comfort in religion. In his last hunger strike, his rosary was always with him. He showed a visitor a book of religious verses he had since 1988. Despite daily use, it was nearly in mint condition. He opened the book with great care, not touching the pages beyond the margins. ``Every verse filled me with peace and tranquillity,'' he said. Mustelier wrote love poems to Maria, whom he calls Caruca, and gave her a collection of them in September for their second wedding anniversary. One, translated from the Spanish, reads: ``Your appearance produces not only happiness, but joy. Happiness is a momentary state of emotion, joy is a state of satisfaction and deep feeling. With that, I will look upon you as a gift of spring.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Again Rejects Lithuania Talks; Deputies Resign From Supreme Soviet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev spokesman praising French-German compromise proposal. Pickup 11th pvs, `Lithuania wants...'
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin again rebuffed Lithuania's attempts to open formal talks on the republic's independence drive, and Lithuania's deputies in the Supreme Soviet legislature resigned, according to news reports. Also, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's spokesman today praised a French-West German proposal to defuse tensions over Lithuania, raising the possibility it could serve as a basis for compromise between the Baltic republic and the Kremlin. Lithuania's Vilnius Radio, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London on Friday night, quoted Bronius Kuzmickas, the deputy chairman of Lithuania's Supreme Council legislature, as saying that a parliamentary delegation had met with some high-ranking officials in Moscow. But the officials reiterated Gorbachev's position that no talks with the government would take place unless Lithuania halts its drive for independence, the radio said. In Moscow today, the national Supreme Soviet heard a formal resignation by Lithuanian deputies and a declaration by Estonian deputies that they would suspend their membership until Moscow began formal talks with their republic on independence, Soviet television reported. Estonian deputies hold 13 places in the 542-member Supreme Soviet. Lithuanian deputies, who have attended only as observers since their republic declared independence on March 11, held 15 places. The Soviet Union annexed Lithuania, Estonia, and Latvia in 1940. The parliament of Estonia has voted to become independent at an unspecified later date, and Latvia is scheduled to vote on the issue next week. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said her government still hopes to begin talks without backing off independence decisions, but it is considering a proposed temporary freeze on secessionist actions as the maximum concession it might offer Moscow. ``This is a compromise which should be viewed as the maximum. This is the limit,'' she told a Friday night news conference, according to the Soviet news agency Tass. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis has said the republic's legislature, the Supreme Council, will consider the freeze proposal, which came from the leaders of France and Germany. The legislature is scheduled to reconvene Wednesday. Gorbachev's spokesman, Arkady Maslennikov, called the proposal for Lithuania to temporarily suspend its secessionist actions a ``constructive signal'' reflecting growing sentiment in Lithuania and abroad that the republic must ``return to the road of reason.'' Lithuania wants an immediate dialogue, Landsbergis said Friday, and ``a termination of the Soviet economic blockade against Lithuania would be beneficial to the atmosphere of this dialogue.'' The Kremlin has imposed a blockade on gas, oil and other supplies to Lithuania as part of the effort to force the republic to stop its independence movement. Tass reported today that coal had been added to the embargo list. Much of the coal Lithuania consumes is imported from Poland, and the republic owes about $1.6 million for coal supplies, so they have been stopped, the news agency said. Vilnius Radio reported that medicines including antibiotics were in short supply, but that the situation was not believed to be critical. On Friday in Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Mrs. Prunskiene had been granted a U.S. visa for unofficial, business travel. He said she was expected to visit sometime next week. The United States and other Western countries have refused to impose sanctions on the Soviet Union for its efforts to stop Lithuania's independence drive. On Thursday, 52-year-old Stanislovas Jamaitis died of burns suffered when he doused his clothes with gasoline and set himself ablaze in front of the Bolshoi Theater in central Moscow to protest the Kremlin pressure. Jamaitis left suicide notes to his wife, Stasala, and to Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. The Supreme Council released the texts on Friday, said spokeswoman Rita Radzavicius. She translated them from Lithuanian to Russian and read them by telephone. Tass also reported the existence of the note to Jamaitis' wife, saying it ``spoke of an impossible family life and a desire to commit suicide.'' The version released by Lithuanian authorities apologized for ``something bad'' in his marriage, but stressed political motives. ``I went to Moscow to set myself on fire,'' he said in both notes. ``The occupiers have cut off energy supplies and people are being thrown out of work,'' Jamaitis wrote. He would kill himself to ``let Gorbachev know that Lithuanians will not live in a Lithuania that is not independent,'' said the note read by the spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents of Abortion to Rally at Washington Monument
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops 6 grafs with early crowds, color; picks up 3rd pvs, The event ...; event begins 2 p.m.; deletes pvs first reference to Cardinal O'Connor. ^By WILLIAM M. WELCH
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of abortion opponents gathered in Washington today trying to impress the nation with their strength at a ``Rally for Life'' on the grassy mall by the Washington Monument. President Bush was addressing the group by a remote telephone hookup. Vice President Dan Quayle was appearing in person along with Catholic cardinals, country and gospel singers, and anti-abortion leaders. Sponsors declined to predict the size of the crowd but hoped to rival the police estimate of 300,000 people who attended a rally by supporters of abortion rights a year ago. The first the more than 2,000 bus loads of people that sponsors expected began arriving Friday evening. Rally-goers walked Washington streets and crowded the city's Metro subway system as they began assembling this morning. A small group of counter-protesters carried ``Keep Abortion Legal'' signs, drawing honks from sympathetic drivers passing by and exchanging waves with abortion opponents. Catholic Cardinal James Hickey conducted a Mass for the abortion protesters on the eve of the rally, and New York Cardinal John O'Connor, head of the church's pro-life committee, planned a Mass at the conclusion. The event was aimed at trying to reverse the impression that anti-abortion forces have been in political decline. It comes at a time when their side has sustained a series of losses in elections and in state capitals. ``At least part of the motive is to try to reverse what we feel is a misperception about the strength of the Right to Life movement _ and also, to give some politicians who might be wavering a little bit of backbone,'' said Gary L. Bauer, president of the Family Research Council and a White House aide in the Reagan administration. ``We hope to impress the Congress. We hope to impress the nation,'' said Dr. J.C. Willke, president of the National Right to Life Committee, the lobbying group sponsoring the rally. Since the Supreme Court's so-called Webster decision last summer, in which states were given more leeway to restrict abortions, candidates who support legal abortions have won elections for governor of Virginia and New Jersey and lieutenant governor of Virginia. And, they have succeeded in blocking abortion restrictions in many state legislatures. In addition, a number of candidates for office this year have switched positions to support abortion rights. And despite a strongly anti-abortion plank in the Republican Party's platform, party officials have made clear they do not want the issue to be a litmus test for the party's candidates or supporters. ``They have a public perception problem,'' Eddie Mahe, a political consultant to Republican candidates on both sides of the issue, said of the anti-abortion forces. ``There is clearly the perception the movement is on the pro-choice side.'' Abortion opponents acknowledge they have been frustrated by the other side's success in framing public debate on the issue as a question of a woman's right to make her own reproductive decisions. ``Our first goal is to keep up front in the public eye the unborn child,'' said Father John Gouldrick, executive director of the National Conference of Bishops' Secretariat for Pro-Life Activities. ``That seems to have been lost in the debate since Webster.'' The Rally for Life is being billed as a celebration rather than a protest or march. Among those scheduled to appear were Christian singer Sandi Patti; and country singer Terri Gibbs. Nancy Myers, spokeswoman for the Right to Life group, said more than 2,000 buses were arriving for the rally from as far away as California, including 425 from Pennsylvania. Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League, called the event ``an attempt by the anti-choice minority to recoup some of their strength, because they've been losing.'' She criticized Bush and Quayle for supporting the rally. ``As long as this small, vocal minority of Americans has the support of the two most powerful politicians in America, the threat to choice is very real and a fundamental freedom hangs by a thread,'' Michelman said.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Crashes On Roof Of Detroit Suburban Office Building
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter removing a satellite dish from the top of the IBM Corp. building crashed onto the roof and burst into flames this morning, killing the pilot, authorities said. Four people assisting with the work escaped without injury when they ran to the far end of the roof as the helicopter crashed shortly after 8:30 a.m., said Southfield fire Lt. James Bunker. The pilot, whose name was not immediately released, was the only person aboard the helicopter, police Lt. Floyd Raths said. The fire atop the 14-story building located 12 miles northwest of downtown Detroit was extinguished within 20 minutes and did not spread to the building itself, he said. ``They were lifting off a satellite dish from the top of the building,'' Raths said. ``Evidently, it lost power in the process of the lift and crashed down to the top of the building and exploded.'' The helicopter was owned by Command Helicopters Inc. of Joliet, Ill., and had been hired by MCI Corp., a long-distance telephone company, Bunker said. Calls to Command Helicopters were not returned late this morning. A man who answered the phone at MCI offices in Detroit said he wasn't familiar with the accident and would not comment. Ernie Desmarais, who watched the accident from a nearby restaurant, said the engine noise became louder as the helicopter apparently strained under the weight of the dish suspended from a cable. The helicopter tilted on one side and its blades struck the roof before the craft fell, Desmarais said. He said he heard a small explosion, followed by a much larger one. ``All of a sudden the whole building shook,'' said Chuck Siemen, an IBM employee working on the building's fourth floor. The Federal Aviation Administration sent investigators to the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Police Discover Antiquities In Raid
DOC.TEXT: Police raided two homes and found nearly 100 antiquities dating from the Stone Age to the Byzantine period, police said Saturday. The treasures discovered Friday include jewelery, weapons, coins, glassware, earthenware statuettes and parts of urns, the official said on condition of anonymity. Police would not say what prompted the raid in Krania, 12 miles northwest of this central Greek town. ``This is certainly the greatest haul in the area and possibly in the whole of Greece, considering the uniqueness of two or three of the finds and the rarity of the rest. There was a spearhead from 4000 B.C., which an archaeologist here says is unique,'' he said by telephone. The finds were hidden in the homes of a 26-year-old laborer and a 32-year-old miner, who were detained, the official said. According to the official, the objects date from the Stone Age to the fall of the Byzantine empire in 1453.

DOC.HEAD: Map Leads to Search for Remains of Two Teen-age Girls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 pvs, bgng `Officials planned ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with search not resuming today, officials pursuing other leads. Picks up 6th graf, `Kentucky state...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LX1
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old girl killed a man who she said had chained her to a tree and raped her repeatedly for three weeks, and police used the man's hand-drawn map to search for the remains of two other missing girls. The girl told police she was abducted by Phillip E. Clopton, 39, of Louisville and that she got free and killed him Thursday with his own shotgun while he slept. Federal and state police began a search in three central Kentucky counties after a map and a journal found Friday at Clopton's backwoods campsite in La Rue County indicated two girls had been killed and dismembered. Divers also scoured the Rolling Fork River, but nothing was found, police said. LaRue County Sheriff Merle Edlin said the map was ``not too detailed,'' but all of the burial plots except one ``were close to or in water.'' Although Edlin said earlier that officials would resume the search today if rain held off, a state police dispatcher in Elizabethtown said late this morning that officials decided not to continue the search at this point and would pursue other aspects of the case. ``They are going to follow up some leads they've got,'' said the dispatcher, Charles Mattingly. He said some people would be interviewed but he had no other details. Kentucky state Police Lt. Wayne Edwards said the girl killed Clopton, rather than running away, because she feared he would wake up and track her down. ``She's 15 years old and she was petrified,'' he said. The girl had several bruises but did not appear to be malnourished, Edwards said. She was treated at Hardin Memorial Hospital in Elizabethtown and released to her father. Another man, 41-year-old James R. Cable, was arrested in the case Thursday night in Louisville and charged with first-degree rape and sodomy. Cable was being held in the LaRue County jail under $250,000 bond on each count. Edlin said Cable was not suspected in the killings but may have distributed the body parts. His relationship with Clopton, who had been previously imprisoned for sodomy and rape, was not immediately clear. The FBI and police had been searching for Clopton in the disappearance of all three girls, who authorities and family friends said were acquainted. Officials had identified the missing girls as Bridgett Allen and Sherry Wilson, two 14-year-olds from Louisville who left home in January, Edlin said. Kentucky State Police Detective Robert Foster said the 15-year-old girl initially left Louisville willingly with Clopton ``but there obviously came time when she wanted to get away.'' The girl's 18-year-old sister, however, told The Courier-Journal of Louisville that her sister was kidnapped. ``She didn't run away. Everybody thought she ran away, but she didn't,'' the sister was quoted as saying. The girl said she took a shotgun while the man slept in a tent and killed him with a single shot to the head. She said she walked several miles from the campsite, half a mile deep in the woods off a gravel road about 15 miles east of Hodgenville, and called the State Police from a store. A police report did not reveal how she freed herself, Edlin said. State police said they found a map and a spiral-bound notebook in which Clopton described killing at least two people, dismembering them and scattering their parts in rural areas of LaRue, Hardin and Nelson counties. The map, roughly sketched in pen on a piece of notebook paper, included the missing girls' names and the spots in which various body parts supposedly were buried, Edlin said. Bridgett Allen's mother, Cathy, told the Lexington Herald-Leader that she went to Clopton in late February or early March looking for her daughter, but he wouldn't tell her anything. Ms. Allen said police had told her that Clopton's diary said the bodies of the two girls were in his Louisville apartment at the time. At the campsite, police found two footlockers full of canned goods and other supplies and a makeshift toilet. A nearby creek served as a cooler. There were also cooking supplies, sleeping bags, clothing and survival books. Neighbors said the campsite was on land once owned by Clopton's grandparents.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Ignores Warnings, Protests A Second Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Zorig, one name, is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Mongolian opposition groups on Saturday protested for a second straight day in their capital of Ulan Bator despite a stern warning from the Communist government that they were breaking the law. About 4,000 people, mostly young, gathered for two hours across the street from the government palace, according to sources in the Mongolian capital interviewed by telephone. One of their banners demanded the resignation of President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat, whom it nicknamed ``Iron Mask'' Ochirbat and depicted in a tank with missiles flying from his face. The reference was to a speech Tuesday in which Ochirbat rejected opposition demands for the Communist-dominated legislature to resign and said: ``The state is empowered to and will show an iron mask in the face of opposition activity.'' Mongolian television warned Friday night that illegal demonstrators faced 30 days in jail and fines of about $90 _ more than the average monthly wage. Ochirbat issued a regulation this month requiring advance permission for all demonstrations. The official newspaper, Unen, published a government statement Saturday accusing the protesters of trying to usurp power and jeopardize the state. The statement was reported by China's official Xinhua News Agency. The hard-line response to the latest series of protests seems to indicate the government is losing patience after five months of pro-democracy demonstrations that have won major concessions. The ruling Mongolian Communists gave up their constitutional right to power last month and agreed to the first multiparty elections in the country's history. But the opposition groups, made up largely of young, urban professionals, have accused the Communists of writing the election law to guarantee their own victory. When they tried to form a picket line Friday around the government palace to demand the legislature's resignation, soldiers and police got there first and formed a protective cordon around the building. The security forces were unarmed, and the protesters left peacefully after several hours. It was the first such confrontation between protesters and security forces since the democracy movement began in December, inspired by political reforms elsewhere in the Soviet bloc. The sources said speeches at Saturday's protest criticized the government's use of troops. Only a few uniformed police stood by Saturday, and by evening security forces removed some of the barriers they had erected around the government palace. In a brief speech over television and radio Friday night, one of the key opposition leaders, Zorig, said they would continue struggling for change through peaceful means. Government and Communist Party officials have pledged repeatedly not to use force. They apparently believe that some reforms are inevitable and that they can best stay in power by leading reforms rather than resisting. Xinhua has rarely reported on Mongolia's demonstrations, but has carried reports whenever the government there issues warnings that coincide with Chinese leaders' view that popular demonstrations are dangerous. It reported Ochirbat's decree restricting demonstrations, for example.

DOC.HEAD: India Warns Pakistan, Won't Rule Out Cross-border Raids
DOC.TEXT: India on Saturday warned Pakistan it would not tolerate infringement of its sovereignty in the border state of Kashmir, and a government spokesman refused to rule out raids on guerrilla camps in Pakistan. ``There will be no compromise on the measures necessary to protect our integrity,'' the government said in a prepared statement read by Foreign Ministry spokesman Aftab Seth. Asked whether India was prepared to send its troops across the frontier to eliminate guerrilla training camps in Pakistani-controlled territory, Seth said: ``We rule nothing out.'' He said Indian-Pakistani relations would not improve until ``there is credible evidence on the ground that Pakistan is desisting from its abetment of terror and violence.'' An escalation of violence by Moslem militants in Kashmir and the ensuing crackdown by Indian government troops have brought India and Pakistan to one of their worst crises since their 1971 war, the third one between the two countries since they became independent from Britain in 1947. Both countries have reinforced their troops along the border and the contested Kashmir frontier. Each side has said it does not want war but has accused the other of fomenting a climate that could lead to one. The latest Indian statement was issued in response to remarks by Pakistan's foreign minister, Sahabzada Yaqub-Khan, at a news conference Thursday at U.N. headquarters in New York. Yaqub-Khan called the Kashmir situation ``extremely grim'' and said ``it would be accurate to say that within the last two weeks a war psychosis has been created.'' Saturday's Indian statement said Yaqub-Khan ``omitted to mention, perhaps deliberately, that this situation was the direct and inevitable outcome of Pakistan's attempts to train, arm, aid and abet terrorism directed against India.'' Pakistan has repeatedly denied it trains or harbors Kashmiri militants who want to secede from India. The Indian statement also accused Pakistan governments, ``both central and provincial,'' of trying to raise funds to support the separatist movement. ``The internal situation in Kashmir is the creation of Pakistan-supported and -assisted terrorists. These gun-toting religious fundamentalists have indulged in arson, kidnappings, terrorizing the civilian population, killings of innocent citizens, murder of officials discharging their duties,'' the statement said. At least 308 people have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20, when Indian troops launched a crackdown on the separatists. Most of those slain were Moslem militants or supporters shot by Indian troops during anti-India demonstrations or while defying curfews. Kashmir was a princely state when Indian and Pakistan were partitioned along religious lines into separate nations. Pakistan moved into the northern third of Kashmir, while the rest came under Indian control as part of the state of Jammu-Kashmir. Today Jammu-Kashmir is the only Moslem-majority state in predominantly Hindu India. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems, but nationwide only 12 percent of the 880 million Indians are Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Two Buses Collide, Killing 18
DOC.TEXT: Two buses crowded with Moslems returning home from holiday travels collided head-on Saturday, killing 18 people and injuring two, the state-run news agency reported. The fiery accident happened in eastern Pakistan about 60 miles north of Lahore, the capital of Punjap Province, Associated Press of Pakistan reported. Many passengers were returning home after Eid-il Fitr, a three-day national holiday marking the end of Ramadon, the Moslem month of fasting. The news agency gave no further details.

DOC.HEAD: Churches Reopen After-24 Hour Closure ^Eds: Corrects Laham's title in 7th graf, `If the...'
DOC.TEXT: Christian shrines and churches reopened today after a 24- hour closure to protest a Jewish settlement in the Old City of Jerusalem. Leaders of nine major Christian sects closed their churches on Friday after the Greek Orthodox Church locked the gates to the church of the Holy Sepulcher, where Catholics say Jesus was crucified and buried. It was believed to be the first time the church of the Holy Spulcher closed its doors in 800 years. The Greek Orthodox Church owns the 72-room St. John's Hospice that 150 Jewish settlers moved into on April 11 during Easter celebrations. The church claims that the four-building complex was illegally leased to the settlers. The government admitted last week that it had contributed $1.8 million to the establishment of the settlement, provoking outrage in Israel and abroad. Israel's Supreme Court ordered the settlers out by Tuesday but will allow 20 guards and maintenance staff to remain in the building pending a final ruling on the tenancy dispute. Church leaders plan more protests if the settlers are not evicted. ``If the situation continues to be critical, we will have to close churches again, hold more special prayers and appeal to the international community to pressure Israel to evict the settlers,'' Lufti Laham, the Melchite Catholic bishop, said. George Hintilian, secretary to the Armenian patriarch Torkum Manoogian, said the Christian community is determined to have its rights recognized. ``The closure of churches and houses of worship in Jerusalem, Bethlehem, Nazereth and the Galilee was never done, not even in the darkest conditions. This shows how serious we are,'' Hintilian said. The Old City, captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East War, is the site of Jewish, Moslem and Christian holy places.

DOC.HEAD: Criticism of Japan Seen as Growing Political Issue
DOC.TEXT: Richard Gephardt thinks maybe he was a little ahead of the curve on Japan. During the 1988 presidential campaign, people accused him of bashing Japan on its trade policies. They called him protectionist. Today, however, he says a lot more people are in his camp, particularly Democrats who sense a good issue for 1992. ``There is a greater understanding on the part of a lot of people, especially about our problems with Japan and a few of the other countries where there are really significant trade access problems,'' the Missouri Democratic congressman said. While President Bush is receiving near-record high job performance ratings in opinion polls, some analysts believe U.S. trade problems with Japan could emerge as an issue against the Republican president in 1992. ``It's the biggest long-term danger to the Bush administration,'' said Democratic pollster Stanley Greenberg. When Bush announced Friday that he was removing Japan from the ``hit list'' of countries judged by the administration to have the most offensive trade barriers against U.S. products, members of Congress were quick to protest. ``It is clear that Japan should be on the list,'' said Sen. Don Riegle, D-Mich. ``Our government is not using the tools that are available to correct this continuing hemorrhage of U.S. capital and jobs.'' ``Trade access problems.'' That's the polite term used by people upset by the $49 billion deficit in the U.S. trade balance with Japan. Some Americans feeling the heat of competition with Japan are apt to be less polite. For example, try the radio ad run by a suburban Washington auto dealer. In an accent distinctly Japanese, a man is heard admiring an American car at a fictitious Tokyo auto show. An incredulous American voice asks: ``Haven't you ever seen a Safford Lincoln Continental before?'' ``Only in magazines,'' is the reply. ``Japanese have too many import restrictions and taxes to see one in person.'' ``I wouldn't phrase it as Japan bashing, obviously,'' said Sen. John Breaux of Louisiana, chairman of the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee. ``But I think it is a very legitimate issue. People in the hinterlands and middle America are feeling we are giving away our technology.'' ``There is a frustration Americans feel over not controlling their own destiny,'' said Michael McCurry, communications director of the Democratic National Committee. But McCurry and other politicians questioned the long-term value of Japan bashing. ``Bashing Japan gets you the audience,'' said the DNC official. ``But you have to make a pretty sophisticated argument about what you would do.'' Ohio is one of the states where people feel hardest hit by competition from Japan. Jim Ruvolo, the state's Democratic Party chairman, recalled that during the 1988 presidential campaign, the Ohio party produced and ran a television spot that directly attacked Japanese trade practices. When that ad ran, Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis gained six points in the state. Frank Greer, a Democratic political consultant, said that among many Americans there is ``anxiety we are slipping behind.'' But he said people are as likely to blame American management practices as they are to point to Japanese trade policies. ``The Japan bashing, I don't think you can tell yet,'' said Bob Teeter, a Republican pollster and adviser to Bush. ``I think it's one of those things that has the potential on the surface to work for you and under the surface to backfire.'' ``I don't think out-and-out bashing works anymore,'' said Greenberg, who has examined public attitudes toward Japan. ``You can run on putting our own house in order, putting America first, about watching out for our interests and not being taken advantage of and with Japan as the primary example of a country that is taking advantage of our good will.'' He said Japan could become an issue against Bush if there were an economic downturn. ``I think the Bush administration (seen as) standing by while the Japanese became more and more dominant would become a major political problem,'' said Greenberg. Attitudes toward Japan differ. In the Midwest, where the automobile industry has been hit hard, politicians can attack Japanese trade practices with impunity. In California, feelings are more complex. ``I think there's a great concern about becoming too jingoistic,'' said former California Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., now the state's Democratic Party chairman. ``It may look good in a primary or a given state race. But when you look at how imbedded we are in a world economy it's going to be very difficult for somebody to get very far by bashing key elements of our own stability.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Writers Coming to Ole Miss
DOC.TEXT: Eight Soviet writers on a U.S. government-funded tour, which has provoked controversy because of some members' reputedly anti-Semitic works, were to arrive Sunday at the University of Mississippi. In Montana, the writers' visit was canceled after one host, Little Big Horn College on the Crow Indian Reservation, refused to receive them. The American Jewish Committee has complained that the tour gives known anti-Semites legitimacy and prestige. ``We're happy to receive them,'' said Martha Boynton, International Projects director at Ole Miss. She said she knew nothing of the writers' work when she agreed to the visit. ``It's never been our policy to question any of the thought or ideology of our foreign visitors,'' Boynton said. Little Big Horn College President Janine Pease-Windy Boy also said she hadn't known of the reputed anti-Semitism when the visit was scheduled. She said the college and the community felt that Native Americans, as minorities themselves, could not appear to condone bigotry against others. The Montana Council for International Visitors on Monday canceled the group's two appearances in the state, scheduled for May 6-9, saying the controversy had destroyed the chance for meaningful dialogue. The U.S. Information Agency, the tour's sponsor, defends it as a means of exposing the Soviet writers to democracy in action. USIA spokesman Frank S. Johnson Jr. has said, ``I don't know that they are anti-Semitic; I don't know that they are not, either. ... We feel very strongly that pluralism in this country is worth talking about and observing.'' During their four-day Mississippi visit, the Soviets will ``learn about the South, specifically Southern literature and William Faulkner,'' Boynton said. ``We'll not get into any discussion further afield than that.'' The tour also includes stops in Washington; Pittsburgh; Iowa City, Iowa; Urbana and Kansas, Ill.; San Francisco; and New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Census Counter Bitten by Woman, Authorities Say
DOC.TEXT: A census counter was attacked and bitten on the shoulder by a woman who apparently mistook her for a fund-raiser, authorities said. Sandra Reed, 32, of Alton was charged with two counts of battery after the incident Wednesday and could also face federal charges, officials said. Census worker Debra Price said she sought medical attention immediately after the attack. Because her skin was broken when she was bitten, she was tested for AIDS. ``I didn't even get to ask her any questions and I identified myself as a U.S. Census bureau person,'' said Price, 31, of Godfrey. ``She thought I was a solicitor, and she told me to get out of her face. I couldn't (because) she grabbed hold of me by the neck,'' Price said. ``She wouldn't let go.'' Price said a neighbor, Cynthia Hargis, tried to help her but was also attacked. ``It's really bizarre. To be attacked and bitten is unusual,'' said Ron McCoy, regional Census Bureau spokesman. ``Usually the biggest problem we have is people not being home.'' Price was one of 300 census workers working in the area of Southern Illinois east of St. Louis, counting people who had not sent in census forms. Reed is being investigated and may be charged with attacking a federal government employee, the FBI said. The charge carries a fine of up to $250,000 and a sentence of up to three years in prison, said assistant U.S. attorney Don Coleman. She was released on her own recognizance.

DOC.HEAD: Partisan Fight Brewing in Senate Over Campaign Financing
DOC.TEXT: Senators are giving up efforts to reach a bipartisan compromise on campaign finance reform and instead putting the finishing touches this week on rival Republican and Democratic bills. Although lawmakers are still uncertain of precisely what they are being asked to support, Majority Leader George Mitchell wants to bring the issue to the Senate floor by the end of the week. The debate should send off sparks and occupy the Senate for quite a while as the parties jockey for position. Democrats already are trying to pin the obstructionist label on Republicans while GOP lawmakers are countering with a bill of their own, to be unveiled early this week. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., each met with their followers last week to explain the workings of the bills. But lawmakers were still ``flyspecking'' the proposals for clues as to how they might affect their political futures. ``Everybody wants campaign finance reform but they don't quite agree on what that is,'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., said as he emerged from a caucus. Dole and Mitchell named a task force of academic and professional campaign experts in January to come up with bipartisan recommendations. Last month, the panel proposed changes that called for painful sacrifices from both parties. The two leaders cautiously embraced the chief recommendation _ so-called flexible ceilings on campaign spending. But their followers balked at the notion. ``Unfortunately, the parties don't have much common ground,'' said Senate Democratic Whip Alan Cranston of California. ``I think we'll pass a bill. How strong it will be remains to be seen.'' By a 2-to1 margin, Republicans last week rejected the flexible ceilings, which would abolish specific limits on how much candidates could raise from outside their states. They called for an end to political action committees (PACs) _ which provide funds to candidates, often on behalf of lobbies. Dole acknowledged that abolishing PACs would most likely be held an unconstituional infringment on the freedom of speech. But Republicans have prepared a fallback position calling for the abolition of only corporate and union-affiliated PACs, as President Bush advocated last year. Democrats embraced flexible ceilings but said they should not be as flexible as the experts recommended. Specifically, they opposed the idea of no limit on small, home-state contributions. Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., a drafter of the Republican counterproposal, said 85 percent of Republicans oppose any limit. ``An even larger number of Democratic senators feel that there has to be a limit, that it isn't reform without some type of limit,'' said Mitchell. ``That's going to be the most difficult area.'' The Democratic bill would establish ceilings for Senate campaigns ranging from $1.5 million for the smallest states such as Alaska, Idaho, New Hampshire and West Virginia up to $8.25 million for the largest state, California. It also would limit PAC contributions to 20 percent of the total. Democratic leaders earlier had abandoned hopes of winning public, taxpayer financing of congressional campaigns. However, a proposal by Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., to provide candidates 20 percent of their spending ceiling through government vouchers for buying TV time has been gaining momentum. One idea on how to pay for it is raising the current voluntary $1 checkoff on income tax returns for presidential campaigns. Meanwhile, House leaders have put off any action on campaign finance reform until after they see how the Senate handles it. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said last week he wants to bring the issue to the floor in June despite a similar lack of progress toward a compromise there between the two parties. ``There are some things we can agree on, but I think it is fair to say that, overall, there will be more significant elements in which we will be in disagreement,'' he said. House Republican leader Robert Michel of Illinois said he envisons the two parties ``going at the issue hammer and tong.''

DOC.HEAD: Freedom for `Winchester Three,' Britain Admits a Mistake
DOC.TEXT: Saying ``British justice stinks,'' an Irishwoman flew home to freedom Saturday, her conviction for terrorist conspiracy quashed in a sensational British court ruling. Martina Shanahan, who arrived in Dublin on her 25th birthday, was released with fellow prisoners John McCann and Finbar Cullen, who flew to Ireland separately. Each had served 2{ years of a 25-year sentence. A British appeals court ruled Friday that the 1988 trial of the so-called ``Winchester Three'' could have been prejudiced by a British Cabinet minister's remarks. The three were jailed for allegedly conspiring to murder Tom King, then the government's secretary of state for Northern Ireland. During their trial in the western England city of Winchester, the government changed the law to allow juries to draw negative inferences from a suspect's silence under police questioning. King, now defense secretary, was prominent in defending the change. He said on television that defendants should not have the right to remain silent. The appeal court agreed King's remarks could have prejudiced the trial, and ordered the three freed. The government immediately ordered them deported. The case of the Winchester Three was the latest in a series of embarrassments for Britain over the justice it metes out to Irish suspects. In October, ``the Guildford Four'' were released, having served 14 years of a life sentence for bombings that killed five people. An appeals judge ruled that police lied about some of the evidence. Then there are ``the Birmingham Six,'' jailed for life in 1975 for bombings that killed 19 people. Their supporters insist they are victims of a miscarriage of justice, and the government has agreed to have certain aspects of the case reviewed. For the Irish, the case of the Winchester Three struck particularly close to home. Unlike the Guildford and Birmingham convicts, most of whom come from Northern Ireland where the Irish Republican Army wages its war against Britain, the Winchester Three come from the Irish Republic. None seemed to fit the stereotype of the hardened fighter for the IRA, which wants to unite Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland. Cullen, 29, is from a prominent middle class family. McCann, 26, is the son of an oil company executive. Even as they returned to rapturous welcome from family and friends, question marks remained. They were arrested in 1987 after Cullen and Ms. Shanahan were spotted near the King family home in County Wiltshire, western England. McCann was arrested at a nearby campground. Police said papers were found containing the names of 19 British national figures, some with their car license numbers. Police said the group's possessions included a woollen mask, binoculars, forged driver's licenses, $7,200, a radio and a magazine article on how to become an expert sniper. The defense argued in court that the possessions did not connect them with an assassination plot, but no explanation of their activities was forthcoming. The appeal court rejected the plea of insufficient evidence, and The Irish Times, Dublin's leading newspaper, editorialized that no one could deny ``something murky was afoot'' when the three were arrested. Said Ms. Shanahan at Dublin Airport: ``British justice stinks. There is no such thing as British justice. The Birmingham Six should be home as well.'' But most newspapers and politicians in Dublin praised the British court for acknowledging a mistake. ``What is important about this appeal judgment in the broader context of Anglo-Irish relations,'' the Irish Independent said, ``is that it will have gone a long way toward reassuring Irish people about the administration of justice in cases involving Irish accused.''

DOC.HEAD: Panels Challenge VA Authority To Award Back Payments to Vets With Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Two congressional committees are challenging a Veterans Affairs Department decision to award back payment of previously denied claims to Vietnam vets suffering from a rare form of cancer linked to Agent Orange. The Democratic and Republican leaders of the House and Senate veterans committees wrote a letter to the VA earlier this month challenging the authority of the department to award retroactive benefits. But the legal issue is caught up in the emotional and complex issue of compensating veterans who claim they have a variety of ailments due to exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange. The letter, which was first disclosed in Saturday's editions of The Washington Post, said benefits may be awarded only ``prospectively'' _ from the date of the new regulation _ and not retroactively. It said the VA's decision to set a retroactive effective date for awarding benefits was unprecedented. ``We question whether you have such authority under current law with respect to a claim after its denial has become final,'' the April 18 letter to VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski said. The issue arose March 29, when the VA announced it would award benefits to anyone who served in Vietnam and later developed non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The announcement came the same day the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said Vietnam vets had a 50 percent higher risk of developing the disease than did men who hadn't served. But the VA, in its attempt to defuse the lingering Agent Orange issue, used its file of past Agent Orange claims to come up with the number of lymphoma victims who should be compensated. The government consistently denies a connection between exposure to the defoliant and a host of ailments, despite claims of veterans groups, a class-action lawsuit that was settled, and a number of independent scientists. Derwinski asserted that the benefits were for not for Agent Orange exposure but for anyone who served in Vietnam who has the cancer. VA was thus able to give some relief without conceding an association between exposure and disease. The same CDC study ruled out an increase in several other cancers among Vietnam veterans that have been linked to Agent Orange exposure. The CDC has acknowledged that the study does not disprove a connection. The VA estimated it would have to pay up to $25 million a year in death and disability benefits to the 1,800 afflicted veterans or their survivors. It is drafting new regulations to award the claims. Should the VA reverse its March 29 decision, those who were previously denied claims could refile for benefits. The benefits would become payable from the date of the new regulations or the date of the CDC study, said Charles Peckarsky, an adviser to the House committee. The letter, which originated in the House VA Committee, is signed by Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, the Mississippi Democrat who chairs the committee; Rep. Bob Stump, R-Ariz., the ranking minority member; Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., chairman of the Senate VA Committee; and Sen. Frank H. Murkowski, R-Alaska, the ranking Republican member. VA spokesman Dennis R. Boxx defended Derwinski's action, saying, ``He believes that the decision was a legal decision, but just as importantly, a fair and humane decision that was appropriate given all the complex questions and issues.'' He said the development is ironic because the VA ``is often accused of not trying to do things that are humane and fair and compassionate.'' The committee leaders' views are not necessarily shared by all the members. ``I don't think it behooves veterans advocates to be working against veterans benefits,'' said Rep. Lane Evans, D-Ill., a member of the committee and a leader of the Vietnam-era veterans caucus in Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Killed by Bomb Found at Bus Station
DOC.TEXT: A bomb found at a bus station exploded Saturday night, killing a policeman who had been sent to investigate it, a police spokesman said. Nine other people were wounded, the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity in keeping with police regulations. Police received a report that a device believed to be a bomb had been found at a bus station on the south side of the capital. It exploded as the constable inspected it, the spokesman said. He said there was no indication who left the bomb or what the target was. Only local city buses used the station, the spokesman said.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Post-Dispatch, Knight-Ridder Journalists Win Awards
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Stands for AM-Clapper Award listed on AM-News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: St. Louis Post-Dispatch correspondent-columnist Bill Lambrecht won the 46th annual Raymond Clapper Memorial Award and Knight-Ridder Newspapers correspondent Christopher Scanlan was named winner of the Barnet Nover Memorial Award, it was announced Saturday. The awards, which recognize excellence in reporting, were made by the Raymond Clapper Foundation and the Barnet Nover Foundation. Each award also carried a $1,500 cash prize. Second place carried a $500 prize. The awards were to be presented at the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner Saturday night. Lambrecht was cited for his series on the export of U.S. garbage. Scanlan was named for his series of articles on the effect of the budget crisis on government health care for veterans. John Hall of Media General was named the second-place Clapper winner for his series on the Navy's investigation of the explosion on the battleship Iowa. Andrew Melnykovych of the Casper Star-Tribune was named the second-place Nover winner for his series on federal oil and gas royalty audits and the nomination of James Cason to be assistant secretary of agriculture. The Clapper winners were selected from among 33 entries submitted to a panel of current and former Washington reporters. Raymond Clapper, a Washington correspondent and columnist for Scripps Howard Newspapers, was killed in an airplane crash while covering the invasion of the Marshall Islands in World War II. The Clapper award was established in 1944 to recognize a Washington-based newspaper writer whose work ``most clearly approximated the ideals of fair and painstaking reporting and good craftsmanship that were characteristic of Raymond Clapper.'' The Nover winners were selected from 24 entries submitted to a panel of five Washington journalists. Barnet Nover was bureau chief of the Denver Post's Washington bureau from 1947 to 1971. He also was a columnist for The Washington Post and a reporter with the Buffalo Evening News.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Gratified by His New Wave of Popularity
LaserPhoto AX2
DOC.TEXT: Jimmy Carter says he's gratified by his popularity and the respect he's getting for his global mediation efforts, but he says he's ``not foolish enough'' to think about winning the presidency again. He also has no aspirations to be the world's most prominent election observer. Carter played a prominent role in certifying that Nicaragua's recent presidential election was fair. He was invited to oversee elections in Hungary and Romania. And he has agreed to help monitor elections in the Dominican Republic next month. But, he said: ``It's not a niche I want to fulfill permanently. If I see that my presence can be the deciding factor in the integrity of an election, I would do it, but I don't need to go just to say, `We've got a former U.S. president here.' I'm not looking for ceremonial roles.'' In an interview last week in his Carter Presidential Center office, the 65-year-old former president warned of tougher times ahead for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, said it's a mistake to assume that communism is crumbling universally, and explained how _ and why _ he was willing to go to Beirut, Lebanon. Carter attributed the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe mainly to Gorbachev. ``It's a change that Gorbachev has brought,'' Carter said. ``It would be a mistake to think it's a worldwide inevitability. ``We don't see it happening in North Korea. We don't see it happening in Vietnam. We don't see it happening in Albania. We don't see it happening in China, and we haven't seen it happen in Cuba.'' Gorbachev's biggest threat _ ``much worse than ethnic independence moves or anything else'' _ is his country's economic ruin, Carter said, adding: ``When I meet privately with Soviet leaders, they make it clear to me that the West has underestimated the economic deterioration in the Soviet Union. ``How Gorbachev will deal with it, I don't know. The fact is, he's been in office now for about five years, and the situation's gotten worse.'' In the Middle East, Carter sees ``a general consensus ... now, that the time for hostage-taking has passed and that these hostages ought to be released.'' He complimented President Bush for ``opening up new avenues of at least discussion and exploration on how the hostages might be released.'' In the wake of last week's release of hostage Robert Polhill, Carter said, the administration should not be ``too effusive in your thanks, when only one hostage is released. But you can acknowledge the fact that this is leading toward reconciliation.'' After spending 10 days in the Middle East last month, Carter was criticized for charging Israel with violations of Palestinian rights. ``I know that when any statement is made that is critical of Israel ... it's going to be condemned,'' he said. ``I understand their concerns.'' He reiterated that he had simply condemned one Israeli policy _ ``deporting mothers and children from their own homes in the West Bank and Gaza to Jordan, which I thought was a terrible crime.'' Following his criticism, the policy was changed. ``I don't have any apology to make. I am concerned about any genuine belief that I am biased, but a lot of the accusations about bias are deliberately designed to prevent further criticism of Israel's policies. And I don't choose to be intimidated.'' During his trip, Carter sought to meet with Lebanese President Elias Hrawi, to understand first-hand Lebanon's position in the volatile region. He considered just going to Beirut, but ``I knew the State Department would not approve. So my thought was to meet with President Hrawi at a military base inside Lebanon.'' But Bush administration officials urged him to stay away from the terrorism-racked country. ``I felt perfectly secure, but I can understand the concerns of others about me,'' he said. While Carter has been seen as a success on the global stage, former President Reagan has been criticized for taking lucrative speaking engagements and stumbling badly in his testimony during the Iran-Contra trial of John Poindexter. The result: Carter's approval rating in U.S. public opinion polls is higher now than that of the man who defeated him so overwhelmingly 10 years ago. ``You find that surprising?'' Carter joked. During his administration from 1977 to 1981, Carter was was widely criticized for the state of the economy and his handling of foreign affairs, including the Iranian hostage crisis. Carter conceded he finds his new popularity flattering, although ``that's not the goal of my life, to get favorable public opinion polls.'' ``Part of it is what we've done since we've left the White House. Part of it is a growing historical assessment of our administrations. And I think part of it is the quite dramatic changes in Reagan's policies by George Bush. ``I think it would embarrass him, my saying this, but I think his policies are much more comparable to those of Kennedy and Johnson and Nixon and Ford and me than they are comparable with Reagan's policies.'' Still, Carter insists he never even daydreams about running again for anything: ``Never. I'm not foolish enough to think that I would win an election for president; that would be out of the question. And secondly, I'm perfectly satisfied with what I'm doing here. ``I can say what I like. I can meet whom I want. I can take on the projects that please me, and reject the ones that don't.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania, Gorbachev Spokesman Speak of Compromise
LaserPhotos MOS4, LON1
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president and a Soviet government spokesman on Saturday praised a French-West German proposal to defuse tensions, raising the possibility it could lead to a compromise between Moscow and Vilnius. The Kremlin has shut down shipments of oil, restricted natural gas and cut supplies of manufactured goods and food supplies to Lithuania. On Saturday, a Soviet government official said coal supplies had been cut as well. A letter from French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl proposed Lithuania suspend some laws backing up its March 11 declaration of independence but did not suggest repealing the declaration itself. ``We consider that this is not far from the line that the Soviet leadership has been pursuing from the very beginning,'' Arkady Maslennikov, a spokesman for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, told a Kremlin briefing. ``We consider this a constructive signal.'' Lithuanian leaders also are showing ``the understanding that there must be a return to the road of reason,'' Maslennikov said. In the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, President Vytautas Landsbergis told a news conference he considered the proposal a positive step, said Lithuanian journalist Eduardas Potashinskas. ``Some may interpret this letter as a concession to the categorical position of the Soviet Union,'' he quoted Landsbergis as saying. ``We see it differently.'' ``We will suggest that the initiative of these leaders not end with this letter,'' he said. On Friday, Lithuanian Premier Kazimiera Prunskiene said the French-West German proposal was ``the limit'' to compromise that Lithuania could accept. The Lithuanian leadership said it will bring the proposal before the Baltic republic's legislature this week for debate. In order to begin talks on the basis of the Kohl-Mitterrand letter, the two sides must find a formula that takes into account their opposing views of the independence declaration. Lithuania has sent several delegations to Moscow in hopes of arranging top-level meetings, but there have been few such contacts. Gorbachev says Lithuania must renounce the declaration. Landsbergis and the Lithuanian leadership say they cannot back down on the declaration but the laws implementing it and the schedule are negotiable. The republic says the declaration only recognizes the legal status Lithuania held before its forcible annexation _ along with that of neighboring Latvia and Estonia _ by the Soviet Union in 1940. Western countries including the United States never recognized the incorporation of the Baltic states but also have not recognized Lithuania's declaration. The issue is a test for Gorbachev, who faces several nationalist and ethnic crises. The parliament of Estonia has voted to become independent at an unspecified later date, and Latvia is scheduled to vote on the issue this week. Gorbachev and Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov have demanded that Lithuania reverse its opposition to its youths being drafted into the Soviet army, return Communist Party buildings being used by Lithuania's independent Communists and repeal a law on citizenship they regarded as discriminatory. The Soviet military has seized some buildings in Vilnius and conducted a series of military maneuvers an effort to pressure the republic of 3.8 million people. Officials say about 10,000 Lithuanians already are out of work because of the economic blockade from Moscow, and the Soviet news agency Tass said experts believe the figure will grow to 35,000 by Tuesday. The republic's only oil refinery shut down last week, and it is receiving only a small share of its normal allotment of natural gas. Supplies of gasoline to private car owners has been restricted to about 7 gallons a month and long lines have formed at gas stations. Many people are walking. Official Vilnius radio reported late Friday that publication of newspapers in the republic would be severely restricted this week. But it said Lithuania had enough newsprint to continue publishing the papers. Soviet authorities have restricted Western reporters from traveling to Lithuania, except by invitation on trips organized by the Foreign Ministry. The Associated Press was not invited on one trip currently under way. Vladimir Kosyunin, deputy chairman of the Soviet State Supply Committee, told Tass that coal supplies had been curtailed as well. Much of that coal comes from Poland, and Lithuania already owes about 1 million rubles for coal supplies, he said. Kosyunin told Tass it would take only a matter of days to restore normal shipments to Lithuania if a political settlement is reached. ``The situation is not yet irreversible, but it will be much more difficult to resolve the problem later.''

DOC.HEAD: Workers Begin Removing Famous Section of Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: Workers on Saturday began tearing down the thickest and perhaps most famous part of the Berlin Wall, a stretch of graffiti-covered concrete in front of the historic Brandenburg Gate. Crowds of tourists and souvenir peddlers watched as East German soldiers and West German construction workers with heavy tools began knocking away at the section ofwall that curves around the 18th-century gate. The huge, colonnaded gate represents the grandeur of old Berlin just as the section of wall in front of it symbolized its division. The wall provided some of the most memorable images of the revolution last autumn that ended four decades of Communist oppression, opened the wall, and began the process of reunifying the two Germanys. With the giant gate as a backdrop, protesters with chisels climbed on the wall last year to demonstrate their new freedom when East Germany's borders were finally opened. Much of the surrounding sections of the 100-mile wall already have been removed, but the section in front of the gate is considered the sturdiest. It is 10 feet high and equally as thick. The area around the Brandenburg Gate has become a heavily visited tourist area. Makeshift souvenir stands hawk everything from postcards depicting the revolt to key chains made of wall fragments. The work Saturday was part of an ongoing process of removing certain sections of the wall. The East German government says the entire wall will eventually be removed, except for one section that will stand as a monument. The East German news agency ADN reported Saturday that 70 segments of the Berlin Wall will be auctioned off on June 23 in the principality of Monaco.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Look out, Disney. Dolly has her sights set on a second Dollywood theme park in Japan. Dolly Parton, country music entertainer and part owner in the Pigeon Forge theme park that bears her name, announced Friday the Dollywood Co. is negotiating with Japanese developers to build a park near Tokyo. Disney already has a theme park in Tokyo, which opened in 1983. ``It's going to be fun teaching them to say `y'all' in Japan,'' said Ted Miller, vice president of development for Dollywood. Dollywood is a regional park at the foot of the Great Smoky Mountains that capitalizes on the theme of Appalachian culture. The park, which attracts more than 1 million visitors a year, mixes country music with working craftsmen and amusement rides. The proposed Japanese version, to be called Dollywood II, would be the same, only larger, Miller said. It would be the first of seven parks clustered together and linked by a common transportation system. He stressed that further feasibility studies, planning and construction mean that the park is several years away from construction. ``I don't want anyone to panic, we are not selling Dollywood to the Japanese,'' Ms. Parton quipped as she opened the news conference. Akio Hashimoto, president of the International Industry Development Inc. of Tokyo, the company developing the Japanese park, told reporters Ms. Parton's popularity in Japan ``is just incredible.'' The singer-actress is known for such hits as ``Here You Come Again'' and ``My Tennessee Mountain Home'' and for appearances in movies such as ``9 to 5.''

Conservative Christians don't get enthusiastic about the religious rantings of media mogul Ted Turner, the man who rewrote the Ten Commandments to suit his tastes. But Turner said Friday he isn't exactly crazy about fundamentalists, either. In a speech before the American Humanist Association, Turner criticized fundamentalist Christianity for emphasizing that man was born into sin. And, he said, Jesus would probably ``be sick at his stomach'' over the way his ideas had been ``twisted.'' Turner said while he was growing up, religion was ``pounded into us so much ... that I was saved seven or eight times.'' Turner said he pondered a career as a missionary. Then his sister died after a lengthy illness, despite his prayers. ``If God is love and all-powerful, why does he allow these things to happen?'' Turner asked. The more he strayed from his Christian upbringing, Turner said, ``the better I felt.'' Turner said he believes ``we're all basically good'' and that all people are ``kindred souls.'' Turner was honored as Humanist of the Year Friday night, mainly for his work on behalf of world peace and the environment. Copies of his own version of the 10 Commandments, the ``10 Voluntary Initiatives,'' were placed on each table at the banquet. His initiatives, which he announced last year, include population control, recycling and pacifism.

Actress Elizabeth Taylor is out of intensive care, much better after surviving a brush with death a week ago, officials said. ``According to her physicians she is responding well to treatment for pneumonia. She continues to improve and her condition is listed as stable,'' said a statement issued Friday by St. John's Hospital and Health Center. The actress was moved to a private room Thursday evening, it said. The previous day, she got off a ventilator that was used earlier in the week to help her breathe. Miss Taylor, 58, entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a persistent fever and sinus infection. Her condition worsened and she was transferred April 16 to St. John's. She had been in serious condition in the intensive care ward at St. John's since last Sunday. Doctors said that at one point last weekend she nearly died. The Oscar-winning star of ``Butterfield 8'' and ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf'' has been troubled with health problems for years, including recurring back troubles, drug and alcohol dependence, and a near-fatal bout of pneumonia in 1961.

The organization that arranged a broadcast interview with ``Satanic Verses'' author Salman Rushdie accused the BBC on Saturday of breaking an agreement not to ask the writer about his life in hiding. The BBC said it was understood from the start that Rushdie would be asked on Radio 4's ``Today'' program about his life as well about his support for Charter 88, which is campaigning for a written constitution for Britain. Rushdie has been in hiding since February 1989, when Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini decreed that Rushdie deserved to be killed because his book was blasphemous. ``It was agreed in writing that Charter 88 would be the main topic of a seven-minute interview,'' said the group's coordinator, Anthony Barnett. He said Rushdie was also angry about the interview. Rushdie answered questions about his life in hiding and under guard, and expressed annoyance only once, when asked a question on his thoughts on British hostages held by pro-Iranian forces in Lebanon.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Emmy-winning producer-director Chet Forte lost millions of dollars gambling and is now sickly and unemployed as he prepares to face federal tax and fraud charges, his court-appointed public defender says. ``He doesn't have a penny to his name,'' assistant federal public defender Larry Lustberg said Friday. ``That's what this case is all about.'' Forte, who was perhaps best known as producer of ABC's Monday night football, was released on personal recognizance following an initial hearing Friday on charges he misrepresented his finances in applying for $1.47 million in mortgage loans. Forte, 54, told Hedges during a 25-minute hearing that he was unemployed, without income, being supported by his wife's family. ``This is a tragedy in the magnitude of Pete Rose, and not entirely dissimilar,'' Lustberg said, referring to the former Cincinnati Reds manager who pleaded guilty to tax charges that stemmed from his gambling habits. ``There is gambling in this case, tax problems and enormous debts,'' Lustberg said. Forte is accused various counts of mail fraud, transporting stolen property across state lines and failure to file a federal income tax return in 1987. He could face more than 70 years in prison and millions of dollars in fines if convicted. Forte produced and directed ABC's coverage of the 1968 and 1984 Summer Olympics, NCAA football, Triple Crown horse races, the Indianapolis 500, and the World Series and All-Star Games. He won nine Emmys during 25 years with the network. Forte left ABC in 1987 to become an independent director and producer.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Finds Cooperative Fish Close To Home
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, an avid fisherman who has pursued the sport in Wyoming, the Florida Keys and the Gulf of Mexico since taking office, may have found a new lucky spot Saturday just a few miles from the White House. ``What do you think?'' Bush said, grinning broadly as he held up one of the 15 or so largemouth bass his fishing party caught during a six-hour excursion on the Potomac River just south of Washington. It was Bush's first try as president at fishing on the Potomac. ``Not bad at all. That's better than last week,'' Bush said, referring to the fishing trip in the Florida Keys he took following a meeting at Key Largo with French President Francois Mitterrand. Bush declined to answer reporters' questions about Lithuania, saying he would probably hold a news conference next week. The president sidestepped a question about whether the Potomac fishing was better than Maine. He has fished extensively from his powerboat in the Atlantic and in a river near his vacation home in Kennebunkport. ``Depends on what you're trying to do. ... You're not going to get me into that,'' he said. The Potomac runs past the Washington Mall, where Bush later spoke by telephone hookup to more than 60,000 anti-abortion demonstrators. The president's fishing party included WRC-TV news anchorman Jim Vance and The Washington Post's outdoor sports writer Angus Phillips. They first tried his luck in a cove on the Maryland shore. The group fared better later at a spot on the Virginia shore just down from Alexandria. Bush, who wore a khaki jacket decorated with a picture of swimming fish, piloted the boat on the six-mile return trip. Before throwing the fish back into the river, the president said he thought he had reeled in three or four. ``I don't know ... we don't do it that way. It's a team concept.'' Asked if he was surprised at the large number of bottles, paper cups and other trash floating in the Potomac, Bush said he was ``delighted'' that the once heavily polluted river has ``come back as far as it has.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran Arms Sale Funds Reported Diverted To US-Israeli Covert Actions
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Iran-Contra investigators discovered but kept secret a diversion to Israeli intelligence of more than $1 million in proceeds from the Reagan administration's sale of arms to Iran, The New York Times Magazine reports. The magazine, in an article by investigative journalist Seymour Hersh, also reports that senators decided before the much-publicized Iran-Contra hearings that they would not ``go after'' President Reagan. They agreed they would avoid seeking impeachment unless it seemed Reagan had been fully aware of the diversion of arms sale money to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels, the article said. The decisions were governed by a desire to avoid jeopardizing the release of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon and to protect the emerging strategic-arms negotiations with the Soviet Union, as well as Reagan's age and immense public popularity, Hersh writes. According to the article, Senate and House committees learned that former Gen. Richard Secord and his partner, Albert Hakim, who worked for White House aide Oliver North in the affair, had diverted Iranian arms-sale profits to the Israelis for the covert actions. The committees obtained documents that showed four cash transfers between Hakim's Swiss bank account and an account controlled by Amiram Nir, an Israeli counterterror official, Hersh writes. This transfer was not mentioned in the panels' joint report in November 1987. The report devotes only three paragraphs to the subject and describes the efforts by code-names ``TH-1, TH-2 and so on.'' It says North testified that the efforts ``had not progressed beyond the planning stage'' and that he therefore did not seek presidential authorization. But Hersh says ``highly placed American intelligence officials,'' whom he did not identify by name, told him that several of the North-Nir operations did take place in 1985 and 1986. These included covert electronic monitoring of the highway between Damascus and Beirut, a series of attempts to penetrate the Shiite Amal militia and the Druse sect inside Lebanon, and a continuing effort to locate Arab terrorists suspected of blowing up the Marine barracks in Lebanon in 1983, Hersh reports. Hersh adds that Secord acknowledged in an interview he was aware of the payments to Nir and said of them, ``This is black money _ Israeli black money,'' a term used to describe the financing of covert operations. Senate committee chief counsel Arthur Liman is quoted by Hersh as saying there were limits on what he could publish from the investigation. Other sources told Hersh that both House and Senate chairmen told Liman not to make anything public that might disrupt continuing efforts to gain the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon. Liman told Hersh that the question of whether the diversion to the Israelis was legal without written presidential authority _ a finding _ was referred to the Senate and House intelligence committees. Neither has made any public report on the matter. The desire to protect both Reagan and the strategic-arms negotiations motivated senators, Hersh says. According to one participant, Hersh writes, ``At an early caucus in January (1987), ... the senators reached one easy consensus. `We don't want to go after the president,' the participant said. `He was too old'.'' The witness also told Hersh that senators believed Reagan could not understand what had happened. Hersh quotes New Hampshire Republican Sen. Warren B. Rudman, vice chairman of the committee, as saying ``We decided to follow the evidence'' but agreed that ``if there was an impeachable offense, it could only be the diversion. The point we talked about was that if there is a conscious diversion we have no choice'' but to seek impeachment. ``If it's nonfeasance and negligence, there's too much at risk,'' Hersh quotes Rudman as saying. ``We could go on for four years.''

DOC.HEAD: Rioting Prisoners Set Fire, Take to Roof
DOC.TEXT: Inmates at the Loos prison mutinied Saturday, refusing to return to their cells after an exercise period and setting fire to a workshop, officials said. Hours later, about 50 prisoners remained on the roof. Several people, including prisoners and firefighters, were treated for smoke inhalation from the fire, which took firemen two hours to extinguish. The rampage started when more than 100 prisoners refused to return to their cells after exercise. Shortly after, another group of 370 prisoners ran amok, starting the fire in a pile of wood in the workshop, prison officials said. Authorities regained control of the interior of the prison within hours. But about 50 prisoners took refuge on the roof, threw tiles into the courtyard, and remained there four hours later, officials said. The governor for the Nord-Pass-de-Calais region, Jean-Claude Aurousseau, and the state prosecutor went to the scene. The prisoners holding out reportedly complained about guards who fired at four escaping prisoners Jan. 28. The four were caught several days later. The Loos prison houses 600 convicts. The mutiny was the first in France in 1990. There were at least 10 such rebellions last year.

Here is the text of President Bush's telephone remarks Saturday to anti-abortion protesters on the Washington Mall. Thank you, Henry Hyde, thank you for the introduction, and thank you as well for your commitment to life. Incidentally, this magnificent rally looks very, very good on television. How do I know? Because I've seen some of it. I want to pay my respects to our able vice president, Dan Quayle, and thank him for his commitment, to other members of Congress that are there, to Dr. Willke, to Dr. Dobson, and a special greeting to my friend, your eminences, Cardinal O'Connor and Cardinal Hickey and others that might be in attendance. I'm very pleased to have this opportunity to express to you my deeply held views about abortion on demand. In January of this year, I addressed the March for Life on this very issue. I said then and reaffirm now, that your presence on the mall today reminds all of us in government that Americans from all walks of life are committed to preserving the sanctity and dignity of human life. Like you, I realize that the widespread prevalence of abortion is a tragedy, not only in terms of lives destroyed, but because it so fundamentally contradicts the values that we as a nation hold dear. And when I look at adopted children, I give thanks that their parents chose life. Today, as a nation of faith and compassion, our mission must be to help more and more Americans make the right choice, the choice for life. One day, your life-saving message will have reached and influenced every American. And until then, continue to work for the day when respect for human life is sacrosanct and beyond question. I know from your devotion and selflessness that this day cannot be far away. God bless you, and God bless life. Thank you very, very much.

DOC.HEAD: East German Leader Arrives for Talks on German Unity
With AM-European Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's new non-Communist leaders arrived Saturday for meetings aimed at easing the concerns of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as his once-loyal ally spins away from the Soviet orbit. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere planned to meet with Gorbachev on Sunday to discuss the effects of German unification on Soviet military and economic interests.
