In an interview with the Soviet news agency Tass before leaving East Berlin, de Maiziere emphasized close ties with Moscow. He said East Germany could accept neither a neutral Germany nor NATO soldiers on East German territory before an all-Europe security system is put into place. ``A neutral Germany would be contrary to the spirit of the times, corresponding instead to the old mentality of blocs,'' Tass quoted de Maiziere as saying. ``It would only conserve military blocs, existing as a formally neutral state between them.'' ``We need a pan-European system of security,'' he was quoted as saying. ``Before this system is in place, NATO military presence on the territory of East Germany should not be allowed.'' De Maiziere, accompanied by his foreign, defense and econimics ministers, was greeted upon arrival in Moscow by Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. East Germany has been a key component in the Warsaw Pact military alliance and an important trading partner with the Soviets. The Soviets are seeking to preserve their current trade agreements with East Germany, which were made under the German nation's former Communist government. The talks are a prelude to formal negotiations between the Germanys and the four World War II allies that divided them: the Soviet Union, United States, Britain and France. Foreign ministers from the six nations are to begin unification negotiations May 5 in Bonn, West Germany. De Maiziere has said East Germany would protect the security interests of the Soviet Union. He has disagreed with West Germany's insistence that a unified Germany be a part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. De Maiziere was quoted in a newspaper interview on Saturday as saying that he and the Soviets disagree with West Germany on the alliance question. ``But this is not a stumbling block. There must be further negotiations about NATO and the question of security. I will make that clear in Moscow,'' de Maiziere said, according to the Hamburg-based Bild newspaper. In Dublin, Ireland, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said in a newspaper interview Saturday that a united Germany should be ``militarily non-aligned,'' and could belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Shevardnadze told the Irish Times that a formula was needed for German unification ``which would not radically tip the balance'' of military power. Shevardnadze insisted ``membership of a united Germany in NATO is unacceptable to us, since it would mean a radical disruption of the current balance of forces in Europe.'' Soviet and East German leaders also are likely to discuss Poland's demand that it be protected from any claim a united Germany may make on former German lands ceded to Poland after World War II. Poland late Friday gave a copy of a proposal to diplomats from both German states that it wants to be the framework for such a guarantee, East Germany's ADN news service and Poland's PAP news service said. In Bonn, a West German government spokesman confirmed officials there have received the proposal. Kohl has been reluctant to make a commitment to Poland's current borders, saying the question must be dealt with after unification.

DOC.HEAD: Croatian Democratic Union Leads In Final First Round Results
DOC.TEXT: A center-right coalition garnered more than 79 percent of the seats in the first round of Croatia's first free elections in 50 years, according to final results published Saturday. A total of 131 seats in the 356-seat tri-cameral regional parliament were decided in the first round of voting April 22-23, the state Tanjug news agency reported. The remaining 225 seats are to be voted on in a second round of balloting May 6-7. The center-right Croatian Democratic Union won 104 of the 131 seats decided, while the Communist Party _ renamed the Party for Democratic Reform _ won 13, according to final official results carried by Tanjug. The centrist Coalition for National Accord won 3 seats, Tanjug said. While in the first round more than 50 percent of the vote was needed to win a seat, in the second round only a simple majority is required. Franjo Tudjman, the leader of the Union, has expressed confidence that his party will emerge victorious after the second round of voting. He said after the first round last week that the first task of his party would be to prepare a new Western-style democratic constitution for Croatia and to discuss Yugoslavia's future with other states in the Yugoslav federation. Tudjman's party favors Yugosalvia becoming a loose alliance of semi-independent states in a confederation. The Croatian Democratic Union, which waged a campaign based largely on national sentiments, was vehemently opposed during the election by Serbs, who make up about 10 percent of Croatia's 4.8 million people. Serbia and Croatia, the second-largest state, have been traditional rivals ever since they united in Yugslavia in the aftermath of World War I. Yugoslavia is curently a looose federation of six republics. Croatia and the neighboring republic of Slovenia have held Yugoslavia's first post-war multiparty elections. Two more member republics are planning to hold similiar elections later this year. Communist-ruled Montenegro and Serbia have not legalized opposition parties.

DOC.HEAD: Computer-Equipped Cars May Relieve Congestion
DOC.TEXT: ``Smart cars'' that give drivers the latest traffic information on a computer screen will soon take to the roads in Florida and California in an experiment aimed at heading off gridlock on overburdened highways. Test programs in Los Angeles and Orlando over the next three years will feature cars equipped with computer screens using satellite-delivered traffic information from sensor-equipped ``smart highways.'' They are the start of a combined federal-state, private-and-public effort to avoid future shock on American roads: gridlock caused by ever-growing numbers of motorists on too few highways that are aging more quickly than they can be repaired, rebuilt or replaced. The application of electronic and communications technology ``can add efficiency and capacity without adding pavement,'' contends the Highway Users Federation, one of the groups behind the project. Experts say the technology is available, only the money and direction for its application are needed. The two test programs and an Orlando-area conference this week are intended to better define the problems and solutions. The National Leadership Conference on Implementing Intelligent Vehicle-Highway Systems, starting Thursday, is expected to set forth a plan for action ``and maybe get some startup of a national organization to carry this forward,'' said Mark Norman of the Highway Users Federation, a lobbying group. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner, who will speak at the conference, is calling for a transportation revolution because the nation's airports, highways, bridges, waterways and mass transit systems are simply wearing out. Experts say that since no new systems are in the works, the existing infrastructure must be made safer and more efficient. To get the new technologies on the road, Skinner wants a national research project supported by federal, state and local governments and by corporate and private groups. The ``smart car'' concept involves the driver, the vehicle and a traffic management team _ much as air travel involves the pilot, the aircraft and air traffic control. In California's Pathfinder program, expected to get rolling in a month or two, 25 smart cars will operate on the Santa Monica Freeway and parallel arteries. They will receive traffic information on dashboard-mounted electronic displays that are constantly updated. The screens tell drivers of congestion and outline alternate routes. In return, the cars feed information about road conditions to a central computer. The $2 million cost of the two-year test is being paid by the Federal Highway Administration, General Motors and the California Transportation Department. In the larger and more sophisticated Orlando trial, called Travtek, 100 cars will be rented and leased to tourists and residents who drive frequently, said Jack Butler of the state Department of Transportation. The computer screens will be able to suggest the shortest, least-congested routes and how to avoid construction areas and accidents. The one-year evaluation is to begin in early 1992. The approximately $8 million cost will be borne by the federal and state transportation departments, General Motors and the American Automobile Association. Surveillance cameras are being installed along a portion of Interstate 4 in the Orlando area to monitor traffic flow and problems like accidents. The data will be fed via satellite to the smart cars' dashboard computers, along with information from traffic spotters in helicopters. Orlando, like other cities, already has the start of smart highways in the form of computerized traffic signals that monitor tieups at intersections. The computer changes traffic lights accordingly. In Europe, an $800 million-plus project called Prometheus is aimed at improving highway and traffic safety and relieving congestion through smart cars, smart highways and computers. In Japan, three similar programs are under way. ``People in this country feel that we are behind not because of technology, but in the institutional framework _ establishing public and private partnerships,'' said Norman. ``That's what this conference is aiming at.''

DOC.HEAD: Principal Expels Bart Simpson
LaserPhoto NY18
DOC.TEXT: Bart Simpson, the spiky-headed cartoon champion of underachievement, has been expelled from an elementary school whose principal says he teaches kids the wrong lesson. Bill Krumnow, principal of Lutz Elementary School in Ballville Township, asked students not to wear T-shirts bearing the likeness of the bug-eyed wisecracking 10-year-old star of the Fox Television cartoon show, ``The Simpsons.'' Krumnow made the announcement, which he maintains is not an outright ban, on Wednesday over the school's public address system after consulting with teachers. At issue is a shirt that boasts, ``Under-achiever and proud of it, man.'' The shirt is part of a line of ``The Simpsons'' family gear. ``To be proud of being an incompetent is a contradiction of what we stand for,'' said Krumnow. ``We strive for excellence and to instill good values in kids.'' Krumnow also said he's no fan of the weekly show, saying it ``teaches the wrong thing to students.'' The response from the show's makers? Don't have a cow, man, as Bart would say. Cool your jets. Antonia Coffman, a spokeswoman for the show, said that the Simpsons aren't meant to set any kind of example. ``We know the family isn't exactly a role model family. We know they're not the brightest family in America. They're not meant to be,'' Coffman said. ``This is satire.'' Cathy Reiter, mother of a Lutz fourth-grader, thinks the flap is senseless. ``They're blowing it way out of proportion. It's only a cartoon,'' she said. ``To me, it's comical.'' She said her daughter, Holly, has several Simpson shirts, including the one that offended Krumnow. Krumnow isn't the first school official to discipline Bart, Coffman told The Blade of Toledo. But he is fast becoming a cult hero anyway, she said. ``We know Bart's a brat,'' she said. ``Bart spelled differently is Brat. He's a holy terror.'' Krumnow doesn't expect Bart's effect on his young fans to last. ``Bart is a big thing right now,'' he said. ``But it's a passing fad.''

DOC.HEAD: Mock Countdown Successful for Columbia
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Discovery's crew spent Saturday packing and preparing for Sunday's landing, astronauts for the space shuttle Columbia successfully completed a simulated countdown for a flight next month. The two-day test culminated with a simulated engine start and cut off five seconds before liftoff of the seven-member crew. NASA has targeted a May 16 launch date for the flight, which will carry a $100 million observatory known as Astro into orbit. Astronaut Samuel T. Durrance, a research scientist at John Hopkins University who may be dropped from the flight because of illness, did not take part in the test. Filling in for him as payload specialist was Kenneth H. Nordsieck, another scientist who has trained as a backup.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Accused of `Appeasement'
DOC.TEXT: In a sign of growing black divisions, a militant group on Saturday accused the African National Congress of ``appeasement'' for agreeing to negotiate with the white-led government. In other developments, police said a black policeman and his father were killed by gunmen, and a police general said the nation's crime rate has reached alarming proportions. Some 3,000 supporters of the radical Pan Africanist Congress, a rival of the larger ANC, gathered in the Atteridgeville township outside Pretoria on Saturday for the funeral of Pan Africanist leader Jeff Masemola. Masemola, who died in a car crash two weeks ago, was freed in October from a life prison term after serving 27 years for sabotage. The Pan Africanists chanted, ``One settler, one bullet!'' a reference to whites, whom they regard as colonialists and believe should be ousted from power by violence if necessary. The vice president of the Pan Africanists, M. Makwetu, in a reference to ANC policies, said Masemola ``had no time for compromise and appeasement.'' ``It is very sad for the ANC to have taken that decision'' to talk to the government, Makwetu said. The ANC, the largest black opposition group, is to hold groundbreaking talks on Wednesday through Friday with President F.W. de Klerk's government. The discussions are designed to clear the way for negotiations on a new constitution that would include blacks. ``Our choice is to fight on,'' said Cunningham Noxukwana, general secreatary of a Pan Africanist-affiliated union organization. ``A sellout is very thick in the air,'' he said of the talks. The Pan Africanist Congress broke away from the African National Congress in the 1950s and disagrees with the ANC on several tactical issues. The Pan Africanists believe blacks should be self-reliant in their struggle for political rights, while the ANC embraces a multiracial approach. Both groups favor a one-man, one-vote system and wage largely ineffective guerrilla campaigns. The ANC also is engaged in a power struggle in the southeastern province of Natal with Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization. Fighting between the two sides has claimed 4,000 black lives in the past four years. Meanwhile, police said five gunmen broke into the house of 24-year-old Constable J.F. Zuma in Mpumalanga outside Durban on Friday night, demanded ammunition, then shot him twice in the chest. Police said Zuma's father, in another room, heard the attack and tried to flee from the house but was also shot and killed. Also, Gen. Jaap Joubert, head of the police Criminal Investigations Division, said crime has reached alarming proportions with almost 1.5 million serious crimes committed last year. On an average day in South Africa, Joubert said, there were 32 murders, 56 rapes, 199 robberies, 160 car thefts and more than 500 cases of house-breaking. The national police force is also experiencing a drain of officers, with an average of 22 a day resigning during the first three months of this year. The government recently announced a pay raise for police in a bid to halt the resignations.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Legal Troubles Continue After Mistrial
DOC.TEXT: The government plans a second bank fraud trial for Rep. Harold Ford, and a prosecutor said Saturday he may try to move the case out of the popular congressman's home district. Ford, 44, went on trial Feb. 12 in U.S. District Court in Memphis and a mistrial was declared Friday when jurors said they were hopelessly deadlocked. U.S. Attorney Hickman Ewing Jr. of Memphis said prosecutors are considering a request for a chance of venue ``so the government can get a fair trial.'' The Democratic congressman was indicted in Knoxville in 1987 and the case was moved to Memphis at his request. Tennessee's only black member of Congress, Ford claimed he was ``judicially kidnapped'' when prosecutors sought his indictment in eastern Tennessee, which is heavily white and Republican. Ford's district in Memphis is 58 percent black and he has avoided any serious challenge for re-election since first elected to Congress in 1974. One of the strongest black politicians in Memphis, Ford was preparing to run for mayor when his indictment sidetracked those plans. He declined to say what effect his continuing legal woes will have on his future political plans. Memphis is 50 percent black but has never elected a black mayor. The city will hold municipal elections next year. Ford is accused of taking political payoffs from former Tennessee bankers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr., who set off the largest banking collapse in the state's history in 1983. The Butchers are serving 20-year prison sentences for bank fraud. A mistrial was also declared for his Ford's codefendants, accountant David Crabtree and lawyers Douglas Beaty and Karl Schledwitz. All three are former Butcher aides. Ewing said prosecutors may ask for a new site for Ford's second trial because of extensive news media coverage surrounding the first one. The congressman held what amounted to daily news conferences throughout the trial, Ewing said, while prosecutors were barred by district court rules from talking about the case. Ford claims his indictment is the work of racist prosecutors who dislike him personally, an allegation the government denies. Shortly after Ford's indictment, a federal judge in Knoxville issued orders telling the defendants not to talk about the case in public. Ford complained that a member of Congress could not be barred from addressing his constituents and an appeals court removed the gag order as it applied to him. Ford was indicted in Knoxville, the government says, because the bank fraud conspiracy he is accused of taking part in was centered there. After the mistrial was declared, Ford said he hoped the government would decide to drop the case. ``What we will do is go now to the Justice Department and let them review this case to see whether or not the government has had its day in court,'' he said. Ford said he regarded the mistrial as a victory. ``This is certainly a big defeat for the government,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Jolts SF Bay Area, Causes Moderate Damage
DOC.TEXT: About 40 homes in the city of Alamo were damaged and a few homes were declared unfit for habitation after two earthquakes rumbled through Northern California, officials said Saturday. Damage included broken glass, toilets knocked off foundations, ruptured water and gas lines and broken furniture, according to San Ramon Valley Fire Department spokesman Mary Raymond. Several homes were deemed uninhabitable by inspectors with the Contra Costa County Building Department after the temblors Friday night, Raymond added. She said follow-up inspections would determine the severity of the damage. Two jolts in Contra Costa County, on the Concord Fault, produced preliminary Richter Scale readings of 4.6 and 3.9, according to the University of California Seismographic Station in Berkeley. The U.S. Geological Survey measured the temblors at magnitudes 4.6 and 4.3. The quakes were centered some 30 miles east of San Francisco, four miles east of Walnut Creek, seismologists reported. The shocks swept cans and bottles off supermarket shelves and knocked out power to thousands of homes in Concord, Danville, Walnut Creek and Alamo, jostling the nerves of residents. The first hit at 9:41 p.m. and another shock hit six minutes later. Several quakes measuring 2.5 and smaller shivered through the area after that. The largest jolts were felt from Vacaville to Marin County to San Francisco. A spokeswoman for the state Office of Emergency Services said the shocks were part of the continuing series shaking the region this month. Tremors of up to 5.5 on the Richter scale were felt in the Bay area on April 6 and April 18. None caused any major damage. The 7.1-magnitude quake that hit the region Oct. 17 claimed 67 lives and caused some $7.1 billion in damage. At the Alamo Safeway, employees closed the store and filled carts with bottled water and batteries to sell at the front door. Their floors were a mess with broken bottles and scattered cans. Karen Allen, Walnut Creek police dispatcher, reported from her post that ``things fell off the shelves behind the console.'' The Bay Area Rapid Transit system was shut down for 24 minutes while crews conducted inspections to ensure the safety of passengers, said spokesman Mike Healy. ``We're in good shape,'' he reported. Brad Thomas, a spokesman for Pacific Gas & Electric Co., reported that the quakes left 1,300 homes in the Concord area without power and scattered outages in other areas. Mild shaking took place at the press box at Candlestick Park where the San Francisco Giants were playing the St. Louis Cardinals, said sportswriter Brian Martin. ``People who have been through them knew what it was. ... It was business as usual,'' Martin said. At six-story Mount Diablo Hospital in Concord, nursing supervisor Mary Bacon said: ``There was a sudden crack and then a rolling that goes on and on. Some of the patients and some of the employees were shook up and were sick to their stomachs.'' The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage in the local area, a 5 considerable damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Flood of Anonymous Claims Leads to Caution
With AM-Colombia-Chaos
DOC.TEXT: Faced with a flood of phone calls and facsimile messages claiming responsibility for terrorist attacks, Colombia's news media are beginning to ignore the messages. The reason is simple _ it is impossible to tell who is really on the other end of the line. Drug traffickers? Police posing as drug traffickers? Leftist guerrillas? Pranskters? Until a few weeks ago, virtually all of Colombia's radio stations and newspapers used the statements without question. No one pointed out the information came from anonymous people and could not be verified. Recently, the country's two leading newspapers, Bogota's El Espectador and El Tiempo, chose not to publish news about some of the anonymous messages. An example of the confusion came after leftist presidential candidate Carlos Pizarro was killed Thursday by an assassin on a Colombian airliner. Within two hours, the anonymous telephone calls started. It was the Medellin cartel, one man said. Another president would be assassinated, he said. On Friday came another facsimile message, also supposedly from the Medellin cartel, to a Bogota radio station, Caracol. It wasn't us, the supposed cartel communique said. It accused the police of killing people and setting off bombs so that the cartel would be blamed. Another example came after a truck bomb in Medellin killed 20 people on April 11. Facsimile statements under the letterhead of the Extraditables, a name assumed by leaders of the Medellin cartel, said the cartel was not responsibile. Recently there have been facsimile and telephone messages from anonymous people claiming to speak for the cartel, saying those statements directly after the April 11 bombing were fakes. ``Somebody has been using us as their public relations office,'' a senior editor at a Bogota newspaper said Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Assures European Community About Costs Of Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 4th pvs, `For example...' to UPDATE with Kohl comments on pace of unification, military status. Pick up 5th pvs, `Kohl expressed...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-European Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Saturday tried to dispel European concerns over the enormous costs of German unification, saying West Germany won't ``stick its hand into the money bag'' of the European Community. At a one-day summit of the 12-member community, Kohl addressed the issue of the hundreds of billions of West German marks it will cost to reunite the two German states created after the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II. ``The Federal Republic of Germany ... does not intend to stick its hand into the money bag of the EC,'' Kohl was quoted as saying by his spokesman, Hans Klein. ``For example, the Mediterranean countries should not suffer as a result of unification,'' Kohl said, according to Klein. At a news conference, Kohl rejected an assertion that he is proceeding too quickly with unification, saying, ``Nothing is rushing forward head over heels.'' Kohl also reaffirmed Bonn's strong commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, rejecting Soviet proposals that a united Germany belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact until a new security system could be formed. At a separate news conference, French President Francois Mitterrand also said a unified Germany must stay in NATO. In an interview with The Irish Times of Dublin, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze suggested a ``non-aligned'' status for the joined German state. Shevardnadze will meet with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and counterparts from France, Britain and the two Germanys in Bonn next Saturday to discuss the international questions of German unification. Kohl expressed his appreciation for the overwhelming support he received from the other leaders for the German unification process, Klein said. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, originally uneasy about the implications of German unification, welcomed Kohl's entire approach, her officials said. ``The prime objective of this council (summit) has been fulfilled,'' said a British government spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The European Community has a clear plan and a scheme for handling it.'' Poorer community members had been uneasy as well. Spain and Portugal, for example, are heavily dependent on EC programs for redistributing Western European wealth. On Thursday, EC Commission President Jacques Delors raised eyebrows among the British by suggesting a small EC fund to help prop up East Germany's nearly collapsed economy. The British were quick to say they were not interested in any such contribution to East Germany. Klein said Kohl made it clear that West Germany was ``not pushing'' for such extra help for the troubled nation. Enormous amounts of money are at stake in unification, which has received the blessing of the EC leaders. Experts estimate it could cost $130 billion to clean up East Germany's polluted environment. About $300 billion will be needed to revamp computers, telecommunications and other forms of electronic information systems. Kohl's government has agreed to exchange East German wages, pensions and small savings into West German marks at a 1-to-1 rate as of July 2, triggering unease in financial markets. Many businessmen and bankers say the planned exchange rate could lead to massive inflation. They think the entire economic venture is taking West Germany into uncharted and potentially dangerous waters. West Germany's finance minister on Saturday reassured West Germans that they will not have to pay higher taxes to finance unification of the Germanys. Kohl is counting on the private businesses already setting up in East Germany to aid in economic unification, and he says other countries should become involved economically as well. ``He urgently called on other (EC) partners to invest in East Germany,'' Klein said. However, the huge head-start enjoyed by the West Germans has already raised concerns they will reap most of the advantages of unification. Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens warned the other leaders that West Germany shouldn't be allowed to have advantages in East Germany that others don't have. ``I believe that everyone will agree ... there shouldn't be any unreasonable advantages, and that, for that reason, the usual supervisory mechanisms have to apply,'' Martens said, according to a written version of his remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Decry Plexiglass Skylights In Historic Covered Bridge
LaserPhoto MR2
DOC.TEXT: A few years ago town selectmen took up the task of repairing the sagging, century-old covered wooden bridge over the Ottauquechee River. The result _ complete with greenish plastic glass windows in the roof _ has townspeople and preservationists aghast. Purists say there was something magical about the darkness in the Lincoln Bridge, built in 1877. ``One old farmer told me he liked the darkness of the bridge because he'd kiss his wife every time they drove through it,'' recalls Harry Francis, owner of the neighboring Lincoln Inn. ``Now I'm cheek to jowl with this tragic atrocity.'' When they assigned the repair task to state engineers, the selectmen suggested that a few skylights might be included. ``It was a safety issue, not just for drivers but for the pedestrians milling about on the bridge,'' said Woodstock Town Manager Phillip Swanson. ``We had tourists from all across the country walking around in the dark.'' But when the bridge reopened last month after the long renovation, there were six pea-green plastic glass skylights installed in a corrugated, baked-enamel roof. ``What bothers me is if you are going to put all of this money into restoring it, why does it have to look like a McDonald's hamburger stand?'' one resident, William McDonald, said at a recent town meeting. ``There is nothing historical about the bridge anymore. It's just a wooden bridge in the same location,'' said Frank Teagle, a Woodstock preservationist. Even town officials concede the plastic skylights aren't quite what they had in mind. ``There are greens and there are greens,'' says Selectman Thomas Debevoise III. The controversy has prompted plenty of finger-pointing. ``It would have made things a lot easier if Mr. Gilbertson had said `No' when the plans came in,'' said Debevoise, a reference to the director of the state Division of Historic Preservation. Eric Gilbertson said he wishes his office had caught the skylights, but they somehow slipped by. Engineer Peter Gratiot, of nearby Pomfret, who has had an office in Woodstock for 35 years, has fought for an all-wood restoration since 1986. He said he mistakenly overlooked the skylights while concentrating on what he called ``the real battle'' _ the fight to keep the bridge authentic from a pure engineering standpoint. Gratiot and members of the National Society for the Preservation of Covered Bridges wanted restoration as the original planner, T. Willis Pratt, would have designed it: free of steel girders and using mostly wood. ``But state engineers are not trained in wood,'' said Gratiot. Now the bridge has both steel supports and the skylights. Swanson, who drives over the bridge every day to work, dismisses the charge that the historical value of the bridge has been damaged. ``It's just as old as it ever was.'' Woodstock, a town of about 3,500, is one of Vermont's leading resort communities, thanks in large part to the efforts of the Rockefeller family, which bought and restored several historic buildings in the village, paid to bury utility lines and took other measures aimed at recreating a 19th-century New England village. The bridge is one of three covered wooden structures in Woodstock. The other two bridges are illuminated by either lattice work or window notches in the walls. In addition to the skylights, the non-wood roof is another sore point. Officials say it is easier to maintain. Francis, McDonald and others are petitioning for another roof. The Board of Selectmen will decide by May 1 whether to allow a group of private citizens to raise enough money _ $20,000 by some estimates _ to install traditional cedar shingles. If the selectmen reject the wood shingle idea, resident Dennis DePaul said he will petition again. ``The quality of life is high in Woodstock because the forbearers of the town had the intelligence and generosity to create beauty,'' he said. ``We are the stewards of that beauty and history. It's important that we hang on to it.''

DOC.HEAD: Tree Grower Charged With Slavery
DOC.TEXT: A commercial tree grower who allegedly imprisoned migrant workers, forced them to work 16-hour days and shaved their heads has surrendered to authorities. Edwin Ives, 53, turned himself in Friday in Los Angeles after three of his foremen and an alleged alien smuggler were arrested earlier in the day at his 49-acre Ventura County ranch. A federal complaint charges Ives with keeping about 150 undocumented workers, some for as long as nine months, during a three-year period at the ranch, where eucalyptus trees and other ornamental plants are grown. Among the accusations: that the workers even had to pay for the haircuts when their heads were shaved. Ives denied the allegations through his lawyer. The defendants and Ives' company, Griffith-Ives Co., are charged with conspiracy to deprive people of their civil rights, assistant U.S. attorney Crol Gillam said. They could also be indicted under the Fair Labor Standards Act and for alleged violations of the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act, a federal prosecutor said. According to the complaint, the aliens were smuggled from Mexico and promised good wages. But when they arrived they found they could not leave the ranch, which is surrounded by a 7-foot chain-link and plastic glass fence. As many as 150 aliens may have been held as long as nine months, Ms. Gillam said. They were forced to work 16-hour days six days a week. They were paid wages, but had to pay for food, clothing, toilet paper, tools and bedding, she said. They were also charged a smuggling fee, according to prosecutors. The allegations were reported to authorities by a worker who said he escaped the ranch earlier this month by crawling under a fence. ``It was slave labor,'' said Fernando Maldonado, 49. ``We could not leave. We realized we had entered the mouth of the wolf.'' Ives was freed on $150,000 bail, Ms. Gillam said. Ives' attorney, Robert Talcott, said the charges were unfounded. ``As the proceedings unfold, the facts will reveal that none of the allegations of peonage and involuntary servitude and the like have an iota of support,'' Talcott said.

DOC.HEAD: Churches, Shrines Reopen But May Close Again
DOC.TEXT: Christian leaders reopened shrines and churches in the Holy Land Saturday after a 24-hour closure but threatened to shut their doors again if Jewish settlers remain in the Christian quarter of the Old City. The 150 Jewish settlers moved into a four-building complex owned by the Greek Orthodox Church in the Christian quarter on April 11. The move interrupted Easter celebrations and provoked demonstrations by angry clerics and Palestinians, both Christian and Moslem. Last week, after repeated denials, the Israeli government admitted it had contributed $1.8 million to help establish the settlement, provoking outrage in Israel and abroad. Israel's Supreme Court has ordered the settlers to leave by Tuesday, but said 20 settler guards and maintenance staff could remain pending a final ruling on the tenancy dispute. On Friday, leaders of nine major Christian sects closed their churches for a day after the Greek Orthodox Church locked the gates to the church of the Holy Sepulcher, where Catholics say Jesus was crucified and buried. It was believed to be the first time the church of the Holy Sepulcher closed its doors in 800 years. Church leaders plan more protests unless all of the settlers leave. ``If the situation continues to be critical, we will have to close churches again, hold more special prayers and appeal to the international community to pressure Israel to evict the settlers,'' said Lufti Laham, the Melchite Catholic bishop. They did not say when they might hold more protests. ``The closure of churches and houses of worship in Jerusalem, Bethlehem, Nazereth and the Galilee was never done, not even in the darkest conditions. This shows how serious we are,'' said George Hintilian, secretary to Armenian patriarch Torkum Manoogian. Latin Patriarch Michel Sabbah said on Vatican radio that the church protest aimed was aimed at showing the world that in Jerusalem, ``the non-Jewish population is in danger.'' ``The Palestinian population has been left without any protection,'' Sabbah said. ``And among the Palestinians are also Christians.'' Palestinians see the Jewish presence in the predominantly Arab neighborhood as part of a campaign to push them out. The Old City, captured from Jordan during the 1967 Middle East war, is divided into jealously guarded sectors _ the Christian quarter, the Jewish quarter, the Armenian quarter and the Moslem quarter. The Jewish settlers say they intend to leave peacefully but only after the Israeli Independence Day, which begins Sunday night and ends Monday night. On Friday, Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek accused caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government of acting in an ``underhanded'' manner. Kollek, mayor of Jerusalem since 1965, predicted that if the right-wing premier stays in power, tensions will increase in the Holy City instead of leading Israel to peace talks with the Arabs. Shamir is trying to form a coalition government following Labor leader Shimon Peres' failure to do so. The last Labor-Likud coalition collapsed March 15 over differences toward U.S.-backed peace proposals with the Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: EC Leaders Approve Plan For Political Union by 1993
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to ADD location of summit. Pickup 3rd graf `West German...'; SUBS final grafs 12-14 with 11 grafs to ADD details, background.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XDUB1,3
DOC.TEXT: European Community leaders adopted a plan Saturday to achieve political union by January 1993, but Britain warned they will run into trouble when they get to the details. ``I think the Community today firmly and decisively and categorically committed itself to political union,'' declared Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, host of the 12-nation summit at the medieval Dublin Castle. ``I think the whole process is now inevitable,'' hee said. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, backed by French President Francois Mitterrand, pressed for a speedy merger, arguing it went hand-in-hand with rapidly approaching German unification. ``Francois Mitterand and I, and others, want to see the European Community strengthened,'' Kohl told a news conference. ``That in plain words means abandoning certain national competencies.'' But British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in characteristically blunt language, predicted the process of European union would founder as soon as the member states faced the prospect of having to cede national sovereignty and accept collective decision-making. ``There is quite a lot of rhetoric and far too little nitty-gritty,'' Mrs. Thatcher told reporters at the end of the one-day summit. ``Clearly they do not quite know what political union means. It astounds me.'' The leaders agreed to instruct their foreign ministers to draw up a draft for political union by the next summit in June, with the aim of calling an inter-governmental conference on the subject in December. It will parallel a conference already scheduled at which governments are to discuss a single currency and central banking system for Europe. A summit declaration said both conferences should finish their work before the end of 1992. Again, Mrs. Thatcher was skeptical. While she thought the leaders could come up with an agreed formula for political union by the end of 1992, she predicted that the work on economic and monetary union would run into ``much fiercer debate.'' Asked why she endorsed the summit's call for political, economic and monetary union, she replied that she was confident it would all come to much less than her European partners now imagined. ``I would have thought two years should be enough to know certainly on political union which way you should go. Economic and monetary union is a much, much more complicated thing and will give rise to much longer consideration and much fiercer debate,'' she said. Mrs. Thatcher was not alone in her stance toward political union. Community officials said several other countries including Denmark, Luxembourg and Portugal also had reservations. German unification was what prompted Ireland, as current president of the Community, to set up a summit ahead of schedule. But a Franco-German call on April 15 for political union by 1992 shifted the focus of Saturday's gathering toward European merger. Kohl and Mitterrand believe union is urgently needed to preserve European stability in the face of upheaval in Eastern Europe. Kohl assured his partners that Germany had no intention of ``sticking its hand into the moneybag of the European Community'' to finance the huge cost of unifying Germany. The summit endorsed a plan to incorporate East Germany into the Community when it is united with West Germany. The program will temporarily exempt the economically backward former communist country from the Community's stringent enviromental standards and restrictions on state subsidies to industry. It also promises that moves to incorporate East Germany will begin July 2 when the two German currencies merge. The summit agreed to reach association agreements with the other new democracies of Eastern Europe, but there was no question of them joining the wealthy trading bloc soon. The summit, taking place in neutral Ireland, did not go into defense questions in detail, but Kohl repeatedly assured the other leaders that a united Germany wanted to remain in the 16-nation North Atlantic treaty Organization. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, in an interview with the irish Times published Saturday, reiterated that a united Germany in NATO was unacceptable to Moscow. He called for a ``militariliy non-aligned'' Germany and suggested it could belong to both NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Although Western officials have rejected the idea, Shevardnadze said it was ``food for thought.'' Analysts say a political merger of the EC countries probably would include a common foreign and security policy. Some predict the EC countries eventually will become a kind of United States of Europe but still maintain their distinct languages and cultures. The European Community members are Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Singh: Trade Treaties Won't Be Changed Under U.S. `Hit List' Threat
DOC.TEXT: India, cited by the United States for unfair trade practices, said Saturday it would never negotiate trade treaties under threat, United News of India reported. The news agency quoted Prime Minister V.P. Singh as saying India was trying to strengthen its economy and could not ignore its social priorities because of the American action Friday. Singh commented at a news conference during a visit to the northern Indian city of Lucknow. Senior businessmen in New Delhi sharply criticized the United States for keeping India on the ``hit list'' of countries targeted for unfair trade practices. President Bush left India as the only country still cited under the 1988 U.S. Omnibus Trade Act, which allows U.S. tariffs of up to 100 percent on goods imported from a nation judged an unfair trader. Bush removed Japan and Brazil from the list. ``The decision is unfortunate and an avoidable development,'' said Viren J. Shah, president of the Associated Chamber of Commerce and Industries. Hari Shankar Singhania, chairman of the Indian section of the Indo-U.S. Joint Business Council, said any attempt to ``force'' India to change its economic policies under threat of retaliatory action was ``against all tenets of multilateralism.'' India has steadfastly refused to modify its restrictive trade policies, designed to protect domestic industries by limiting foreign investment and imposing high import duties. Ever since India first was targeted, the government has maintained the U.S. trade law unfairly penalized developing nations. Shah said the United States and India could have shown greater flexibility in dealing with the problem. He encouraged India to continue its economic liberalization and urged Washington to look ``sympathetically'' on India. Under former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, India began a program of relative economic liberalization, opening up to limited foreign investment. But Singh's government has shown few signs of continuing those policies. Relatively few foreign products are seen in the world's second most populous nation. Last year, foreign firms invested only $200 million in India. India's 880 million people have a per capita annual income of only $290, but there is a growing consumer market among the 25 percent of the population reckoned as middle-class. America's trade deficit with India is only a fraction of the one it has with Japan. India has a trade surplus of about $850 million with the United States. For the fiscal year that ended in March, Japan's surplus with the United States was $42.8 billion, down 12.7 percent from $49 billion in the previous fiscal year. The United States is India's largest trading partner. India's exports consist primarily of clothing, diamonds, crude oil and cashew nuts. Its chief American imports are fertilizers, chemicals, electronic parts and industrial materials.

DOC.HEAD: Police Clash With Skinheads; Five Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with 150 arrested; Picks up last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Police used tear gas and dogs Saturday against a group of about 50 skinheads who barricaded themselves in a restaurant in the southwestern city of Nordhausen, East Germany's official news service said. Five of the skinheads, a term for radical right-wing youths with closely shaved heads, were injured in the clash, and 150 were arrested, the ADN news service said. About 200 youths had gathered in the restaurant and all but about 50 obeyed police orders to leave, ADN said. It said the youths hurled rocks and bottles at police, who responded by firing tear gas and loosing police dogs. Most of the youths were West Germans in town for a rock concert, it said. Nordhausen is about 125 miles southwest of Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Partisan differences were put aside when Alderman Robert Shaw came to the rescue of a colleague and political foe who suddenly began choking at lunch. ``I was really gasping for breath,'' Alderman Bernard L. Stone said after Friday's mishap. ``He really saved my life.'' Shaw was dining with Stone and Aldermen Fred Roti and Thomas Cullerton at a restaurant across the street from City Hall, when Stone choked on a sandwich. ``I had to really reach around him but I was able to get my hands around his chest and apply the Heimlich maneuver,'' Shaw said. The rescue technique involves the application of a sudden, sharp pressure to the abdomen below the rib cage. Stone is a white Democrat-turned-Republican representing a ward along the city's north border. He was among the City Council bloc that long blocked programs of the city's first black mayor, Harold Washington, who was elected in 1983 and died in office in 1987. Shaw is a black Democrat and represents a ward on the city's southern border. Stone said that there was a touch of chaos when he got into trouble. ``Freddy started telling everyone else what to do. Thomas Cullerton tried to put his arms around me, but he is too small. I am gasping and Shaw stood up and saved me.'' Stone ``is a big guy, so I had to really reach around,'' Shaw said with a laugh. ``I would do that for anyone _ even if they didn't support Harold Washington,'' Shaw said.

DOC.HEAD: East German Farmers Protest Food Imports from West
DOC.TEXT: East German farmers parked tractors and trucks at highway border crossings and tied up traffic Saturday to dramatize their fears about West German food imports. East German farmers have become increasingly worried that they will lose their livelihoods to West German agribusinesses. In East Berlin, about 500 demonstrators took to the streets to protest government sales of houses and prime plots of land to former members of the ousted Communist government. The demonstrators demanded that the new, democratically elected government investigate the matter. The farm protest backed up traffic for an hour on the highway between the southern East German city of Plauen and the West German border town of Hof, police said. East Germany's official news agency ADN also said farmers used their vehicles to block border crossings at Blosenberg, Gassenreuth and Heinersgruen, which border the West German state of Bavaria. It gave no figures on the number of farmers involved. East German Agriculture Minister Peter Pollack has said he would seek to control Western food imports and promote local products. Many Western goods already are flooding across the border even though the German states have not completed agreement on how they will merge their economies. A full economic union is planned for July 2.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Pilot Rests After Marrow Transfusion
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet pilot who got radiation poisoning from his efforts to stem the Chernobyl nuclear disaster was described as happy and relieved Saturday, as the wait began to see if new bone marrow will save his life. Anatoly Grishchenko, 53, who suffers from a pre-leukemia condition, has been honored in the Soviet Union for his work to put a cement cap on the reactor in the Ukraine. He received the marrow in a relatively simple, eight-hour procedure completed at 2:40 a.m. Saturday, said Susan Edmonds, spokeswoman for the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center. ``He is stable. He handled the transfusion very well and there are no problems,'' she said. ``The next step is to see if the marrow will grow.'' Grishchenko will remain in a sterile hospital room for 35 to 40 days as the new marrow slowly re-establishes his immune system, Edmonds said. Doctors should know in about three weeks whether the transplant was a success. ``His condition will probably stay the same for another week, two weeks,'' Edmonds said. Meanwhile, he will rest, undergo some mild physical therapy, get transfusions of blood or blood components, and be monitored closely for signs of infection or marrow rejection. The marrow, about one quart, was taken from the hip of a 42-year-old Frenchwoman, in a procedure similar to drawing blood, early Friday in Besancon, France. The donor asked to remain anonymous, hospital officials said. Hutchinson's Dr. Patricia Stewart rushed the marrow, which can lose its effectiveness after 24 hours, to Seattle aboard a commercial flight. Within two hours, doctors began transfusing it through a catheter into Grishchenko's chest, one day after the fourth anniversary of the Chernobyl disaster. Marrow is a substance inside the bones which produces blood cells. In transplants like Grishchenko's, marrow transfused into the bloodstream makes its way to the interior of the bones. Grishchenko, a ``very warm, nice man,'' chatted with his wife, Galina, and physicians during the procedure, Edmonds said. ``It was very clear there was a lot of happiness and relief the marrow was here,'' she said. In September 1988, Grishchenko was found to have the pre-leukemia condition, typified by low counts of blood platelets needed for clotting and of white blood cells that fight infection and disease. He arrived in Seattle April 11 and has undergone radiation treatment and chemotherapy to prepare for the marrow transplant. Such treatment often leaves a patient too weak for doctors to try a second transplant if the first one doesn't take, Edmonds said. Grishchenko, who has two sons and a granddaughter, has up to a 75 percent chance of survival without a recurrence of the condition for five years, Edmonds said. The Hutchinson Center, which pioneered bone-marrow transplants, has done about 5,000 over the past decade and now averages about one a day, she said. Grishchenko is the first Chernobyl victim to receive medical care in the United States. The transplant was arranged by his friend Cap Parlier, light helicopter testing and evaluation director for McDonnell Douglas Corp. The donor was found in a nine-country search. Grishchenko made five flights over Chernobyl in the four days following the April 26, 1986, explosion and fire. He flew through hot, intensely radioactive gases spewing from the plant to survey the damage and to dump tons of sand and wet concrete onto the wreckage. He was issued lead-lined clothing and his copters were equipped with extra lead shielding. But he was treated soon after for radiation sickness. According to official figures, 31 people were killed in the Chernobyl disaster. Unofficial reports said at least 250 died, and recent estimates are that at least 4 million people were endangered by the radiation. The blast scattered radioactive cesium, strontium and plutonium isotopes across much of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia and sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in December Coup Arrested
DOC.TEXT: The government said Saturday it has captured a key leader of last December's coup attempt. Lt. Col. Marcelino Malajacan, arrested Friday evening, is accused of having been a major tactician in the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt against President Corazon Aquino. Authorities had offered a $45,500 reward for Malajacan, who was arrested at a house in suburban Quezon City. Military officials said he was unarmed and did not resist. The December coup, considered to be the most serious of six armed attempts to oust Mrs. Aquino, left at least 113 people dead and more than 600 others injured. Military vice chief of staff Maj. Gen. Rodolfo Biazon, at a news conference, called Malajacan's arrest a major setback for the mutineers. But he said they remained a threat.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Draft Treaty For United Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with details on treaty, clarify Kohl's position on Polish border. Pickup 11th graf, ``East Germany's...' ^By JOAN FISCHER
DOC.TEXT: Seeking to protect itself from a huge new neighbor, Poland has drafted a border treaty that it wants a unified Germany to sign, officials said Saturday. The proposal is the latest effort by Poland to obtain guarantees that a united Germany will not seek to reclaim former German lands now part of Poland. Polish officials late Friday gave copies of the draft to diplomats from both Germanys, Poland's government news service PAP said. PAP said the draft treaty confirms the present Polish-German border and states that the frontier has an ``international legally binding character.'' In Bonn, government spokesman Martin Erdmann confirmed Saturday that West Germany received a copy of the proposal but he declined to comment. Part of Nazi Germany was ceded to Poland after World War II to make up for an even larger part of Poland absorbed by the Soviet Union. Poland's borders are expected to be a key part of superpower talks on the future of a unified Germany. Foreign ministers from the four World War II allies that divided Germany _ the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain _ are to meet May 5 in Bonn to discuss unification with envoys from the two Germanys. At the insistence of Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the six nations have agreed to allow Poland to participate when the negotiations address its borders. Although West Germany in 1972 signed an agreement recognizing Poland's present borders, that agreement would not necessarily be legally binding on a united Germany. West German ultraconservatives have seized on unification as an opportunity to scrap the agreement. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who faces elections in December, caused an international uproar earlier this year by hedging on the border issue. Opponents accused him of courting the ultraconservative vote. But in March the West German parliament, with Kohl's backing, passed a resolution unequivocally confirming Poland's borders. It also said that a united Germany should sign a border treaty accepting the borders. East Germany's new democratic government already has said it would press for full recognition of Poland's present boundaries. The issue probably will be discussed when East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere meets in Moscow on Sunday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Soviets also have demanded that Poland's present borders be guaranteed. In another development, West Germany's finance minister on Saturday reassured West Germans that they will not have to pay higher taxes to finance the costly unification of the Germanys. Theo Waigel also urged East Germans to be more realistic in their demands on West Germany. ``What we need now is an effective economy in West Germany that can shoulder things without false recipes, such as tax increases and supplementary payments,'' Waigel said in an interview with the Hamburg-based Welt am Sonntag newspaper. The newspaper provided news media with an advance copy of the interview, which will appear in its Sunday edition. Both Germanys have agreed to merge their economies and social institutions by July 2, but they have differed on the best way to finance it. West Germany has agreed to East Germany's demand that the nearly worthless East German mark be traded at a 1-1 rate for the powerful West German mark. The West Germans are proposing that the rate apply to salaries and pensions but only to savings accounts of 4,000 marks ($2,300) or less. Personal savings above 4,000 marks would be traded at a 2-1 rate. East Germany is pressing for a higher ceiling on personal savings and wants to retain subsidies for rent, energy and public services. In the interview, however, Waigel said that the Bonn offer represented the limits of what the West German government could afford. ``East German politicians must become more aware of realities,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Chastises Man Accused of Rape for Calling Himself the `Victim'
DOC.TEXT: A judge sentenced a man to 24 years in prison for the rape of a Yale University student in her dormitory room in 1988, but first blasted the man for calling himself the victim. Jesse R. Reed, 37, of New York City, was defiant Friday as Judge Richard Damiani sentenced him on two counts of first-degree sexual assault. Reed pleaded guilty to those charges in February under the Alford doctrine, meaning he denied guilt but conceded that prosecutors had enough evidence to convict him. His fingerprints were found on two empty liquor bottles at the crime scene. At his first sentencing hearing April 20, the victim came to New Haven Superior Court with several friends and, choking back tears, read a statement to the judge. The victim was 18 at the time of the fall 1988 attack. Reed then sought to withdraw his guilty plea, saying he hadn't understood what he was doing in making the plea and that he was unhappy with his lawyer. Damiani postponed sentencing for a week to review his questioning of Reed, and said on Friday he had found it satisfactory. Reed told the court on Friday that as a black man, he was being treated unfairly by a white judicial system. ``I tried very hard to trust in the judicial system,'' Reed said, ``but I feel more or less like I'm the victim.'' That sent Damiani into a tirade, which Reed tried several times to interrupt. ``You're not being sentenced for your race, you're being sentenced for one of the most vicious sexual assaults I've ever seen,'' Damiani said. The victim, who did not attend Friday's sentencing, came from Canada and had been at Yale just six weeks when she awoke to find a man standing in her room. He raped her twice, ransacked the room and defecated in the hallway. Assistant State's Attorney Mary Elizabeth Baran said she would not add to remarks made at the earlier hearing, when she said the victim's ``once happy, challenging world was just shattered by this man who has done nothing in his life but commit crimes and hurt people.'' Reed was serving time at Riker's Island jail in New York City when he was tracked via his fingerprints and arrested in the New Haven case.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Guts Government Building Complex in Grenada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPATES throughout with quotes, details, background; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A huge fire gutted the Finance Ministry, the Treasury, the Printing Office and a post office before authorities brought the blaze under control early Saturday. No injuries were reported, but officials said government paychecks and important documents were destroyed. The cause of the blaze was not known. Prime Minister Nicholas Braithwaite said the fire in the 19th-century complex in the capital's historic waterfront district caused about $3 million in damage. But that figure will rise by millions of dollars, he said, when the loss of equipment, postal orders and packages is factored in. Hundreds of paychecks with retroactive salary increases for civil servants were destroyed. They were to have been distributed Monday. The fire, which may have started in the post office, was reported at 10:45 p.m. Friday and brought under control about 2 a.m., officials said. The blaze destroyed the buildings' interiors, leaving only their brick shells standing. St. George's has twice been ravaged by fire, in 1771 and again in 1775. Wooden buildings were banned after that. Firefighters said they were able to save the audit department in the Treasury building, although it suffered extensive water damage. Braithwaite, speaking after an emergency meeting with his Cabinet and the chief of police, said the affected government agencies would temporarily operate out of offices provided by three private firms and out of his own official residence. He urged other private businesses to provide temporary office space. Braithwaite said he would ask Britain, the United States and other countries for financial aid and help investigating the fire. Grenada became independent from Britain in 1974. Braithwaite was sworn in as prime minister March 16. He replaced Ben Jones, who was named to complete the term of office of Herbert Blaize, who died in December. Blaize came to power after the U.S.-led invasion of Grenada in October 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Tammy Faye Bakker Rips Made-for-TV Movie
DOC.TEXT: Tammy Faye Bakker is flattered that Bernadette Peters portrays her in a made-for-TV movie, but the wife of convicted televangelist Jim Bakker says she won't be watching ``Fall from Grace.'' ``It's trash, nothing but trash, and you can quote me on that,'' Mrs. Bakker told The Muskegon Chronicle from her home in Orlando, Fla. The interview appears in the paper Sunday. ``I'm not going to watch it,'' she said of the movie scheduled to air Sunday night on NBC. ``I'm not going to get upset about something that doesn't deserve getting upset about.'' NBC has promoted ``Fall from Grace'' as the true story behind the rise and fall of the PTL Club television ministry founded by the Bakkers. But Mrs. Bakker, who read the script earlier this month, told the Chronicle that it focuses more on the intimate details of their marriage than their ministry. ``How do they know what happened in our bedroom?'' Tammy Faye said. ``It's just crazy. We have a wonderful marriage. Jim is a loving, giving, kind man, and I don't care what the movie showed, he never turned me down sexually.'' Bakker was born in Muskegon and lived there until he graduated from high school in 1959. He was convicted last year of fraud and conspiracy charges and is serving a 45-year sentence at a federal prison in Rochester, Minn. Bakker declined the Chronicle's request for an interview. Kevin Spacey plays Jim Bakker. Mrs. Bakker said she was pleased that actress-singer Peters was cast to play her and wondered which gospel songs she would sing.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Abortion a National `Tragedy
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates throughout and includes new police crowd estimate of 200,000
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told a ``Rally for Life'' Saturday that ``the widespread prevalence of abortion in America is a tragedy'' but omitted any mention of his once-outspoken support for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion. The president, who spent the morning fishing on the Potomac River, spoke by telephone hookup to tens of thousands of people who gathered on the Mall by the Washington Monument just a few blocks from the White House. Bush spoke for just two and a half minutes. He offered encouragement to abortion opponents without referring to proposals to amend the Constitution or to the possibility the Supreme Court would one day reverse its 1973 decision upholding abortion. ``Like you, I realize that the widespread prevalence of abortion in America is a tragedy, not only in terms of lives destroyed but because it so fundamentally contradicts the values we as Americans hold dear,'' Bush said. The rally was designed to demonstrate strength by an anti-abortion movement that has suffered recent political setbacks and to reverse the impression that anti-abortion forces have been in political decline. U.S. Park Police estimated the crowd at 200,000 people at 4 p.m., up from an earlier estimate of 60,000 before the really began. Speakers at the rally claimed larger numbers. The National Right to Life Committee, the rally's sponsors, had hoped for a crowd that rivaled in size an abortion-rights gathering here that was attended by an estimated 300,000 people a year ago, and outstrip the 75,000 who attended a January anti-abortion march in Washington. The crowd mostly filled the grassy area surrounding the Washington Monument. As springtime heat sent temperatures approaching 90 degrees, some sought shade from surrounding trees and others made their own out of anti-abortion placards. Lines to refreshment stands stretched 80 yards, and the line to a water fountain ran 30 yards. Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said her side's political and election successes in a number of states _ and not Saturday's crowd _ are the accurate measure of public opinion on abortion. In his remarks, Bush also made no direct reference to political divisions within his own Republican party over abortion, or to efforts by abortion opponents to win abortion restrictions in state legislatures. A year ago Bush emphasized to a similar gathering that he supported a constitutional amendment to reverse the Supreme Court's landmark Roe vs. Wade decision that effectively gave women the right to abortion on demand. Bush pointed to adoption as the appropriate alternative to abortion. ``Our mission must be to help more and more Americans make the right choice, the choice for life,'' Bush said. ``One day your lifesaving message will have reached and influenced every American. And until then, continue to work for the day when respect for human life is sacrosanct and beyond question. I know from your devotion and selflessness that this day cannot be far away,'' Bush said. Vice President Dan Quayle appeared before the group and called legal abortion ``a terrible wound which for almost two decades has torn at our country's heart.'' Quayle also did not directly refer to efforts to reverse the Supreme Court decision or to amend the Constitution. But he asserted that ``a great majority stands together against the terrible reality of unlimited abortion on demand.'' ``The pro-life movement is the humanitarian movement of our time,'' Quayle said. Entertainment began early in the day, long before the afternoon program of Catholic cardinals, television evangelists, country and gospel singers, and anti-abortion leaders. ``I'm here because I feel real strongly that babies have a right to live,'' said country singer Terri Gibbs, who brought her 6-month-old son David. Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., known for his sponsorship of anti-abortion riders to government appropriations bills, called the other side's ``pro-choice'' slogan a fraud. He said: ``The answer to that is, `Madam, if you're pregnant, you have a baby! You have a baby!' Nobody should have the choice to kill an innocent human life once it's begun.'' The rally was held at a time when their side has sustained a series of losses in elections and in state capitals in the wake of the Supreme Court's Webster decision last summer. While permitting greater state limits on abortions, the decision gave new political vitality to supporters of abortion rights, who depicted the debate as an attempt to take away a woman's right to make her own reproductive decisions. ``At least part of the motive is to try to reverse what we feel is a misperception about the strength of the Right to Life movement _ and also, to give some politicians who might be wavering a little bit of backbone,'' said Gary L. Bauer, president of the Family Research Council and a White House aide to former President Reagan. ``It looks as though the court is going to ultimately reverse Roe,'' said Dr. J.C. Willke, president of the National Right to Life Committee, referring to the Supreme Court's 17-year-old Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortions. ``Our job now is to go to the 50 states ... and convince them to pass laws to protect unborn babies.'' Bush's remarks were his second by telephone hookup to anti-abortion crowds in little more than three months. On the Jan. 22 anniversary of the 1973 decision upholding abortions, Bush pledged ``this president stands with you on this issue of life.'' But in a demonstration of the political conflict Republicans feel over abortion, Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, on that same day made clear ``there is room within the party for varying points of view on this issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Instability Worse Than Ever After Candidate's Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 10th graf, ``The media...' to UPDATE with announcement of new M-19 presidential candidate. Pickup pvs 11th graf, ``Traffickers have...'' Edits to Trim
DOC.TEXT: Less than a month before elections, the assassination of a third presidential candidate has pushed Colombia to the brink of political chaos. After the shooting of candidate Carlos Pizarro in a jetliner Thursday, the country's largest newspaper implored the government to ``do something, for the love of God.'' Addressing President Virgilio Barco, the El Tiempo editorial said: ``In your hands, and only in your hands, is the power to avoid the country's dissolution.'' ``The gravest aspect of Colombia's bloodletting is that the government has no idea how to even slow it,'' said a member of a regional human rights committee based in Medellin, the cocaine capital. He declined to be identified because he was afraid someone might be angered by his statements and kill him. Four of his predecessors have been assassinated. In recent interviews, Pizarro, the candidate for the leftist April 19 Movement, or M-19, admitted he was afraid. But he said his desire to lead Colombia was greater than his fear of assassins' bullets. A gunman on a suicide mission shot Pizarro aboard a Colombian jetliner after it took off from Bogota's airport. Pizarro's bodyguards shot and killed the assassin. Two other presidential candidates had already been assassinated during the campaign for May 27 elections. Sen. Luis Carlos Galan of the ruling Liberal Party was gunned down last August at a political rally in Bogota, and Bernardo Jaramillo of the leftist Patriotic Union Party was killed last month at the Bogota airport. Authorities blamed the assassinations on drug traffickers. The media, citing security sources, reported that traffickers were the main suspects in Pizarro's killing as well. But the Medellin cartel denied involvement, and no government official has yet said who was responsible for Pizarro's assassination. On Saturday Antonio Navarro, a longtime guerrilla leader of the April 19 Movement, announced he would take Pizarro's place as candidate for president. Traffickers have carried out a terrorist campaign that has killed nearly 300 Colombians in the past nine months in an effort to halt the government's campaign to capture and extradite drug barons to the United States. Bombings by the Medellin cartel have caused millions of dollars in property damage, led to the militarization of Medellin and other cities and shattered the nerves of citizens. Pizarro's death appears to have pushed the country to its limit. For the first time, leading politicians suggested the government itself might be compromised by the killing. Several politicians and analysts said an armed assassin could not have been aboard a jetliner without the complicity of government and airport security personnel. Former president Alfonso Lopez said the assassinations of three candidates indicated that Colombia's armed forces must be reorganized. Lopez, of the Liberal Party, was president from 1974 to 1978. Official investigations have shown that certain members of the armed forces are allied with drug traffickers and the country's right-wing death squads. One of the country's presidential candidates, Alvaro Gomez, said Friday that Barco should name a three-man council to run Colombia's security forces to avoid a military coup. He suggested that Barco had lost control over the armed forces. Gomez made the proposal in a written statement given to the press. ``Never has there been such a great and pathetic image of anarchy,'' said Gomez, a presidential candidate of the Conservative Party. Barco, of the Liberal Party, rejected Gomez's suggestion of a triumvirate, saying the armed forces would be reorganized only if necessary. Continuing to focus on a military solution to Colombia's problems, Barco said late Friday he would double the size of a 3,000-man anti-terrorist police unit. The unit achieved its greatest success against drug traffickers when it killed a Medellin cartel leader, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in a gunfight last December. Both Barco and his party's presidential candidate, Cesar Gaviria, have linked Colombia's salvation to constitutional reform. Through such reforms they hope to reform the corrupted Congress, strengthen the judicial system and provide more political representation for minority parties. According to recent polls, Gaviria is heavily favored to win the presidential elections.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Withdraws Early Recommendation on Proposed Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has withdrawn Justice Department recommendations for strict sentencing guidelines for white collar criminals, a department spokesman said Saturday. The spokesman, David Runkel, said the decision to take back the department's comments to the U.S. Sentencing Commission came after White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray told the department the White House wanted to give the proposals further study. The commission last fall had unveiled proposals that would require federal judges to impose stiff mandatory fines on companies convicted of polluting, bilking the government and other so-called white collar crimes. The Washington Post, in its Saturday editions, said that in a Feb. 26 letter to the sentencing commission, Deputy Attorney General Donald Ayer expressed the department's ``strong support'' for the guidelines. But Thornburgh, who according to the newspaper was unaware of Ayer's letter, told him to withdraw his letter, which Ayer did on March 16. Thornburgh's decision followed an intense lobbying campaign at the White House by defense contractors, oil companies and other major businesses who claimed the sentencing guidelines could mean a ``corporate death penalty'' for some firms, the Post said. However, Runkel said the department's criminal division had given the sentencing commission its view of the proposals before the Justice recommendations ``went through the entire review process.'' ``I think Boyden said, `Hey, we haven't had a chance to take a look at these and wanted to be part of the process,''' Runkel said. ``They were later withdrawn so that the attorney general and White House could take a look at them. That is being done in the attorney general's office now,'' the spokesman said. The department would file new recommendations in the near future, Runkel said. ``I can't say at this time what the review is going to come up with, whether the recommendations that go back will be the same or stronger or not,'' he added. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said Saturday that he was ``concerned that the Department of Justice has surrendered so easily to pressure from the White House and big business to go soft on white collar crime.'' The department's withdrawal ``is undermining the battle against corporate crime at the very time when stronger law enforcement is most needed to deal with the multibillion-dollar corporate scandals plaguing our economy and country,'' Kennedy said in a statement. The commission, created by Congress in 1984, last fall proposed an escalating range of financial penalties, with the severity becoming progressively steeper depending on the extent of high-level management involvement, prior convictions, bribery of public officials, defrauding of charitable organizations and risks to national security. Runkel said the withdrawal will not hurt the commission's deliberations, since it does not have a quorum of members yet to make final decisions. He said the review does not represent a change of heart on Thornburgh's part. ``The attorney general has a record of going after white collar crime, has decried weak sentences and applauded strong sentences,'' Runkel said.

DOC.HEAD: Slain Candidate, Former Guerrilla Commander Pizarro Buried
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 8th graf `The 38-year-old...' to UPDATE with another M-19 leader declaring candidacy for president. Pickup 9th graf `The funeral...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Colombia-Chaos
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people marched through Bogota's streets Saturday to mourn Carlos Pizarro, the slain guerrilla leader whose presidential campaign ended with an assassin's bullets. Under a steady rain, about 20,000 people trudged two miles, chanting and waving placards appealing for peace in their war-torn country. ``Not one man, not one woman, not one peso for the war,'' said one of scores of placards. ``I did my duty for you, Colombia, and they killed me,'' people chanted as they headed for the cemetery on the outskirts of the downtown area. In a nationally televised address late Friday night, President Virgilio Barco urged Colombians not to react to Pizarro's murder with more violence. Barco said he was doubling the size of a police anti-terrorist strike force that now numbers about 3,000. The strike force has been in Medellin, Colombia's cocaine capital, in a search for the head of the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar. Pizarro was just starting his presidential campaign when a gunman shot him Thursday aboard a domestic airliner. The 38-year-old candidate had been a leftist guerrilla for 16 years and rose to be commander of a rebel organization, the April 19 Movement, known as the M-19. Antonio Navarro, a longtime M-19 guerrilla leader, announced Saturday that he will run for president in place of Pizarro. The funeral was held in the Primatial Cathedral on the city's huge Bolivar Plaza. The cathedral is only about 200 feet from the site of Colombia's Palace of Justice, which was raided by the M-19 in 1985. More than 100 people were killed in the raid, and a fire destroyed the interior of the building. The palace was torn down last year. Pizarro was commander of the M-19 at the time of the guerrilla takeover, but he did not take part in the raid. Two other presidential candidates besides Pizarro have been assassinated during the campaign for May 27 elections. Sen.
