Luis Carlos Galan of the ruling Liberal Party was gunned down last August at a political rally in Bogota, and Bernardo Jaramillo of the leftist Patriotic Union Party was killed last month at the city's airport.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Author Of `Kiss Me Kate' also said She Created Girl Scout Cookie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf to restore first reference to Samuel Spewack.
DOC.TEXT: Bella Spewack, who co-wrote the book to the musical ``Kiss Me Kate'' and was instrumental in getting the Girl Scouts into selling cookies, has died. She was 91. Mrs. Spewack died Friday night in her New York apartment of natural causes, said a family friend who asked not to be identified. ``I am responsible for that heinous, heinous thing, the Girl Scout Cookie,'' Mrs. Spewack once said. She said she came up with the idea that if the scouts tried to sell cookies at a flower show attended by actresses, the resulting publicity could launch cookie-selling nationwide. Mrs. Spewack, however, never claimed to have baked any cookies herself. Born Bella Cohen in Bucharest, Romania, in 1899, she moved to the United States, where she attended high school. She worked as a journalist on several New York papers and as a theatrical press agent before she married Samuel Spewack, in 1922. The couple became a successful playwriting and screenplay-writing team, winning a Tony Award in 1949 for ``Kiss Me Kate.'' Cole Porter wrote the music for the show, which became one of the most popular musical comedies of the modern stage. Mrs. Spewack and her husband also were praised for their collaboration on ``Boy Meets Girl,'' a 1935 lampoon of the Hollywood mystique. Other plays included ``Clear All Wires,'' 1932, and ``Woman Bites Dog,'' 1946. They also collaborated on the screenplays for 20 films, including ``Clear All Wires,'' 1933; ``Rendezvous,'' 1935, and ``My Favorite Wife,'' 1940. Samuel Spewack died in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Man Believed To Be `Ski Mask Rapist' Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf to DELETE defendant's name.
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested a man they believe is the ``ski mask rapist'' responsible for up to 30 rapes in Dallas since early 1985. Gilbert H. Escobedo, a 38-year-old co-owner of an auto detail shop, was arrested Tuesday night as he allegedly tried to break into a woman's apartment in north Dallas, police said Friday. ``We believe the intent was to break in and rape her,'' Detective S.K. Hatchel said. ``We think it was an attempted sexual assault.'' Escobedo was being held on four charges of investigation of aggravated sexual assault, a burglary charge and an attempted burglary charge. Police said Escobedo is a convicted burglar who has served time in Texas prisons off and on since 1972. New evidence has linked him to 17 rapes, and police said they believe he committed more than a dozen more. ``We had circumstantial evidence in the past, but up until this week we were unable to make a good case,'' said Detective R.E. Rommel. ``He had been to the penitentiary for burglary, and he knew what he was doing. We've been watching him for several years.'' Rommel said Escobedo is also a suspect in a rape case in suburban Richardson and police in a Southern California city where Escobedo recently visited want to talk to him. The rapist, who wore a ski mask or hood, was known for his burglary skills. He began drawing public attention several years ago as police realized one man seemed to be responsible for a string of rapes. Most victims, police said, were women in their early 20s who were awakened and raped by a man who had broken in through a door or window. The series of rapes began in 1985 soon after Escobedo was released from prison where he was serving a term for a burglary conviction, officers said. The last attack attributed to the serial rapist was March 10, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting in East Beirut, But Cease-Fire Observed North of City
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces skirmished Saturday with automatic rifles in east Beirut but observed a 21-hour cease-fire in the Christian hinterland to the north. In East Beirut, two boys playing in an empty lot were killed when a mine exploded. The victims were 8 and 10 years old, said a police spokesman, speaking anonymously in line with standing rules. The incident occurred in the district of Ein Rummaneh, held by rebellious Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. Police said a man was killed and another was wounded in an exchange of sniper fire across east Beirut between Aoun's troops and militiamen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese forces. The battle for control of the Christian enclave has killed 919 people and wounded 2,442 since it broke out Jan. 30. Aoun, former interim prime minister, does not recognize Christian President Elias Hrawi, whose government was set up last November under a peace plan aimed at ending a 15-year-old civil war. Aoun has said he opposes the plan because it lacks a fixed timetable for the withdrawal of Syria's estimated 40,000 troops. Meanwhile, a truce was reported holding on the eastern flank of the Kesrouan province. Civilians flooded the contested resorts of Kleiat and Daraya to check on their damaged houses. Kleiat, once a posh spot known for its restaurants and night clubs, has been turned into a no-man's land in savage fighting between Aoun's 19,000 troops and Geagea's 6,000-strong militia. Geagea's fighters control the western half of the village, while Aoun's men control its northern edges and direct their fire onto its main square. Geagea's militiamen also control a nearby hill overlooking the adjacent resort of Daraya, in Aoun's area of influence. Nearly all of Daraya's 12,000 residents have fled. Hardly 200 of Kleiat's 20,000 residents remain, living in basements and underground shelters. The police spokesman said most of the villagers who had stayed in the region up until now were taking advantage of the cease-fire to flee. ``They appear convinced that all-out clashes will break out again,'' the spokesman said. The cease-fire, which went into effect at mid-morning, was mediated by Maronite Catholic monk Bulos Naaman. He is a member of a three-man independent mediation committee that sponsored at least 20 cease-fire calls during the three-month confrontation. Both Aoun and Geagea are members of the Maronite sect, the largest Christian community. It has dominated political life, the army command and the judiciary since Lebanon's independence from France in 1943. The power struggle, the worst intra-Christian confrontation in the civil war, has inflicted damage estimated at $1 billion. It has forced 40 percent of the enclave's original population of 1 million to seek refuge in safer areas in Lebanon and abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher: God Did Better with Eve
With AM-European Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Divided over where their drive toward political union is leading them, European Community leaders on Saturday went back to basics: the Garden of Eden. At a 12-nation summit in the Irish capital, the Western European leaders adopted a plan Saturday to achieve political union by January 1993, without saying precisely what that meant. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who expressed reservations about the plan, offered a long list of consequences political union would not produce, such as abolishing Britain's monarchy or getting rid of national parliaments. Jacques Delors, the Community's pro-union chief executive, finally got fed up. ``If I set out to try to define what a man isn't, I don't know whether Adam would have been created,'' he commented sardonically at a post-summit news conference. Mrs. Thatcher, Europe's first woman prime minister, retorted: ``My reply is, God did it better on his second thoughts when he created Eve.''

DOC.HEAD: Hope Glimmers In Battered Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS number of radio stations to 11 sted 91 in 18th graf, `Mariano Valle...' Pickup pvs 19th graf, `The confiscated...' ^By CANDICE HUGHES
DOC.TEXT: From the dust and desperation of a dump occupied by squatters to the cool, white elegance of a rich man's home, hope glimmered in the first days of Nicaragua's new government. The optimism seemed almost improbable given the rocky start of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's conservative administration and the dire straits of this battered nation. The 60-year-old widow took office Wednesday, confronting deep divisions in her United National Opposition coalition and thousands of Contra rebels who refused to lay down their arms. Government ministries and agencies were in disarray, some barely functioning and most under only nominal control of her coalition, known as UNO. No one in UNO would say whether the outgoing Sandinistas had left enough money in the treasury to meet Monday's state payroll. In addition, the value of the national currency was slashed in half Friday and the prices of staples such as rice, meat and oil soared. But Nicaraguans voted for change _ for peace and a measure of prosperity _ when they voted against the leftist Sandinistas in the Feb. 25 elections and their expectations were not so quickly dashed. In the bustling Eastern Market, a bastion of free-enterprise spirit, merchants shrugged off the latest plunge in the cordoba as a necessary evil. ``They had to do something to stabilize things,'' said appliance salesman Carlos Brinones. ``The value was unrealistic. If they can just keep it stable for six months....'' The cordoba has ridden a roller coaster for years, propelled by inflation that hit a staggering 36,000 percent in 1988. ``Business is business,'' Candida Salgado, a Sandinista, said from the shade of her clothing shop. ``It keeps going somehow; it has its own magnetic force.'' Mrs. Salgado believes the Sandinistas were good for Nicaragua because they freed it from dictatorship. Now she says it is up to Mrs. Chamorro to repair the damage inflicted by war with the U.S.-backed Contras and years of U.S. economic sanctions. From market to mansions, Nicaraguans expect the new government to reap millions in foreign aid and trade. ``Dona Violeta could open a new path, she could take us another step forward,'' Mrs. Salgado said as she sat chatting with her sister from Miami. Nellie Campos, 52, ventured back for a visit after 10 years of exile because of Mrs. Chamorro's election. She is thinking of staying for good. ``Business is always business,'' she said, echoing her sister. ``There are always possibilities.'' For Mrs. Campos, the decision to return hinges on whether she can reclaim her shop and house. They were taken over under a ``law of absence'' that discouraged Sandinista critics from returning from abroad. The property of thousands of others was confiscated outright. For them, Mrs. Chamorro's election means a shot at recuperating some of their losses. Mariano Valle, for example, lost 11 radio stations. He and other pre-revolutionary broadcasters expect the new government to follow through on its promise to review the confiscations. The confiscated stations became part of a government-run network which the Sandinistas handed over to party faithful after losing the election. ``It was supposedly `privatization,''' Valle scoffed during an interview at his elegant home. The dismantling of the radio network was part of a post-election rush aimed at ensuring that Sandinista loyalists wouldn't leave power empty-handed. Thousands got homes occupied under the ``law of absence'' or confiscated by the government. Car dealers say their inventories were cleaned out for Sandinista ``going away'' gifts at government expense. ``We have sold 60 cars since the election,'' said Idalia Gonzalez, a saleswoman at the Hyundai dealership. ``We normally sell six a month.'' The greedy scramble sparked a land rush among the left-out poor, who have been squatting on vacant lots since the election. Expectations are basic in the ruined economy. ``We hope the new government will help us get building materials,'' Rosalina Garcia Calero, 52, said as fellow squatters at the dump burned trash and marked off 30-foot-by-45-foot plots with rocks, bits of debris and crooked sticks. ``The old one never did.'' Mrs. Garcia was one of more than 150 home-hungry people who have occupied the dump in the past few days. ``Things aren't going to change overnight,'' said 45-year-old Damian Gutierrez, who lives in one room with 14 relatives and sees the dump land as his only hope for a home of his own. ``But they will change.''

DOC.HEAD: Direct Talks By Angolan Government, Rebels Disclosed
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of Angola's Marxist government and the UNITA rebels have held their first face-to-face talks in 10 months, the Portuguese government disclosed Saturday. In talks Tuesday and Wednesday outside Lisbon, the two sides fixed a secret calendar for future negotiations aimed at ending their 15-year civil war in the former Portuguese colony, the government said. The meetings in Evora, 90 miles east of Lisbon, were the first direct contacts since a truce brokered by Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko last June 22 collapsed within weeks. The rebels, who control of large areas of central and southern Angola, have been fighting to share power since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Portugal's secretary of state for foreign affairs and cooperation, Jose Manuel Durao Barroso, told a news conference the two sides had signed a document, the contents of which were not disclosed. The time and place of future meetings between the two sides would not be revealed, he said. The Portuguese government was given a copy of the document, the Portuguese news agency Lusa said. Confusion arose after the June truce when the two sides announced differing interpretations of the pact. Durao Barroso said the two sides still had many differences to resolve. ``Frankly, their positions are still very far apart,'' he said. ``The path to peace is Angola is still a long one.'' UNITA's foreign affairs secretary, Toni da Costa Fernandes, told reporters: ``The peace process will succeed this time _ we are satisfied.'' Angolan Ambassador to Lisbon Rui Mingas also expressed satisfaction with the results of the talks. UNITA's delegation in Evora was headed by Lisbon representative Gen. Paulo Mango. Mingas declined to reveal the identities of the government negotiators. Neither government nor rebel officials attending a separate gathering in Lisbon would reveal details of the talks. Meanwhile, UNITA on Saturday claimed it had sabotaged electricity supplies to the Angolan capital, Luanda. Rebel statements and the state news agency ANGOP also reported bitter clashes continuing this week in the field. UNITA is a Portuguese acronym for National Union for the Total Indendence of Angola.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Probing Payments by Government AIDS Research Lab
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 8th graf, ``Mrs. Salhuddin xxx and deletes 9th graf, ``Attempts to xxx to delete nongermane reference to attorney who could not be reached
DOC.TEXT: AIDS researcher Robert Gallo is set to testify Monday before a House panel investigating payments made by his government laboratory to a firm with ties to a fellow National Institutes of Health scientist, a congressional source said Saturday. Gallo, a leading AIDS researcher, will appear before the House Energy and Commerce Committee along with officials of the General Accounting Office, which has conducted an 18-month investigation into hundreds of thousands of dollars paid to the firm, Pan-Data Systems. A committee source who spoke only on condition of anonymity said there is evidence that shareholders in Pan-Data, a contracting firm based in a Maryland suburb of Washington, have included a close NIH associate of Gallo, Indian-born research scientist Syed Zaki Salhuddin, and his wife, Firoza. Published reports of ties to the company on the part of the Salhuddins first appeared last year and Gallo was quoted at the time in The Washington Post as saying he did not know of any relationship until 1988. The Chicago Tribune in its Sunday editions said the congressional inquiry has found evidence that rare and valuable viruses, including the one that causes AIDS, have found there way from Gallo's laboratory and been sold to universities, private companies and other government agencies. Some numbered vials of virus that had belonged to the laboratory appear to have been sold, but the committee is still attempting to establish conclusively who did the selling and under what circumstances, according to the committee source. Syed Zaki Salhuddin's brother, S.M. Salhuddin, said the researcher was in Belgium attending a scientific conference. Mrs. Salhuddin, reached by telephone Saturday, declined to say whether she was a part owner of the contracting firm. The committee source said evidence that the Salhuddins have been shareholders in the company include Small Business Administration records. The source said committee investigators and the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, had found payments of as much as $800,000 a year to Pan-Data by Gallo's laboratory. Records show the firm was paid for a variety of reasons, ranging from research assistance to providing office supplies to the laboratory, according to the committee source. Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman John Dingell, D-Mich., is seeking to determine why NIH did not inquire more deeply into the relationship between the laboratory and Pan-Data, the source said. Gallo has co-authored more than 60 scientific articles with Salhuddin and has described him as ``the world's leading researcher in the area of blood cell cultures.''

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope's Scientific Instruments Remain on Hold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with unsuccessful efforts to restore high-speed antennas. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `The overnight...
DOC.TEXT: The Hubble Space Telescope's electronic system was back in operation Saturday, but despite daylong efforts its high-speed antennas remained down and its science instruments on hold. Meanwhile, Discovery's five astronauts prepared to land at 9:49 a.m. EDT Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., amid some concern that high wind might force postponement the landing until Monday or Tuesday. Air Force forecasters said winds at the desert base were expected to be close to the limit for a safe shuttle landing Sunday. ``It's time to pack up our camping gear and get ready to come home,'' said flight director Wayne Hale. Early Saturday, the $1.5 billion telescope was sent ``health and safety'' instructions to operate on its own. A day earlier, the electronic instruments had automatically shut down when they sensed trouble with one of two high-gain antennas, and when opening the lens cover made the telescope move. The high-gain antennas send data back to Earth at high speed. ``We are continuing to remain in good communication with the telescope,'' said Dave Drachlis of the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. He said systems other than the antenna were running properly. Ground controllers at Goddard tried moving the good high-gain antenna, but noticed the other antenna also was turning. ``They ... basically stopped the process and scratched their heads for a bit,'' Drachlis said. Jean Olivier, a deputy project manager for Hubble, said various options are being considered to aim the good antenna without moving the bad one. If computer programs must be adapted to get data from just one antenna, ``it will be somewhat of a hit.'' Neither Olivier nor Mike Harrington, director of orbital verification, ventured to say how much that might affect scientific returns. The problems with the antennas have delayed calibration tests that ground controllers must conduct on the telescopes five scientific instruments. Drachlis said delaying those tests was not a major problem. The overnight commands put the instruments on hold, the state in which they will spend much of their time awaiting signals to wake up and study the heavens. Engineers can send commands to the telescope via its secondary low-gain antennas. But that system, which is considerably slower, isn't useful for scientific data. In a news conference from Discovery, astronaut Bruce McCandless said he's not surprised ``a very complex system like this may have a few minor bugs to be worked out.'' But neither the bugs nor the complexity seemed to have dampened the astronauts' enthusiasm. ``It's hard to go somewhere and find someone who has never heard of the Hubble Space Telescope,'' said pilot Charles Bolden. ``It makes little kids' eyes light up. It makes little kids want to learn how to add and subtract and study science. ``And that's extremely gratifying to know that you're part of a mission that seems to have excited the nation as well as the world about something.'' The astronauts made some last-minute observations of Earth, about 380 miles below. The record-high shuttle altitude was needed to put the telescope in its proper orbit far above Earth's distorting atmosphere. ``From what we've seen so far, compared to some of our previous flights ... it looks a little bit better than we remember, maybe a little less smoke in some places,'' said Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver. NASA expects to release its first test image from the telescope late this week at the earliest, later than planned because of the antenna problems. Scientific data will follow in a month or two. Astronomers expect to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. The universe is believed to have been created about 15 billion years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Toxic Waste Cleanups Could Add to Stench of $325 Billion S&L Bailout
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf, ``Officials at xxx to CORRECT Resolution Trust Fund to Resolution Trust Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators cleaning up bankrupt savings and loans are finding they've inherited another unexpected and expensive mess: real estate contaminated by hazardous waste. Officials at the Resolution Trust Corp., which has taken over more than 400 insolvent S&Ls, say some of the failed financial institutions had foreclosed on polluted property. Recent court rulings have found that financial institutions are potentially liable for cleaning up such property under the 1980 Superfund law. By extension, that could put the RTC on the hook. The RTC doesn't know yet how many of its more than 30,000 real estate parcels are contaminated, but agency spokesman Stephen J. Katsanos says, ``I'm confident there are sites in our inventory that ... need some cleanup.'' The RTC, already faced with an estimated $325 billion price tag for its S&L bailout, thinks the Environmental Protection Agency's Superfund should foot the bill on any failed S&L property cleanups. ``The taxpayer is going to be paying for it one way or another ... but if it comes out of the RTC then it reduces the amount of money available to protect deposits,'' Katsanos said. A bigger problem than the actual cleanup cost is the cloud of uncertainty cast over the RTC's portfolio. Pollution problems aside, the agency has had great difficulty selling S&L assets when it turns over a failed institution to a new owner, and the potential for an environmental expense is just one more risk discouraging the purchase of assets in large blocks. Not only do buyers have to worry about evaluating real estate owned by an S&L, they have to worry about environmental problems at properties pledged as collateral for loans that may later turn sour. Other agencies, including the Small Business Administration and the Farmers Home Administration, also are wrestling with polluted properties. Sally Narey, SBA general counsel, estimated the agency has wound up with about 150 cases of contamination _ and there could be more. Not only does the SBA face a possible problem when it forecloses on a delinquent loan it has guaranteed, it could face liability from other programs in which it provides operating advice to businesses. ``We just don't know what's out there that we haven't uncovered yet,'' she said. A bank or S&L, as private enterprises, can simply steer clear of making loans to high-risk businesses, but the SBA, as a government agency, is caught in the middle. ``It's a difficult situation. Our mission is to make loans to small businesses that can't get loans elsewhere,'' Narey said. A variety of legislation introduced in Congress aims to address the problem both for the agencies and for financial institutions. Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, the senior Republican on the Senate Banking Committee, would provide immunity to federal banking agencies as well as lenders for environmental problems they only inherited, not created. ``My sense is this is a much bigger problem than a lot of people think it is. There are more examples all the time,'' Garn said. Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., has offered a bill applying only to government agencies, while earlier this month Rep. John J. LaFalce, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Small Business Committee, introduced legislation that would exempt only lenders. Another proposal by Rep. Curt Weldon, R-Pa., would exempt lenders only if they paid for an environmental audit to determine before taking over a property if it is contaminated. The EPA and private environmental groups are opposing the bills as unnecessary. The Superfund law already provides some protection to lenders who only have a security interest in a property and no role in its management. The problem, from banks' perspective, is that they often in effect become managers of a property after they foreclose. Even before foreclosure, a lender will sometimes participate in management in an effort to steer a borrower out of trouble. EPA enforcement attorney Glenn Unterberger said cases of potential lender liability vary so widely that it is better to let the courts judge each on the facts rather than trying to write a blanket rule to cover all situations. Moreover, he added, ``EPA is making some reasoned decisions about when it's reasonable to pursue lending institutions.'' Attorney Donald Strait of the Natural Resources Defense Council said he fears providing greater protection for lenders could result in windfall profits at the taxpayers' expense. ``All of a sudden, a bank which took over a site which was worth very little would have a much more valuable site because it was cleaned up with taxpayers' money. I don't think banks should get that windfall,'' Strait said. Sponsors of the bills say they are willing to write them to prevent such profit. And they argue that without the legislation businesses face a credit crunch, particularly high-risk businesses such as gasoline stations and dry cleaners. Forcing banks to pay for environmental studies before they accept property as collateral is no solution either, said Thomas Greco of the American Bankers Association. ``The lowest level of investigation will probably cost $2,000 or $3,000. These things can rapidly escalate to $10,000, $20,000 or $25,000, and even then there's no assurance the bank will be protected,'' Greco said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agents Arrests Shrimpers on Violations of Endangered Species Act
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents have arrested a captain and two crew members for allegedly violating federal law after they were caught with an endangered Kemp's ridley sea turtle. The turtle was tethered to the men's boat when the Coast Guard made a routine inspection in the Gulf of Mexico, authorities said. Inspectors also caught the three men trawling for shrimp on Tuesday with no turtle excluder devices attached to their nets, the Coast Guard said. The fishermen were arrested Friday at a dock in the Clear Lake area, officials said. Hung Van Tran, 37, master of the shrimp boat; Capt. Paul Le; and crewmen Quang Duc Nguyen, 34, and Binh Van Nguyen, 33, are charged with illegal possession of a sea turtle and aiding and abetting in the illegal possession of a sea turtle, violations of the federal Endangered Species Act. Each carries a penalty of up to a year in prison and a $100,000 fine. Investigators said charges of failure to use excluder devices may be filed next week against the three. They were released on their own recognizance. Shrimpers last fall protested the requirement they use the devices, saying up to 30 percent of their catch was lost because of the devices. Since the law went into effect, several shrimpers have been fined for not using them.

DOC.HEAD: Audit Find Seniors Program Riddled With Costly Mismanagement
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf, ``On at least xxx to show that this was an internal audit
DOC.TEXT: One-third of the projects in a $1.6 billion elderly housing program are in or near financial ruin, with bloated loans and lousy management to blame, according to auditors who say the government will have little choice but to foot the bill. On at least two occasions, prominent Republican political consultants swayed senior Department of Housing and Urban Development officials to overrule field deputies and approve loans for projects in the troubled Retirement Service Center program, the internal audit says. The study details anew favoritism and myriad management problems at HUD during the Reagan administration tenure of Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. It also suggests the pricetag for that mismanagement is rising, with no end in sight, as millions of dollars in loans insured by the government go sour. ``There is a high probability that as more recently approved (retirement centers) proceed through their processing stages, additional projects will become troubled or go into default,'' the auditors concluded in the new report, obtained by The Associated Press through the Freedom of Information Act. And the money lost and wasted in many cases went to projects that catered not to low- and moderate-income people but for developments featuring fountain-filled lobbies, plush dining rooms, swimming pools _ and rents in excess of $2,000 a month. It would take an income of at least $25,000 a year to live in many of the centers, while the median annual income for the over-65 population is roughly $15,000. As in other HUD programs in which private lenders were allowed to underwrite HUD-insured mortgages, the audit found lenders were too generous in their appraisals and thus approved excessive mortgages. Such bloated loans bring lenders higher fees. They also result in higher rents because of the cash flow needed to pay the mortgage, and the high rents in turn contribute to the unusually high vacancy rate in such projects, the auditors said, ultimately causing cash crunches that trigger defaults. HUD Secretary Jack Kemp suspended the program last July after a limited audit in the Chicago area first touched on its problems, finding bad or shaky loans totaling $119 million. Kemp has yet to decide whether to revive the program; the auditors said it would need a total overhaul and cited ``ample justification'' to kill it. In the report's nationwide review of the program, auditors said 62 of 190 Retirement Service Centers _ or nearly 33 percent _ either had defaulted or were financially troubled. The mortgages for the 62 facilities total $599 million _ nearly 40 percent of the $1.6 billion spent on the program. HUD is liable for at least 85 percent and in some cases 100 percent of the loans should they default. The $599 million figure was from loan data through last October. Preliminary results of a follow-up review that includes more recent data paint an even bleaker picture, a HUD official said Friday. The auditors told Kemp he needs to develop a program to sell the centers that are coming under HUD's control because of defaults. The report said that in at least 17 cases HUD field offices and the private lenders ignored reports in which HUD economists said local housing markets would not sustain the projects. Fifteen of those projects are now in default or severe financial trouble. The auditors also questioned 10 cases in which officials at HUD headquarters overruled field office rejections of project proposals. In most cases, no documentation could be found to support the reversals, the report said. At least two of those involved political favoritism, the audit said. In one case, the developer of a project rejected by HUD officials in San Francisco because of a saturated market paid $30,000 to GOP consultant Lou Kitchin, who worked for both the Reagan and Bush presidential campaigns. Kitchin met with senior HUD officials in Washington, including top Pierce deputy Deborah Gore Dean, and won approval for the $13.2 million project. That project, the Woodcrest Retirement Service Center in Escondido, is surviving because of the default of a nearby HUD-insured center, the audit said. In the second case, Robert Weinberger, a Republican consultant and the nephew of former Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger, persuaded HUD headquarters officials to overrule local officials and approve a $3.7 million HUD-insured mortgage for the Rosewood Estate development in Roseville, Minn. The audit refers to the consultants but does not name them. But the role of Kitchin and Weinberger in the projects surfaced last year during investigations of influence-peddling at the agency. Many of the management shortfalls cited by the auditors included seemingly routine tasks. The report said HUD failed to require status reports from the private lenders, had few written guidelines for program management, did not coordinate headquarters decisions with appropriate field offices and never bothered to assess the potential risks of the program or whether it would result in affordable housing.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Challenger Recovering From Stabbing
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leader Oskar Lafontaine was moved out of intensive care Saturday, three days after he was stabbed in the neck with a butcher knife, his spokeswoman said. A deranged woman who hid the knife in a bouquet of flowers stabbed the 46-year-old leader during a campaign rally Wednesday in Cologne. The woman detained after the stabbing, 42-year-old Adelheid Streidel, told police she tried to kill Lafontaine to get into the news, officials said. She has been sent to a psychiatric clinic. Lafontaine initially was in critical condition due to massive blood loss. By Saturday he had recovered sufficiently to be moved from intensive care to a regular ward at the University Clinic in Cologne, Lafontaine spokeswoman Maria Zimmermann said. Lafontaine, a member of the Social Democrats and governor of Saarland state, is Chancellor Helmut Kohl's main rival in the Dec. 2 elections.

DOC.HEAD: Searchers Find Missing Airplane; Apparently No Survivors Among Six Aboard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with rescuers finding three bodies before being driven from moutain by an avalance. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Aboard were...
DOC.TEXT: A light plane carrying a Sweet Adelines women's singing quartet crashed into the side of a snow-covered mountain, apparently killing all six people aboard, authorities said Saturday. A TV news helicopter crew spotted the wreckage in the Rocky Mountains Saturday morning, about 15 miles northeast of Aspen in Pitkin County, said a Lake County Sheriff's Department dispatcher who refused to give her name. There apparently were no survivors of the Friday crash, she said. Searchers hampered by winter weather found three bodies and managed to flag their locations before an avalanche drove crews from the mountain for the day, the dispatcher said. Deputy Calvin Dawe said the wreckage was found in an avalanche-prone area. The single-engine Piper Cherokee had left Salt Lake City about 6 a.m. Friday, en route to Colorado Springs, and was reported overdue about noon. Aboard were four women and two men, including the pilot. They were en route to a regional competition of the Sweet Adelines organization, an international group that promotes barbershop-quartet-style, four-part-harmony singing for women. Fourteen choruses from six Western states were scheduled to complete. Dr. Jayne Clark, leader of the Mountain Jubilee Chorus of Salt Lake City, confirmed that a Sweet Adelines quartet was aboard the plane that vanished but declined to release their names. The search was launched Friday after a satellite and airplanes picked up signals from an emergency locator transmitter apparently high in the Rocky Mountains between Aspen and Leadville, said Michael Kendrick, a spokesman for the Pitkin County sheriff's office. The search was called off at midnight and resumed after sunrise, with a foot of fresh snow covering the target area. Temperatures were in the low 30s, said John Yudnich, a sheriff's department dispatcher. Search conditions _ snow in the upper elevations to rain lower down _ were ``crummy to mediocre,'' Kendrick said. Ground crews equipped with a tracked snow plow were unable to find anything. While contest organizers announced the plane was missing Friday night, Utah singers were ushered into the basement to pray. Sweet Adelines is an international non-profit organization of women based in Tulsa, Okla. It was founded in 1947 to uphold the tradition of barbershop-style, four-part harmony singing. Sweet Adelines has more than 34,000 members in 10 nations.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Mourns Its War Dead
LaserPhoto JRL3
DOC.TEXT: Israel lowered flags to half staff, lit torches and paid silent tribute Saturday to those who have fallen in battle for the Jewish state. A siren's minute-long wail halted traffic Saturday night. Pedestrians and motorists observed a moment of silence, standing at attention to remember Israeli soldiers who fell in five wars with Arab neighbors. Once the final echoes of the siren faded, President Chaim Herzog lit a torch at the Western Wall in the Old City, officially starting the mourning period, which ends Tuesday in this nation of 4.4 million people. The military counts 16,951 dead in the five wars and in guerrilla attacks, including 785 in the 1967 Middle East War when Israel captured the West Bank and Gaza Strip. In Israel's last war, the 1982 invasion of Lebanon and three-year occupation, 1,183 soldiers lost their lives. In the Gaza Strip, the army imposed a curfew from late Saturday night until Tuesday morning, confining more that 700,000 Palestinians to their homes to prevent possible violence. In Israel, bars, restaurants and theaters were closed for the observances. As the sun set, television broadcast stories of slain soldiers and the radio played sad traditional folk songs. At the Western Wall, the holiest site in Judaism, uniformed soldiers saluted as Herzog took his place. The president bowed his head while a trumpet played. ``We the living, promise you, the victim of hatred between brothers, we promise that we will not rest until this country deserves your memory,'' he said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who is also acting as defense minister, wrote a letter to bereaved families. Almost 20,000 Israelis have lost a family member in battle. ``Those who have fallen order us to go forward,'' Shamir said. ``We must make every effort towards peace while at the same time safeguarding our own interests and survival.'' A two-minute siren will mark the start of memorial services in 40 military ceremonies Sunday. The mourning period ends Tuesday with a torch-lighting ceremony at the Mount Herzl cemetery in Jerusalem, where many soldiers and pioneers are buried. The ceremony signals the start of Independence Day celebrations.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITS a0593 to fix category code.
Reagan Urges Free Elections in Cuba
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT that speech carried on radio sted TV. Pick up 2nd graf pvs, `Test yourself...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Carter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Basking in the adulation of anti-communist exiles, former President Reagan on Saturday called for free elections and democratic reforms in Cuba in a speech Fidel Castro could have heard in his living room. ``Test yourself in a vote, Mr. Castro. Let the voices of the Cuban people be heard,'' Reagan said in an address broadcast live to Cuba on the U.S.-funded Radio Marti network. ``In the sanctity of the secret polling both, the voice of freedom triumphs,'' he added. Reagan's 30-minute speech to a predominantly Cuban audience of about 10,000 in Miami's Orange Bowl capped a 3{-hour rally attended by dozens of other officials. Among them were Cuban-born U.S. Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, R-Fla., and President Bush's son Jeb. Many Cuban leaders credit Reagan with beginning a pro-democracy avalanche that may eventually bury Castro and allow the return of thousands of exiles. ``I believe we will soon be singing to liberty and independence in Cuba,'' said Jorge Mas Canosa, chairman of the Cuban American National Foundation and an early supporter of the 5-year-old Radio Marti program. Canosa said the rally and speech was the first event broadcast live to Cuba via Radio Marti. Foundation spokeswoman Marilyn Kalusin said Reagan spoke free of charge. Reagan praised both Radio Marti and the new TV Marti network as instrumental in building grassroots opposition to Castro. ``This is an authentic breakthrough in U.S. information programs because it is television that hold such promise and potential: The power of pictures, the visual images of freedom that are sweeping the world,'' said Reagan. ``They will see the Berlin Wall coming down, the last speech of Romania's dictator, the Soviet citizens massing by the thousands in front of the Kremlin in support of broader democracy in the Soviet Union.'' The Cuban government has jammed the TV Marti signal since its first broadcast March 27. Earlier this month, Radio Marti was also jammed for first time since it went on the air. Both the radio and television stations are named after 19th century Cuban independence hero Jose Marti. ``We can understand why Fidel Castro is so hysterical in his denunications of TV Marti,'' said Reagan, who wore a traditional Cuban guayabera, an open-collared shirt. ``What is he afraid of? He is afraid of the truth.'' The crowd interrupted Reagan several times with applause, and waved Cuban flags. Cuban and U.S. flags were marched into the stadium by the Brigade 2506, a group of Cuban exiles who launched the unsuccessful Bay of Pigs invasion of their homeland in 1961. ``I look forward to the day that this gathering will be held in free Cuba and I know that day will come, and soon,'' said Reagan. He also called on the Soviet Union to cut off its massive aid to Cuba. ``I hope it won't be too much longer before the Soviet Union joins Eastern Europe in redefining its relationship with Cuba,'' he said. ``Maintaining their economic umbilical cord to Castro _ the world's most vehement critic of Soviet-style reforms _ is anachronistic behavior in today's world.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes, Two Others Found After IRA Terror Campaign Reported
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded and two others were found Saturday after authorities warned of a heightened IRA terror campaign. No injuries were reported in the bombing, which came a day after a booby-trapped car exploded and killed a building contractor threatened by the Irish Republican Army. Security patrols and road blocks have been increased in Belfast and across the province since police headquarters warned Thursday night that intelligence reports indicated the IRA was planning a new offensive. The IRA is waging a campaign to drive the British out of the province and unite it with the Irish Republic. A bomb attached to a lamppost in Lisburn, 10 miles south of Belfast, exploded while police and troops evacuated the area following a warning that a 200-pound bomb had been left there. One woman was treated for shock. Later, army bomb disposal experts defused a bomb attached to a gas cylinder in the back of a car in the area. Patrols stopped an airport bus in Templepatrick, Country Antrim, seized a bomb and arrested an unidentified woman, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. The bus was en route from central Belfast to Aldergrove Airport. A police spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British practice, would give no further details and would not say what prompted patrols to stop the bus. The airport is 15 miles west of Belfast, and Templepatrick is five miles from the airport. On the outskirts of Strabane, 60 miles northwest of Belfast, two mortars were fired at the permanent border security post on the route to Lifford in County Donegal. Only one of the mortars, fired from the back of a van parked in a filling station, exploded. Damage to the heavily fortified post was not reported to be serious. None of the soldiers on duty was injured but an 18-year-old woman was taken to a hospital suffering from shock. There were no immediate claims of responsibility. On Friday, a booby-trap bomb killed builder Kenneth Graham as he drove to work in Kilkeel, County Down. A similar bomb exploded prematurely under a car in County Londonderry and a third was defused in County Tyrone, police said. The IRA had warned Graham's company to stop construction work at police and military installations in the province, according to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Graham was the 20th person to die in political and sectarian violence in the province this year.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Government Defends New Tax But Said To Be Considering Review
DOC.TEXT: A member of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet on Saturday defended the unpopular tax that set off a riot last month, but reports said the government was thinking about amending it. The local per capita tax, which went into effect April 1 and replaced a property tax, seriously undermined support for Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party. The Conservatives are expected to fare badly in local council elections across the country Thursday because of hostility toward the tax. The Times of London, which often backs the Conservatives, quoted unidentified sources at the prime minister's office as saying legislation to amend the new tax could be introduced later this year. On Saturday, however, Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley defended the tax, whose revenues are to help fund local councils' spending. Ridley's comments were described by The Sunday Correspondent newspaper as an indication of disarray in the Thatcher government over ``the attempt to repackage the poll tax.'' The government calls the tax a community charge. But the opposition socialist Labor Party and others have dubbed it the poll tax after a similar per capita tax that sparked a peasants' revolt in 1381. Under the measure, local services are paid for not by a property tax as in the past but by a per capita tax on everyone over 18. The rate is set by each local district and varies widely. Ridley said if the Labor Party took power, ``they would keep the charge because they would have to face up to the reality of the need to restrain local government spending in the interests of overall economic management.'' Critics, however, say the new tax is unfair because unlike income tax it takes no account of an individual's ability to pay and poorer people must pay the same as wealthier people. Low-income families and some other groups can get rebates of up to 80 percent under the new system. Violence broke out at anti-tax demonstrations around the country last month. A demonstration by 40,000 people in London on March 31 turned into a six-hour riot with 86 civilians and 374 police injured and 339 people arrested. Mrs. Thatcher came to power in 1979 and is now in her third term. The next general election is due by mid-1992.

DOC.HEAD: Heat in East, Snow in West; Thundershowers in South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf pvs, `Showers reached...,' to UPDATE with death toll in Texas flooding reaching six; SUBS lead to CORRECT that snow in West and Plains sted Midwest. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Snow fell...
DOC.TEXT: More than 20 cities in the Northeast sweltered in record high termperatures Saturday, snow fell in the West and parts of the Plains, and the South continued to get pelted with thunderstorms that brought high winds and hail. Watches for tornadoes and severe thunderstorms were posted for much of the South Saturday evening. Thunderstorms at Lenox, Ala., produced hail a half-inch in diameter, and gusty winds knocked down a few trees. Hail also fell near Jonesboro, Ga., and at Fayetteville, Ga. Winds gusted to 68 mph and three-quarter-inch diameter hail fell at Columbus, Ga. Snow resulted in the closing of several roads inside Yellowstone National Park. Three inches of snow covered the airport at Kalispell, Mont., and 4 to 6 inches of snow were reported north of Jackson, Wyo. Overnight snowfall ranged from 2 to 6 inches in eastern North Dakota. At noon Saturday, rain and thunderstorms extended from the western Carolinas across eastern Georgia to southern Florida, from Kentucky across southern Illinois, southeast Missouri, Tennessee, northern Mississippi, Alabama and northwest Georgia. Showers reached from northern Illinois across Wisconsin through east-central and northwest Minnesota, as well as the Nebraska Panhandle, northern Utah and northeast Nevada, from south-central Wyoming to north-central Wyoming, and along the Oregon coast. Meanwhile, the death toll from three days of storms and flooding in Texas last week rose to six, with the discovery of two victims. The bodies of two men whose was washed off a road near Sunray in north-central Texas on Wednesday were recovered from 13 feet of water. Snow fell in the Idaho Panhandle, and parts of Montana, Wyoming, the Dakotas and Minnesota. Among the cities where high temperature records for the date on Saturday were broken or tied included (old record and year in parentheses): Binghamton, N.Y., 88 (84 in 1962); Boston, 90 (89 in 1938) Bridgeport, Conn. 91 (80 in 1957) Buffalo, N.Y., 92 (88 in 1986); Concord, N.H., 89 (88 in 1969) Erie, Pa., 84 (83 in 1986) Flint, Mich., 82 (80 in 1951) Hartford, Conn., 92 (91 in 1938); Marquette, Mich., 77 (76 in 1970); Muskegon, Mich., 79 (tied 79 in 1970) Newark N.J., 90 (89 in 1962); New york N.Y., 90 (89 in 1962); Philadelphia, 90 (87 in 1957) Pittsburgh, Pa., 88 (tied 88 in 1986); Portland, Maine, 81 (76 in 1941); Rochester, N.Y., 89 (87 in 1962); St. Johnsbury, Vt., 91 (87 in 1962) Syracuse N.Y., 92 (89 in 1962); Traverse City, Mich., 84 (tied 84 in 1901); Wilkes-Barre-Scranton, Pa., 88 (87 in 1962) Williamsport, Pa., 89 (88 in 1962); Wilmington, Del., 89 (88 in 1915) and Worcester, Mass., 90 (89 in 1938). One low temperature record for the date was broken, too. In Omaha, Neb., the mercury plummeted to 30 degrees, breaking the 32-degree record set in 1965, and tied in 1979 and 1986. The nation's low temperature Saturday, was 19 degrees at Minot, N.D. Temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 24 degrees at Cutbank, Mont., to 95 at Imperial, Calif. The forecast for Sunday called for a band of showers from Arizona to Minnesota, and snow flurries in Montana, Wyoming and North Dakota. A band of thunderstorms was expected from Ohio to the Carolinas. Showers were predicted from Massachusetts to Maine, and in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands March to Protest Animal Experiments
DOC.TEXT: About 8,000 people marched in central London Saturday to protest the use of animals in laboratory experiments. Police were out in force and a helicopter hovered overhead. But the march was peaceful, and no arrests were reported. It was the first major march and rally in central London since a demonstration against a new tax on March 31 escalated into a riot. The protesters passed the Houses of Parliament to attend a rally at Central Hall. Speakers included singer Lynsey de Paul, vice-president of the National Anti-Vivisection Society, and Green Party spokesman David Icke. ``The legal abuse of animals through vivisection and factory farms is done with the same sort of distorted values that allow people to sleep in cardboard boxes,'' said Icke.

DOC.HEAD: Jury: Ex-Husband Gets 25 Percent of $31.5 Million Jackpot
DOC.TEXT: A man who sued his ex-wife for half of her $31.5 million Florida Lotto jackpot is entitled to 25 percent of her winnings for his role in buying the ticket, a jury decided Saturday. Lewis Snipes, a mechanic who claimed he helped pick the six winning numbers and had agreed to share the winnings before purchasing the ticket, rejected his former wife's offer of $1 million before filing the suit. One fourth of $31.5 million works out to roughly $7,875,000. The jury deliberated for 2{ hours before ruling that while Mary Ellen Snipes was the true owner of the ticket. Jurors also found that the couple had arranged to share the winnings, and that Snipes was entitled to a one-fourth share. Attorneys for Mrs. Snipes vowed to appeal and said lawyers for both sides would have to meet to determine the exact cash amount. Snipes, 55, of Indiantown, said he and Mrs. Snipes, 54, had a pool. He would buy 25 to 30 tickets a week and she would buy about 10 because she made less money. He said they agreed to share any winnings. The couple's two-year marriage ended in 1982, but Snipes kept in touch and occasionally paid part of his ex-wife's rent, mowed her lawn and repaired her car. Snipes still professes his love for his ex-wife, and she concedes it was an off-again, on-again love affair _ until the Oct. 22, 1988, Lotto drawing triggered the lawsuit.

Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expressed continuing support for Arab causes during a meeting Saturday with Syrian President Hafez Assad, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. In their three-hour meeting, the two leaders discussed Lebanon, the prospects for peace in the Middle East and the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, Tass said. Soviet policy of ``principled solidarity'' with Arab liberation movements remains unchanged, Gorbachev was quoted as saying. Assad arrived in Moscow Friday for a two-day visit. The Soviet Union has traditionally been Syria's main backer, but that has been changing as Moscow pursues detente and reforms at home, and Syria has been trying to cultivate better ties with the West. The loss of Soviet support was seen as a key reason for Syria's role in the freeing of U.S. hostage Robert Polhill after 39 months in captivity in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Akaka Named to Replace U.S. Senator Spark Matsunaga
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Daniel K. Akaka of Hawaii was appointed Saturday to fill the U.S. Senate seat of Sen. Spark Matsunaga, who died April 15. Hawaii Gov. John Waihee signed a proclamation naming his fellow Democrat to the post effective May 16. Akaka will serve until January, when the winner of special elections held during the regular primary and general elections will be seated to serve the remaining four years of Matsunaga's six-year term. ``I am honored to serve in the United States Senate. I am honored to fill the seat vacated by our beloved Senator Matsunaga,'' Akaka said. ``I will continue his work of peace and justice.'' Matsunaga, a Democrat, was elected to the Senate in 1976 after serving 14 years in the U.S. House. He died of complications of prostate cancer. Matsunaga was known for his work on a bill ordering reparations payments and an apology to Japanese-Americans imprisoned during World War II. He also campaigned to establish the U.S. Peace Institute in Washington, D.C. which awards grants to university projects. Akaka, 65, is a former schoolteacher and school administrator who has served in the House since 1976. He announced last week that he would enter the race to fill Matsunaga's full term. Hawaii's other member of Congress, Republican U.S. Rep. Patricia Saiki, has said she is interested in running. Akaka's 2nd Congressional District seat will be filled in a special election to be held in conjunction with Hawaii's primary election Sept. 22. Simultaneously, there will be the regular election for the U.S. House seat, meaning the winner of the special election would serve until January, when the winner of the regular election would take office. Waihee, a Democrat, called Akaka ``an individual of proven experience in the United States Congress.'' With Akaka in Waihee's office for the for the announcement and proclamation signing was U.S. Sen. Daniel K. Inouye, D-Hawaii. ``With his experience, his know-how and his established integrity in the United States Congress, he will be a great asset for Hawaii,'' Inouye said.

DOC.HEAD: Casinos on Reservation Reopen; Police Discourage Gamblers
LaserPhotos XMTL1, XSTR1
DOC.TEXT: State police warned gamblers to stay away Saturday night as Indian casinos reopened for the first time since gambling opponents blockaded this strife-torn Mohawk reservation in March. Fearing further violence after nearly a week of nightly gunfire and vandalism, more than 500 women, children and elderly people fled Friday from the Canadian side of the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation. The reservation, home to some 14,000, straddles the U.S.-Canada border. The reservation was quiet Friday and Saturday, authorities said. Authorities and Mohawks had feared renewed violence when workers returned home for the weekend and casinos reopened. Although some casinos were open, many of their employees stayed home and the usual busloads of customers were expected to be absent Saturday night. State police put up informational roadblocks at entrances to the Mohawk land, warning people to stay off the reservation because of violence. Customs agents along the border searched cars for weapons. Residents are divided over casinos and bingo halls on the American side of the reservation. The feud also touches on the question of Indian sovereignty _ whether state and federal officials have the authority to intervene in a dispute between Indian factions. In late March, gambling opponents blockaded roads leading to the reservation. Pro-gambling Mohawks tore down the blockades in a fierce fight Tuesday night, and for several nights there were violent confrontations between the factions. Buildings on the reservation are spray-painted with pro- and anti-gambling slogans, and areas where fighting has occurred are littered with broken glass, burnt car parts and spent shells. Mike Mitchell, chief of the Canadian Mohawk Council, said he ordered the evacuation because residents were in danger. Evacuees were housed in dormitory rooms at a training center for air traffic controllers in Cornwall, Ontario. Evacuees decided to return home Monday if they don't get a commitment of support from the American or Canadian governments, Mitchell said. He said he believed both sides in the gambling dispute should surrender their arms, but he doesn't think that will happen voluntarily. ``If no outside government gives us assistance putting those weapons away, we're going to have to do it ourselves,'' he said. Mohawk Chief Harold Tarbell, a gambling opponent, has called on New York Gov. Mario Cuomo to send in the National Guard to restore order. Cuomo said Saturday that ``so far there is no necessity for military involvement.'' He said some Mohawks were exaggerating the seriousness of the violence ``to advance their own political cause.'' One Mohawk chief, David Jacobs, agreed that some Indians were making the violence sound worse than it was. ``It is my profound hope that Chief Tarbell's alarmist calls for intervention do not result in the revival of unrest on the reservation,'' said Jacobs, a gambling supporter.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Contends USS Stark Defense System Was Faulty
DOC.TEXT: A federal lawsuit blames 11 defense contractors for the deaths of 37 sailors aboard the USS Stark in the Persian Gulf three years ago, accusing them of failing to properly test a missile defense system. Twenty-two relatives of the sailors who were killed in the May 17, 1987, Iraqui attack on the U.S. Navy frigate and two survivors of the attack filed a lawsuit in federal court Thursday. The suit seeks unspecified actual and punitive damages. Twenty-one sailors were injured and 37 died when an Iraqi warplane fired two French-made Exocet missiles on the guided-missile frigate. The Stark was on routine patrol in international waters 85 miles northeast of Bahrain during the Iran-Iraq war. The lawsuit contends the companies and the university failed to conduct reliability tests on the vessel's Phalanx and Aegis anti-missile defense systems. That negligence is to blame for the sailors' deaths, the suit alleges. The suit accuses General Dynamics of fraud by misrepresenting its product test results and hiding the actual results. General Dynamics, one of the nation's largest defense contractors, also failed to warn the sailors about the dangers of the ship's defense system, the suit alleges. Also named as defendants are Raytheon Co., FMC Corp., Hughes Aircraft Corp., Unisys Corp., Martin Marietta Corp., General Electric Co., RCA Government Systems Division, Honeywell Inc., and Computer Sciences Corp. Also named is Johns Hopkins University. A spokesman in General Dynamics' Fort Worth office failed to return phone calls. Jim Furlong, spokesman for Computer Sciences Corp., based in El Segundo, Calif., said the firm is unaware of the suit. A spokesman for Honeywell Inc. in Minneapolis did not return phone calls. Iraqi officials said after the attack that the plane's crew mistook the ship for an Iranian target. The Stark did not return fire.

DOC.HEAD: Sex on the Border: `Boys Town' Brothels Lure American Men
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 17th graf pvs, `Until the...,' to ADD names of other border towns with boys towns. Pick up 18th graf pvs, `Prostitutes come...
DOC.TEXT: In a handful of cities on the Mexican border, American men still throng to the brothels of ``boys towns,'' legal prostitution zones little changed by fears of sexual disease or campaigns for more wholesome tourism. At least five Mexican border cities have flourishing boys towns, and though some have been moved away from central tourist districts, they remain popular attractions for businessmen, hunters and teen-agers. They're accepted with little controversy, although Texas' Republican gubernatorial candidate, Clayton Williams, drew heat after admitting recently that he frequented border brothels during his college years more than 30 years ago because they were the only place to get ``serviced.'' Visiting the prostitutes, Williams said, was just ``part of growing up in West Texas.'' On a Thursday night in Acuna, across the border from the Texas town of Del Rio, about 50 American men mingled with Mexican women at the Hunters Saloon beneath a glittering banner that proclaims in English: ``Welcome Hunters.'' While nude dancers perform on stage, prostitutes lead customers toward the bar's back rooms. ``We're just here to check it out,'' said one Texas man, gazing around the bar. ``This is really mild compared to a lot of places.'' Outside along the dusty streets of boys town _ also known as La Zona de Tolerancia or Zone of Tolerance _ scattered groups of men from nearby Air Force installations, teen-agers and other Americans wander to bars like the Rio Club and La Camelia. The half-dozen bars, most only a few years old and well-appointed, are clustered on a small hill along a gravel road south of town. Smaller and older brothels cater to Mexican clients. A Del Rio businessman in his 40s who has frequented the brothels for more than 20 years says there's little fear of AIDS or other sexual diseases. ``I believe there are more problems with diseases ... in the big cities,'' said the man, who declined to be identified. ``These ladies go to medical checkups. Every week a doctor checks them.'' Dr. Herbert H. Ortega of El Paso, executive director of the U.S.-Mexico Border Health Association, said AIDS is ``almost nonexistent'' among the prostitutes. He credits education efforts by the association and other groups, such as the Pan-American Health Organization that he leads. Acuna health officials last week cited some prostitutes for not having health certificates and checked them for disease. Men visiting boys towns say many prostitutes require condoms. Some say the threat of disease limits them to looking. ``It's too much of a chance, going home with something you don't want,'' said a Brownwood, Texas, man who made a side trip to Acuna from a seminar for undercover narcotics agents in Del Rio. The agent, who did not want to be identified, said he was there only to drink and look. Until the early 1980s, boys town was near the center of Acuna, a city of about 120,000. After residents complained about the noise, the district was moved out of town and the party atmosphere subsided. Boys towns also flourish in the border towns of Reynosa, Juarez, Neuvo Laredo and Piedras Negras. Prostitutes come from all over Mexico to earn money at the brothels. Clients say the women charge $40 to $100 for their services. The prostitutes won't discuss profits. They say they have no pimps and keep all the money they get except for about $5 per customer they pay the bar for use of a room. By contrast, the legal minimum wage in Mexico for unskilled workers is $3.90 a day. Mexican workers in some American factories along the border generally are considered well-paid at about $100 a week. The prostitutes shy away from discussing their personal lives. Rosalinda, 26, said in her six months in Acuna she has had sex with thousands of men. Her only complaints are slow nights early in the week and the American youths who come not for sex but to take advantage of Mexico's lower drinking age. ``You don't need them around,'' Rosalinda said in Spanish. ``What do you need them for?''

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Officials Order Plant Shut Down For 4-6 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Seabrook nuclear power plant officials ordered the reactor shut down for four to six weeks of modifications Saturday, shortly before the long-delayed plant was to produce its first commercial electricity. Seabrook officials decided Saturday morning that electrical feedback from the New England power grid could cause a section of the plant's turbine to vibrate beyond specifications, plant spokesman David Scanzoni said. ``It's a delay, but that's the purpose of the test,'' Scanzoni said. ``We'll take all the time that's necessary.'' He said plant engineers have yet to determine what modifications are needed on the turbine, a 200-foot-long shaft that drives an electrical generator. The problem didn't involve the reactor. The reactor, which has operated at up to 10 percent of full power since winning its commercial license from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on March 1, was at 6 percent power before the shutdown, Scanzoni said. Plant officials had hoped the reactor would begin commercial operation by early this week and reach 100 percent power within two to three months. Scanzoni said Seabrook now won't be able to start commercial operation before late May. Saturday's shutdown was the third shut down since the reactor since the current phase of testing began March 20. The reactor was shut March 22 for adjustments and again a week later because of questionable readings from sensors on the turbine, Scanzoni said. The $6.5 billion, 1,150-megawatt reactor, initially planned to operate commercially in 1979 at a fraction of the cost, wasn't completed until 1986 because of repeated regulatory delays and cost overruns. Concerns about evacuation planning for crowded beach communities less than two miles from the plant held up a commercial license until this year. The delays forced lead Seabrook owner Public Service Company of New Hampshire to seek bankruptcy protection in 1988. The plant also has been the site of anti-nuclear demonstrations that have resulted in more than 3,000 arrests since 1976.

DOC.HEAD: British Art Critic Peter Fuller Dies in Auto Crash
DOC.TEXT: British art critic Peter Fuller, founder of the magazine Modern Painters, was killed in an auto crash Saturday, police said. He was 42. No other vehicle was involved in the crash on the M4 highway in Berkshire, west of London, said Thames Valley police. Three other people in the car were injured, including Fuller's wife, Stephanie, and his son, Laurence, 3, said police speaking on condition of anonymity in line with British custom. Fuller was appointed art critic last year of The Sunday Telegraph which carried his final review in its Sunday edition. Trevor Grove, editor of the weekly, said: ``Peter Fuller was one of the most perceptive, passionate and fluent art critics of our time.'' ``His defense of traditional artistic values and vigorous skepticism of what was and is bogus in the modernist movement made his writing both controversial and stimulating. But this never blinded him to the merits of good contemporary work,'' Grove said. In 1987, Fuller founded and edited the quarterly Modern Painters principally to bring to attention British artists whom he considered were too often underrated. In Britain, where sales of art magazines and books are traditionally modest, the magazine had an astonishing successs and attracted several thousand subscriptions. Fuller wrote in what was to be his final newspaper review:``In Britain right now, painting seems to be in a more robust state than anywhere else in the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Letter Writer Must Get Treatment After Threatening President
DOC.TEXT: A man who wrote a letter threatening President Bush and others was sentenced to six months a halfway house. At a U.S. District Court hearing Friday, David L. Cook also was fined $1,000 and ordered to undergo mental evaluation and attend mental counseling if deemed appropriate. Cook, of Dry Prong, pleaded guilty in February to a charge of writing a threatening letter. Prosecutors said Cook mailed a letter May 8, 1989, threatening Bush, former President Reagan, England Air Force Base and Fort Polk. The letter was mailed to Secret Service agents in Shreveport. Another letter written by Cook on top of the threatening letter left an impression with his name and address that showed up under laboratory analysis, prosecutors said. U.S. District Judge F.A. Little Jr. ordered Cook to serve his sentence at the Alexandria Salvation Army Community Treatment Center, a halfway house for federal prisoners.

DOC.HEAD: Official Attacked For Article Calling For Ties With U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A radical Iranian newspaper on Saturday attacked Iran's vice president for suggesting direct talks with the United States, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Vice President Ataollah Mohajerani, in a column in the Farsi-language newspaper Ettelaat on Thursday, had argued that Iran has much to gain by agreeing to direct talks with the United States. The daily Jomhuri Islami said Mohajerani's arguments had ``stirred a feeling of disgust among the people and the officials,'' according to IRNA, monitored in Cyprus. The Iranian news agency also said the Islamic Association of Tehran University Students has called for a demonstration Sunday to protest against Mohajerani's comments. President Hashemi Rafsanjani has spoken in favor of normalizing ties with the West, especially the West European countries. But until the Mohajerani article, no high-ranking Iranian official had argued publicly that Tehran should re-establish ties with Washington. Rafsanjani's radical opponents are unwilling to consider the possibility of renewed relations with the United States. Iran has been implacably anti-American since its 1979 Islamic revolution. In his article, Mohajerani argued that the United States could pressure Iraq into withdrawing troops from Iranian territory seized in the eight-year Persian Gulf war. Mohajerani also said that talks could result in the freeing of billions of dollars in frozen Iranian assets. The United States froze the assets and severed ties after Iranian militants stormed the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in November 1979 and took 52 Americans hostage.

DOC.HEAD: Blues Singer Misses Concert; Reported Hospitalized in Las Vegas
DOC.TEXT: Blues singer and guitarist B.B. King canceled two weekend performances at a jazz festival here, and a festival spokesman said King was hospitalized in Las Vegas. King, 64, whose earthy lyrics and soulful guitar sound have won him a wide following outside traditional blues circles, missed performances Friday and Saturday at the 21st New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival. His represetatives said King was hospitalized in Las Vegas, according to JazzFest spokesman Louis Edwards. ``He canceled late Friday afternoon. I don't know what's wrong but I understand it's pretty serious,'' Edwards said. Officials of the four largest hospitals in Las Vegas denied treating King, a Mississippi native who lives in Las Vegas. King, who calls his guitar Lucille, is known for performances of such songs as ``The Thrill is Gone,'' ``You Done Lost Your Good Thing Now'' and ``Caldonia.'' King was replaced Friday night by blues singer and guitarist Elvin Bishop, but no replacement was brought in for the Saturday performance.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 14th graf, The president's ... to clarify that President Bush campaigned for Ms. Ros-Lehtinen. ^Justice Investigating Miami U.S. Attorney for Misconduct
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is conducting an internal inquiry into allegations of misconduct by the acting U.S. attorney in Miami, whose office is prosecuting Manuel Noriega, according to sources. The investigation of Dexter Lehtinen comes as the Senate Judiciary Committee considers his nomination by President Bush to a full term as the chief federal prosecutor in south Florida. The sources familiar with the inquiry and who asked not to be identified by name said the Justice Department Office of Professional Responsibility recently sent investigators to Miami to conduct interviews into allegations including: _ That Lehtinen pressured his staff to inflate overtime reports to prompt Washington to boost the size of his office _ now one of the Justice Department's largest. _ That Lehtinen tried to participate in a public corruption investigation after recusing himself from a case which involved a potential political rival of his wife, Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, R-Fla. _ That a letter written by Lehtinen's spokeswoman, Diane Cossin, to the Miami Herald may have violated federal privacy law. The letter said Lehtinen once almost fired a former prosecutor for ``egregious misconduct.'' The Herald obtained a copy of the personnel file of the prosecutor, who resigned last month, and reported that its contents did not support the statements in Ms. Cossin's letter. Lehtinen did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment Friday. Ms. Cossin declined to comment on the reported inquiry, saying: ``We don't respond to speculation and we don't confirm or deny investigations.'' Lehtinen has been in the headlines before. In January, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh eased Lehtinen off the Noriega trial team. Government sources said at the time that the attorney general took the action because of concern that Lehtinen's volatile temper and his relatively modest trial experience could hamper the government's drug-trafficking case against the deposed Panamanian leader. The internal Justice Department investigation comes at a politically sensitive time. Lehtinen's nomination to a full term as U.S. attorney in Miami is pending in the Senate. The review also could prove ticklish for the Bush administration because of Lehtinen's political ties to the White House. The president's son, Jeb, supported Ms. Ros-Lehtinen's successful campaign last summer to win the seat of the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. President Bush personally campaigned for Ms. Ros-Lehtinen, who is popular in Miami's Cuban-American community. One of the items under review involves an alleged attempt by Lehtinen to involve himself in the corruption investigation of Hialeah Mayor Raul Martinez after publicly recusing himself from the case, according to sources familiar with the probe. In announcing his recusal, Lehtinen explained that Martinez, who was indicted this month on racketeering charges, was a possible political rival of his wife. The false overtime report allegation stems from a staff meeting during which Lehtinen told prosecutors they should take more credit for the long hours they put in, the sources said. Lehtinen told the staff that he wanted the U.S. attorney's office for the southern district of Florida to replace the southern district of New York in the eyes of the nation's lawyers as the premier branch of the Justice Department, the sources added. Lehtinen told staff attorneys that federal prosecutors in the department's New York office worked 65 hours of overtime a month and expressed confidence that Miami prosecutors did so as well, the sources said. Federal prosecutors do not receive additional pay for overtime work. But the figures collected by the Justice Department in monthly statistical reports from the nation's 93 U.S. attorney's offices are used to determine whether to add more prosecutors to a particular office. The number of federal prosecutors in the office increased from 88 in November 1988 to 154 currently, and the Justice Department has authorized as many as 200 this year, officials said. The possible Privacy Act violation involves a March 12 letter Ms. Cossin wrote to the Herald in reply to a letter the newspaper had published from David DeMaio, who resigned to join a private Miami firm. The departure of DeMaio and four others from the office was cited by the Herald as evidence of staff dissatisfaction with Lehtinen. The Herald article quoted Ms. Cossin as saying the fact the prosecutors stayed long after Lehtinen took over ``indicates some sort of happiness with the office.'' DeMaio wrote a letter published by the Herald saying ``her views do not necessarily reflect my own, and she was not authorized to speak for me.'' By way of reply, Ms. Cossin wrote that Lehtinen had authorized her to state that he had once almost fired DeMaio for ``egregious misconduct'' and was ``counseled for failure to pursue important investigations properly'' and denied a pay raise.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 200 Aliens Seeking Asylum May Be Released
DOC.TEXT: About 200 aliens in detention centers may be paroled in an experiment that could signal a change in the way the United States views aliens seeking political asylum, according to report published Sunday. Under current rules, aliens requesting asylum are held in custody while their cases are reviewed _ a process that can take from a few days to years. The new program, starting in several cities this week, would let selected detainees remain free while the Immigration and Naturalization Service reviews their cases, The New York Times reported. Participants in the program would have to post a bond of between $500 to $2,500, establish their identities, and have jobs, residences and lawyers or other accredited representatives. Alien also would have to agree to report monthly to the INS and return to detention or leave the country if ordered, the newspaper reported. The 18-month experimental program will be in New York, Miami, Los Angeles and San Francisco. The INS said there are 5,000 to 6,000 aliens in its detention centers, not including Cubans from the Mariel boatlift who are considered criminals. The director of the refugee project for the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, Arthur C. Helton, said the program stems from talks he had with the new INS commissioner, Gene McNary. ``We hope that this release project will demonstrate that many refugees are being unnecessarily incarcerated in the United States,'' Helton told the Times. ``This project may indeed signal the beginning of the end of one the harshest elements of the INS's detention policy.''

DOC.HEAD: The 6,137th and Final Performance of `A Chorus Line'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with performance, reaction. PICK UP 5th graf pvs, The public xxx. ^LaserPhoto NY28
