DOC.TEXT: Broadway said goodbye Saturday to ``A Chorus Line'' in an emotional final performance that included tears, cheers and a standing ovation for the musical's cast, past and present. ``This show is dedicated to anyone who has ever danced in a chorus or marched in step anywhere,'' said producer Joseph Papp as the show ended a 15-year run of 6,137 performances, the longest in Broadway history. ``Take a final bow `Chorus line,''' Papp said. There were wild applause after every musical number and at the end of the show, the audience cheered throughout the finale. Papp began a roll call of all the performers in the current production and hen brought on stage all the dancers who were in the original 1975 production. Theater-goers then roared their approval as a photo of Michael Bennett, the show's director and choreographer appeared on stage. Bennett died of AIDS in 1987 at the age of 44. The sold-out evening benefited the New York Shakespeare Festival, which produced the musical. Tickets were priced from $80 to $500. Papp announced the pending closure in February, citing declining ticket sales. At first he said it would close at the end of March, but a surge of last-minute ticket sales pushed the closing date back four weeks. The public first saw ``A Chorus Line'' in April 1975 in the Shakespeare Festival's Newman Theater off-Broadway. The show was born from a series of workshops conducted by Bennett. Material came from more than 40 hours of taped conversations with theater dancers about their hopes, fears, lives and loves. It was Bennett who fashioned the musical, hiring composer Marvin Hamlisch, lyricist Ed Kleban, and Nicholas Dante and James Kirkwood to write the book. ``A Chorus Line'' was an immediate success. The reviews were ecstatic, and the musical moved to Broadway on July 25, 1975. In 1976, it won the Pulitzer Prize for drama. Since then, it has become one of the most financially successful Broadway shows ever. Variety pegged its total profit as of February 1990 at more than $50 million, the second highest in U.S. theater history after ``Cats.'' A London edition ran more than 900 performances. The first national company opened in May 1976 and didn't close until September 1980. An international tour lasted even longer, from April 1976 until August 1983. There have been several special performances over the years. On Jan. 30, 1981, the recently released Iranian hostages attended a performance of the show. On Sept. 29, 1983, ``A Chorus Line'' became the longest-running show in Broadway history with performance No. 3,389, passing ``Grease.'' Bennett put 332 past and current cast members on stage. At the 5,001st performance, 19 people who appeared in stock or amateur productions of the show joined Broadway cast members on stage for the finale. There has been renewed interest in ``A Chorus Line'' over the past year, with four books written about the show or about Bennett. The original cast, which participated in one of the books, appeared on talk and news shows. The list of the five longest-running Broadway shows now stands at: ``A Chorus Line,'' 6,137 performances; ``Oh! Calcutta!,'' 5,959; ``42nd Street,'' 3,486; ``Grease,'' 3,388, and ``Fiddler on the Roof,'' 3,242.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LOS ANGELES
Mexico Demands Extraditions After Abduction Of Mexican Suspect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Mexico's foreign ministry saying it will demand extradition of anyone who participated in abduction, arrested former policeman says was told kidnapping was DEA operation; pick up 6th graf pvs, `On Saturday ...'; edits to trim
DOC.TEXT: Mexico said Saturday it would demand the extradition of anyone involved in the abduction of a Mexican doctor to face U.S. charges in connection with the murder of an American drug agent. The April 2 kidnapping _ and allegations that it was masterminded by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration _ have inflamed U.S.-Mexican relations. ``The Mexican government will immediately initiate the process for soliciting the extradition of the people, whether Mexicans or foreigners, who participated in the execution, planning or organization of the abduction,'' Mexico's Foreign Ministry said in a news release. Mexican authorities said Saturday a former Mexican policeman arrested in connection with the kidnapping said he was told it was a DEA operation. Claims that the abduction was DEA-approved also came from from Antonio Garate Bustamente, a self-styled DEA informant and former Mexican police officer. Garate told the Los Angeles Times that 10 Mexicans were promised a total of $100,000 to deliver Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain to U.S. authorities. Among those involved were Mexican federal policemen, he said. The Mexican attorney general's office said that former policeman Jorge Covarrubias Manriquez, arrested Saturday, said he was told the kidnapping was a DEA operation and that he would receive $3,700. The attorney general's office described Covarrubias as a leader of the group accused in the kidnapping. Covarrubias joins six other men Mexican authorities have arrested for questioning in the incident. Four men claiming they were Mexican federal police seized Alvarez Machain in Guadalajara on April 2. When he arrived in El Paso, Texas the next day, he was arrested. The U.S. Justice Department and the Mexican attorney general's office are conducting separate investigations of the incident. On Saturday, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh denied DEA involvement. ``No DEA agent was involved in Mexico in the apprehension of Dr. Alvarez Machain,'' Thornburgh said CNN's Newsmaker program. ``No one was involved in bringing him to this country. Our first encounter was when he got off the plane in El Paso and he was taken into custody in the United States by DEA agents,'' he said. Thornburgh said he wanted to bring to justice everyone involved in the February 1985 kidnapping of U.S. drug agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena in Guadalajara. Camarena's mutilated body was found several weeks later. Alvarez Machain had long been sought by American authorities, who allege that he monitored Camarena's medical condition while he was being interrogated and administered stimulants to revive the DEA agent during questioning. Garate told the Times that plans to abduct Alvarez Machain were approved by Hector Berellez, a DEA agent in Los Angeles who heads the nine-member unit investigating Camarena's murder in Guadalajara. ``I couldn't do anything without their knowledge,'' Garate said. He said he was paid $4,000 a month by the DEA for his work. ``I know the crooks,'' said Garate, who claimed he once headed a state SWAT team in Guadalajara. ``I know Guadalajara.'' Garate, 51, said the plot to abduct Alvarez was dubbed ``The Wild Geese,'' for a 1978 film starring Richard Burton about mercenaries in Africa. Unnamed DEA officials told the newspaper that Garate was the key go-between in arranging the abduction. A DEA source called Garate a longtime agency ``asset,'' a term often used to describe an informant or operative. Officials in Mexico City also said Garate was an informant, who had been wanted in Mexico since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian President To Meet with Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara said he is optimistic the U.S. Senate will approve an aid package for Panama and he intends to thank President Bush for the funds during his visit to Washington this week. Endara's five-day trip beginning Sunday is his first to the United States since he was installed as president at the start of the U.S. invasion on Dec. 20 that overthrew dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``When I meet with President Bush, everything indicates that we are going to have the economic aid approved,'' Endara said in an interview with the Associated Press late Friday. Endara, scheduled to see Bush on Monday, said he will ``thank (Bush), in my name and for the Panamanian people.'' The $420 million aid package to Panama is part of a $3.4 billion spending bill that has been held up in the Senate. Once the Senate approves the bill, a joint Senate-House panel must then reconcile the proposal with the House's $2.4 billion spending bill. Endara opposed Noriega in the May 1989 presidential elections. Noriega, awaiting trial on narcotics charges in the United States, annulled the elections when it became apparent that Endara was winning. During his five-day trip to Washington and New York, Endara will also meet with officials from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. He will also hold talks with the secretary general of the Organization of American States, Joao Baena Soares, and with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Accompanied by 12 other Panamanian officials, Endara is to take a commercial flight to Miami, where a U.S. government plane will pick him up for the flight to Washington. He travels to New York on Tuesday and returns to Washington on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Dig Up Bodies Unidentified After Panama Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Authorities Saturday began digging up bodies buried in common graves during December's U.S. invasion to try to identify them. According to official statistics, 314 Panamanians, including 202 civilians, died in the Dec. 20 invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Many of the dead were not identified at the time. A committee of family members of casualties of the invasion requested the exhumation. The operation could take up to a week, medical and judicial authorities supervising it said. The first common grave, opened Saturday, is on the edge of the city in the Garden of Peace cemetery. As a backhoe opened the grave, some 300 people looked on, many of them relatives of missing persons.

DOC.HEAD: No Retrial for Ex-Panther in San Quentin Killings
DOC.TEXT: Former Black Panther Johnny Spain, whose double murder conviction in a 1971 San Quentin prison uprising was overturned because he was shackled during his trial, will not be retried, authorities said Friday. Marin County District Attorney Jerry Herman called the reversal of Spain's conviction ``a travesty and a gross miscarriage of justice'' but said in a statement that a retrial would serve no practical purpose. ``Since this case is now 19 years old, and since the defendant Spain has now been out of custody and led a crime-free life for three years, it is impossible to believe that a conviction secured after a retrial would result in the defendant Spain being resentenced to prison,'' Herman said. Spain, 40, has been out of prison for just over two years. He was freed in March 1988 after a judge ordered the state parole board not to consider the San Quentin incident in deciding whether Spain was suitable for parole from a 1967 murder conviction. Herman said the widows and families of three prison guards who were killed in the incident, and three other guards who survived after their throats were cut, ``support our decision not to retry the case.'' Spain's lawyer, Dennis Riordan, said he was relieved, not only that the case was over, but also ``that that era is being laid to rest.'' It was a time of ``tremendous racial and political violence, when decent people on both sides of the line were killed,'' Riordan said. ``You have to put it behind you at some point and go on or the cycle continues. Three guards and three prisoners, including militant leader George Jackson, author of the book ``Soledad Brother,'' were killed in the August 1971 melee. Authorities said it started when Jackson pulled a smuggled gun from beneath a hairpiece and tried to escape from the prison's isolation unit. Spain, then serving a life sentence for a Los Angeles murder committed when he was 17, was seen running with Jackson out of the maximum-security unit, and was accused of aiding Jackson in the escape attempt and the murders. U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson overturned Spain's convictions in 1982, ruling that Marin County Superior Court Judge Henry Broderick had improperly left on the jury a woman who had said she thought a friend had been murdered by a Black Panther. The Supreme Court reversed Henderson's ruling in 1983 but left other issues unresolved. Henderson again overturned the convictions in 1986, this time citing the 25 pounds of shackles Jackson was forced to wear throughout the court proceedings from 1971 to 1976. The chains, sometimes attached for 10 to 12 hours a day, hampered Spain's ability to communicate with his lawyer, may have affected his decision not to testify, and may have prejudiced the jury against him, Spain said.

DOC.HEAD: Some Indians Flee Reservation as Violence Mounts over Gambling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to make `side' sted `state.'
DOC.TEXT: Some 2,000 Mohawk Indians began evacuating their reservation Friday to escape factional violence that has left roadways lined with burned cars and caused residents, including children, to brandish arms. Gov. Mario Cuomo, meanwhile, stood firm on his refusal to send New York State Police or National Guardsmen to restore order on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation, despite pleas from one Indian leader and some outsiders. One man was critically injured in the violence and another was missing. The reservation straddles New York and Canada, but the violence so far has taken place on the United States side. After a week of nightly confrontations between Indians who support casino gambling and bingo on the U.S. side and those who oppose it, Canadian Mohawk leaders on Friday evacuated women, children and the elderly from the village of St. Regis in Quebec, which is near the violence on the New York state border. They were sent to nearby Cornwall, Ontario, just outside the reservation. ``It has become a very tense situation and we can no longer guarantee safety for our people,'' said Lloyd Benedict, chief of the Canadian band council. About 5,000 Mohawks live in the Canadian sector of the reservation, and it's expected the evacuation will affect at least 2,000 of them, he said. The reservation's total population is about 14,000. The recent violence began March 23, when Indians who oppose gambling set up roadblocks to keep outsiders off the reservation. They demanded tribe leaders address the gambling dispute and the presence of the Warrior Society, a heavily armed faction that has appointed itself the protector of Mohawk sovereignty. Pro-gambling Mohawks tore down the blockades in a hailstorm of gunfire Tuesday night, but gambling has largely stopped since the barricades went up. On Friday, the reservation straddling the Canadian border had the look of a war zone. Burned cars lined the roads, most buildings had bullet holes or broken windows and residents, including children, were armed with guns or baseball bats. State police warn outsiders to stay off the reservation. The latest casualty of the long-running dispute was Brian Cole, one of the leaders of the blockades. He was in critical condition in Ottawa General Hospital Friday after his skull and jaw were fractured in a confrontation Thursday. Relatives said Cole was helping search for Horace Cook, 50, who came as a representative of the Onondaga nation near Syracuse to help monitor the barricades at the request of the anti-gambling faction. Cook, a diabetic who doesn't see well, has been missing since Thursday. Among those calling for intervention has been St. Regis Tribal Council Head Chief Harold Tarbell, who has asked for National Guardsmen to serve as peacekeepers on the reservation. On Thursday, U.S. Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the select committee on Indian affairs, wrote Cuomo expressing his concern about the ``most grave situation'' at St. Regis. Canada urged Cuomo to take action in a complaint made by the its embassy in Washington, D.C., to the State Department, said Patricia Low-Bedard, a spokeswoman for the Canadian Department of External Affairs. ``We made no specific suggestions, but our government finds the situation alarming and we are concerned that something needs to be done,'' Low-Bedard said Friday. State troopers entered the reservation Thursday to help search for Cook, on Sunday to investigate a fire and last week to make their first arrests since last summer, of five people involved in the violence. ``We want this situation resolved,'' Cuomo said Friday at a news conference in Albany. ``We're working very hard to figure out how to do it. I think what we've done so far, what the state police have done so far, has been appropriate.''

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Recounts France's Deportation of 3,500 Jewish Children
DOC.TEXT: Nazi hunter Serge Klarsfeld on Friday hailed a magazine report as the first French media account of France's role in the roundup and deportation of 3,500 Jewish children who later died at Auschwitz. ``The episode in well-known to historians,'' Klarsfeld said in an interview, ``but this is the first time a journalist has ever gone to the scene of the crime to interview people who lived there.'' The cover story in this week's L'Express magazine, published Thursday, details the role of the French police in the roundup. Klarsfeld, who tracked down the Lyon Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie, said he hoped the article would help speed court action against Rene Bousquet, 80, charged with crimes against humanity. Bousquet was chief of the national police during the deportations, which Klarsfeld said were conducted by the collaborationist Vichy government to curry favor with the Nazi occupiers. Eric Conan, a reporter for L'Express, visited the towns of Pithiviers and Beaune-la-Rolande, sites of two French concentration camps where the children spent their last days before being shipped to the Nazis' Auschwitz death camp. ``In Pithiviers, nothing, absolutely nothing, officially commemorates the agony experienced by the children before their deaths,'' he wrote. A collective gravestone in Beaune-la-Rolande shows three small children died at that time. The stone reads simply, ``Victims of Hitler's barbarism.'' ``This is false: they were under the auspices of the French government until the moment they died,'' Conan wrote. The children were arrested in Paris with their families July 16-17, 1942, in the infamous ``Vel d'Hiv Roundup,'' named for their destination, a large cycling stadium. The families were kept kept at the stadium for days without food, water or sanitary facilities. They were transferred to Pithiviers and Beaune-la-Rolande. The adults were sent directly on to Auschwitz, but the children, including babies and toddlers, remained for weeks in the camps, where many died of starvation and disease. They were later shipped to Auschwitz and sent to the gas chambers on arrival. Klarsfeld said French authorities ordered the deportations of the children. The Nazis, he said, had issued orders for the roundup of only Jews over age 16 for fear of inciting the occupied population. ``They never would have taken the risk of arresting and dragging children into the streets of Paris,'' Klarsfeld said.

Some members of Congress, upset over President Bush's removal of Japan from a ``hit list'' of unfair traders, are introducing legislation to take away the president's discretion in the matter. The bill is just one example of the firestorm created by the administration's decision Friday to remove Japan from a list of countries deemed to have erected the most offensive barriers to the sale of U.S. products. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., took to the Senate floor to declare that he was ``thunderstruck'' by the action. ``Excuse me, Mr. President, but this boggles the mind,'' he said. ``Letting Japan off the hook is a serious mistake and I think Congress ought to take a look at it.''

The chairman of a Soviet parliamentary delegation says he will try to find out which Soviet official rejected offers of international aid after the 1986 explosion at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor. With the full dimensions of the Chernobyl disaster now becoming clear, the Supreme Soviet has reversed course and is urgently seeking scientific, medical and material aid from the world community. At a news conference at the Soviet Embassy on Friday, five Soviet parliamentary deputies said the official secrecy that shrouded the aftermath of the April 26, 1986, fire and explosion at the Chernobyl reactor was a damaging mistake because it masked the scope and scale of the disaster. In addition, they said efforts to clean up radiation contamination and deal with the medical effects of the accident might have been far more advanced by now if most foreign assistance had not been rejected.

Managers of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina put some of its workers at an unnecessarily high risk of ``gross contamination'' by plutonium, according to an Energy Department audit report. Plutonium, a key ingredient in nuclear warheads, is one of the most toxic elements known. Lethal lung doses of plutonium are measured in the billionths of a gram. The defense contractor that runs the plant, Westinghouse Electric Corp., said Friday it was taking action to correct the problem. It was discovered during a two-month probe of health, safety and environmental conditions at Savannah River, which makes plutonium and other special materials for nuclear weapons. The audit ended March 23 and results were made available Friday at the Energy Department, which owns Savannah River and 16 other major nuclear arms plants and laboratories.

Freed hostage Robert Polhill may remain hospitalized for as long as three or four weeks and will undergo a biopsy soon to determine the nature of a growth on his vocal cords, an Army doctor says. Dr. Russ Zajtchuk, deputy commander of clinical services at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, said Friday that Polhill is not considered strong enough yet to have the general anesthesia that is necessary for the biopsy. He said it probably will be performed ``about Monday.'' Polhill, 55, a diabetic, lost 25 pounds during his three years and three months in the hands of Shiite Moslem extremists in Lebanon.

Lithuania's president and a Soviet government spokesman on Saturday praised a French-West German proposal to defuse tensions, raising the possibility it could lead to a compromise between Moscow and Vilnius. The Kremlin has shut down shipments of oil, restricted natural gas and cut supplies of manufactured goods and food supplies to Lithuania. On Saturday, a Soviet government official said coal supplies had been cut as well. A letter from French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl proposed Lithuania suspend some laws backing up its March 11 declaration of independence but did not suggest repealing the declaration itself. ``We consider that this is not far from the line that the Soviet leadership has been pursuing from the very beginning,'' Arkady Maslennikov, a spokesman for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, told a Kremlin briefing. ``We consider this a constructive signal.''

One-third of the projects in a $1.6 billion elderly housing program are in or near financial ruin, with bloated loans and lousy management to blame, according to auditors who say the government will have little choice but to foot the bill. On at least two occasions, prominent Republican political consultants swayed senior Department of Housing and Urban Development officials to overrule field deputies and approve loans for projects in the troubled Retirement Service Center program, the audit says. The study details anew favoritism and myriad management problems at HUD during the Reagan administration tenure of Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. The new report, obtained by The Associated Press through the Freedom of Information Act, also suggests the pricetag for that mismanagement is rising, with no end in sight, as millions of dollars in loans insured by the government go sour.

Richard Gephardt thinks maybe he was a little ahead of the curve on Japan. During the 1988 presidential campaign, people accused him of bashing Japan on its trade policies. They called him protectionist. Today, however, he says a lot more people are in his camp, particularly Democrats who sense a good issue for 1992. ``There is a greater understanding on the part of a lot of people, especially about our problems with Japan and a few of the other countries where there are really significant trade access problems,'' the Missouri Democratic congressman said.

Thousands of angry workers battled riot police with firebombs, rocks, pipes and clubs Saturday to protest a huge police attack that crushed a three-day strike at the world's largest shipyard. Police said at least 24 people were injured, 10 of them policemen, in violence that began when thousands of security officials stormed the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. by land and sea. Police said 499 workers were arrested and warrants were issued for six fugitive union leaders. The crackdown came as other plants threatened to stage sympathy strikes, raising fears of reduced business investment and more sharp declines in South Korea's ailing stock market. ``The survival of the national economy was at stake,'' a governing party spokesman, Park Hee-tae, said in defending the police action.

The Hubble Space Telescope's electronic system was back in operation Saturday but its high-speed antennas remained down and its science instruments on hold. Meanwhile, Discovery's five astronauts prepared to land at 9:49 a.m. EDT Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., amid some concern that high wind might postpone the landing until Monday or Tuesday. ``It's time to pack up our camping gear and get ready to come home,'' said flight director Wayne Hale. Early Saturday, the $1.5 billion telescope was sent ``health and safety'' instructions to operate on its own. A day earlier, the electronic instruments had automatically shut down when they sensed trouble with one of two high-gain antennas, and when opening the lens cover made the telescope move.

Business and organized labor say Brazil's economic ``shock plan'' is driving the nation toward recession, but the poor think President Fernando Collor de Mello has the right idea. ``I hadn't eaten meat in so long, I'd forgotten what it tasted like,'' said Derly Rosa Perreira dos Santos, 25, who works as a maid and lives in a shantytown of Rio's poor North Zone. ``Now I can afford it twice a week.'' Record annualized inflation of 4,854 percent has fallen dramatically since Collor announced his ``New Brazil'' plan March 16, one day after taking office as the country's first democratically elected president in 29 years. It put an 18-month freeze on savings deposits of more than $1,200 and limited withdrawals from money market funds to $600 or 20 percent of the value, whichever was greater.

DOC.NOTE: $adv30
For Release Monday, April 30, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Sluggish Times For OTC Stocks
DOC.TEXT: While the performance of all major U.S. stock markets has been uninspired so far in 1990, the going has been particularly tough in the over-the-counter market. From New Year's through the middle of last week, the Dow Jones average of 30 blue chips listed on the New York Stock Exchange posted a net decline of 3.15 percent. Over the same span the NASDAQ composite index of issues that are traded over-the-counter more than doubled that decline, with a 7.53 percent drop. For the 12-month period through April 25, the story is much the same, with a gain of 11.61 percent for the Dow and a 0.67 percent decline for the NASDAQ index (the acronym stands for National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations). All this is not very cheery news for individual investors, who have a bigger proportional stake in over-the-counter trading than they do at the NYSE, the primary hunting ground of investing institutions such as pension funds. Nor is it any great source of elation to Joseph Hardiman, president of the NASD, which serves as the industry overseer and regulatory organization for over-the-counter activity. But whatever ails the OTC market can be largely attributed to investment vogues that tend to run in cycles, Hardiman suggested in an interview on a visit here from his Washington headquarters. The small growth companies that make up a big part of the NASDAQ system, he noted, have suffered through an unusually long period of disfavor, which most analysts trace as far back as 1983. Over that stretch, both domestic institutions and foreign investors have gravitated to the big blue-chip names. ``I think the cycle may be about to reverse itself,'' he said. OTC price indexes also have been dragged down, Hardiman added, by the large number of bank and other financial stocks traded in the market. Beset by real-estate debt woes and a new stringency in lending practices, over-the-counter bank stocks tumbled 23.40 percent in the past year. None of the many NYSE-listed bank holding companies, by contrast, is represented in the Dow. The image of the over-the-counter market suffered a severe blow in the crash of 1987, as a flood of orders ran into bottlenecks and other problems. Hardiman says the system has been greatly strengthened since that time by new rules and procedures intended, among other things, to put greater reliance on automation. In the current sluggish environment, he observes, ``we've got excess capacity at the moment.'' How to restore the enthusiasm of investors for the kind of small and medium-sized stocks that make up such a large part of the NASDAQ system? Hardiman sees no single wonder drug to prescribe. But he maintains that both individual investors and the economy would benefit from a restoration of some form of favorable tax treatment for capital gains, skewed to encourage long-term investment. ``The longer you hold an asset the lower the tax rate should be,'' he says. ``I think individuals who think they can speculate by trying to trade the market are fooling themselves,'' he adds. ``They should be long-term investors _ buy stocks, put them away and grow with the company. ``Some of the people who did the best in the October 1987 market break were individual investors who didn't sell.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, April 30
$Adv30
For Release Monday AMs, April 30, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Listening to the Vibrations
LaserPhoto FDK1 of April 20
DOC.TEXT: Slim Harrison's Appalachian mountain music recently fell on deaf ears, but those who were there had a knee-slappin' good time. Students at the Maryland School for the Deaf, who all wore hearing aids, strummed his guitar, plucked a wash tub bass, picked the strings of his banjo and tapped spoons on their thighs. A few of the youngsters could hear various tones from Harrison's jug band instruments, but most experienced the sounds through vibration. ``The idea is to expose the kids to some different instruments that they probably have never seen,'' said Harrison, whose program is one of a rising number of attempts across the country to introduce music to the hearing impaired. ``They've probably seen a guitar on TV, but have not actually played it and felt the vibration. ``If they have never felt the instrument with their hands and felt the vibrations, they really can't understand what this music stuff is all about.'' One group made such a racket that vibrations could be felt through tiles on the classroom floor. Teachers were holding their ears, but the children were oblivious to the noise they were making. ``It sounds that way with hearing children too,'' Harrison shouted as fourchildren played his banjo, guitar, dulcimer and autoharp _ all at the same time. ``That's about par for the course.'' Harrison, a one-man band, is doing a five-day residency at the 122-year-old school, which provides free education to deaf students in Maryland. His work with 47 severely to profoundly deaf children is being sponsored by Very Special Arts in Maryland, an organization that works to enrich the lives of disabled people through art, and the Maryland State Arts Council. Harrison has introduced the world of music to physically, emotionally and mentally handicapped children during programs in Rutland, Vt., Portland, Ore., Boston, Washington, Upland Hills, Mich., and across Maryland. This was the first time he had worked with a whole school of deaf students. ``Some of them can hear high tones, but not low tones,'' he said. ``They can enjoy music on a different level than we do. With loud rock 'n' roll, they can feel the vibrations shake their bodies.'' The sound of Harrison's autoharp apparently rattled the hearing aid of 8-year-old Robin Oswald who cupped her hands over her ears and squinted her eyes. The three other children in her class expressed no discomfort at the sound. At one point in his program Harrison lost charge of the children, who in their excitement began chatting with their hands and doing impromptu solo performances. ``How do you get deaf students' attention?'' he asked their teacher, who quickly commanded their attention through eye contact and a series of hand signs. Harrison then launched into a tune on his dulcimer with the teacher signing the students a message about how the name of the instrument came from a Latin word meaning ``sweet song'' or ``sweet love.'' Robert Mowers, music consultant to the National Technical Institute for the Deaf in Rochester, N.Y., said Harrison's jug band program was one of a rising number of music programs being offered to the deaf. ``Most of them are very small,'' said Mowers, who launched a music program at the institute 14 years ago despite comments from his colleagues who thought he was ``crazy.'' ``There are many hearing impaired persons who enjoy music. They just don't hear it like we do,'' Mowers said. Music heard by a deaf person might be like early radio broadcasts full of static or early records that played at 78 revolutions per minute, he said. ``Those 78 recordings were terrible _ full of distortions and scratches, yet millions of people enjoyed them,'' Mowers said. Music could be better utilized by deaf educators nationwide, according to Deborah P. Clark, an assistant principal at the Maryland School for the Deaf where music is a required course for primary students. ``Most deaf schools use it as an adjunct or motivator, but not very many have a whole course on it,'' she said. ``It gives them a chance to work with the language in a musical and rhythmic way. We're trying to get them to practice the feel of a loud sound and the feel of a soft sound (in their throats).'' Carol Bean, the school's music aide, said she regularly teaches students about high and low notes on an organ equipped with large amplifiers. ``They all can't hear, but they can all feel the vibrations of the organ,'' Bean said. ``The more exposure you can get the better it is. Otherwise, the deaf world can be very narrow.''

DOC.HEAD: Better Than an Oscar
DOC.TEXT: Glenda Jackson, the Academy Award-winning actress and socialist, is within reach of a dream: abandoning the stage for politics. Jackson still has her choice of stage and screen roles, but she's also a liberal who has chosen to tie her future to the Labor Party, the socialist opposition. If elected, she faces the comparative obscurity of being a backbencher, a rank-and-file lawmaker in the 650-member House of Commons. That means late-night sittings and looking after a constituency, which can entail everything from fighting road expansions in the district to unsnarling hitches in the supply of hot meals to the elderly. It also raises the fascinating prospect of that distinctively low, richly textured Jackson voice doing verbal battle with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at twice-weekly Question Time. This spring, after doing a Los Angeles production of ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' Jackson won the Labor Party nomination for Hampstead and Highgate, home turf of London's smart literary and theatrical set. Thatcher's troubled Conservatives hold the district by a narrow 2,200-vote margin, making it a prime Labor target at the next general election. The election must be held by mid-1992, but could well come sooner. In British politics, a candidate for Parliament must go before the party constituency branch and explain why he or she would be a good candidate. Jackson was up against three finalists, and she says her ultimate triumph was to write her own script. ``I mean, you don't win an Oscar; someone else wins it for you,'' she said in an interview. ``But this, I did.'' The actress won her first Oscar for ``Women in Love'' in 1970, followed by another for ``A Touch of Class'' in 1973. But for her political career, she chooses to look almost determinedly unglamorous, making no attempt to hide her 53 years. She is spurred by a hatred for Thatcherism. ``I hope she's hanging herself with her own hubris,'' she said. ``I am genuinely appalled by the state of my country and the plight of many thousands of people under a government that seems to govern only for the top people.'' Jackson has been a Labor activist for most of the 11 years since Thatcher won power. She appears in party television ads and has lined up alongside leader Neil Kinnock at the big pre-election rallies. She's not the only actor involved in politics. Vanessa Redgrave turns out for the ultra-left Socialist Workers' Party, and John Cleese for the centrist Social Democratic Party. But they have never run for office. The late Laurence Olivier had a seat in the unelected House of Lords after he was ennobled. But actors who become full-time politicians are a rarity in Britain. Jackson's socialism springs from her working-class roots in northern England. The eldest of four daughters of a bricklayer, she dropped out of high school at 16 to become a drugstore clerk. She got into amateur dramatics, smoothed out her northern accent, won a state scholarship to drama school and went on to the front rank of British theater. Roy Hodges, from whom she was divorced in 1976, once said of her: ``If Glenda had gone into politics, she would have been prime minister.'' But Jackson, a committed feminist, disclaims any such goals. ``My political ambitions would be fulfilled by seeing the return of a Labor government. I plan to be a very loyal backbencher,'' she said. Being famous guarantees Jackson the kind of media attention other political beginners can only dream about. The same goes for the only other celebrity among the first-time nominees so far announced, Olympic gold medalist runner Sebastian Coe. He has the Conservative Party nomination in a different district.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Economic Upheaval Hurting Profits at U.S. Companies
DOC.TEXT: The anti-inflation austerity plan that has slowed Brazil's economy to a near standstill is reaching into the balance sheets of U.S. companies thousands of miles away. This past week, Whirlpool Corp. reported its first-quarter profit fell 27.5 percent due to the impact of the economic plan on its Brazilian affiliates. Whirlpool Chairman David R. Whitwam predicted the Brazilian problems would hurt the appliance maker's operating results into the second quarter before things gradually improve. Ford Motor Co. also warned this past week that its earnings could be hurt if current conditions continue in Brazil, where it makes cars through a joint venture with Volkswagen AG. Earlier, Caterpillar Inc. blamed lower first-quarter earnings in part on slower sales in the South American nation. Also, J.P. Morgan & Co., BankAmerica Corp. and Chemical Banking Corp. said they received lower interest payments or no interest payments at all on Brazilian loans in recent months. Some of the revenue softness felt by U.S. companies can't be traced directly to the Brazilian austerity plan, since it only was launched last month. But economists warn that many foreign companies operating in Brazil soon will feel the crimp unless they take steps to export products they make in the nation. Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello initiated his inflation-fighting plan a day after taking office March 15. Its main feature is an 18-month freeze on bank accounts with more than the equivalent of $1,200, and a limit on money market withdrawals to $600 or 20 percent of the account, whichever is greater. The plan took an an estimated $115 billion out of circulation overnight. It has cut inflation sharply, but also sent the Brazilian economy into a tailspin, with the automobile, construction and other industries virtually paralyzed. Many Amercian companies have extensive operations in Brazil, the most industrialized nation in South America and eighth-largest economy in the world. Among them are Ford, Caterpillar, General Motors Corp., Johnson & Johnson, Union Carbide Corp., Champion International Corp., Philip Morris Cos., Alcoa and Quaker Oats Co. Javier Murcio, an economist with the economic research firm DRI-McGraw-Hill, said the short-term impact of the anti-inflation plan could be severe on Brazilian operations of these companies. ``It will take lots of strong nerves. In the short term it's going to be very bumpy,'' he said. But over a longer period, U.S. companies may decide to export more goods from their Brazilian operations, avoiding the troubled domestic market as much as possible, he said. ``Using Brazil as an export launching pad is something companies have discovered in the past few years and will continue to do,'' he said. However, Mike Sherman, chief investment strategist for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said it may not be so easy to export manufactured goods that are made specifically for the Brazilian market. Johnson & Johnson, for one, says it doesn't have the option of exporting its Brazilian goods because ``we tend to manufacture in individual countries for sale in that country,'' said spokesman Robert Kniffin. Johnson & Johnson makes the same array of hospital and consumer products in Brazil as it does in the United States and elsewhere, he said. ``Our plants are operating but there has been a noticeable decline in sales of products,'' he said. Johnson & Johnson said Thursday its first-quarter earnings dropped 23 percent due mainly to a $125 million charge. The charge primarily was due to paying off an Argentinian subsidiary's loan, but part of it came from problems in Brazil, Kniffin said. Murcio said the Brazilian operations of foreign companies have been a bright spot and should continue to do well once the short-term trouble from the economic plan eases. In the long run, he said, all companies operating in Brazil should benefit from lower inflation. ``Even despite the economic problems in Brazil in the recent past, the Brazilian operations tended to be the ones that have been the fastest growing and most profitable,'' he said. In other business and economic news this past week: _Junk bond pioneer Michael Milken pleaded guilty to six felony charges and agreed to pay $600 million in fines and penalties stemming from the biggest securities fraud case ever against an individual. _Financier James Goldsmith scrapped his $22 billion takeover attempt of BAT Industries PLC, which would have been one of the largest acquisitions in history. In addition the British conglomerate agreed to sell its Saks Fifth Avenue upscale fashion store chain to Investcorp International Inc., a multinational investment group, for about $1.5 billion. _Ames Department Stores, an Eastern discount chain, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws. _President Bush removed Japan from a ``hit list'' of countries judged to have erected the most offensive trade barriers against American products, rewarding Japanese efforts to ease trade tensions between the two economic superpowers. _Donald Trump said he is considering selling or refinancing virtually every major asset he owns, including the Trump Shuttle, his Northeastern airline.

DOC.HEAD: Nine An Un-Magic Number On Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: In the mathematics of Wall Street, a 9 percent interest rate equals a distinct minus for the stock market. At least that's the way the numbers crunched in the past week as yields on long-term Treasury bonds surpassed the 9 percent level for the first time in nearly a year. There was a time, a decade or so ago, when stock and bond traders might have exulted to see interest rates at anywhere near 9 percent. In those inflation-wracked days, yields all along the credit-market spectrum held persistently in two digits. But now things are different _ or at least they were supposed to be as the 1990s dawned amid hopes for slow but steady growth in business activity and corporate profits, without much interference from inflationary pressures. At the start of the year long-term government bonds yielded slightly less than 8 percent, and many forecasters voiced confidence that they were headed lower still. Lower rates figured to stimulate spending by both businesses and consumers, and to benefit the stock market by reducing the comparative allure of interest-bearing investments. Such visions quickly began to fade, however, when rates jumped in Japan, West Germany and other important U.S. trading partners, dragging domestic rates higher as well. Optimism in the bond market has been dealt a second blow of late by data for the first quarter of the year showing inflation rates at their highest levels since the early 1980s. Now talk is spreading in the financial world that the Federal Reserve once again finds itself facing a choice between two not-very-happy alternatives. ``The classic dilemma of higher inflation amidst pockets of economic weakness is confronting the Fed,'' said Anthony Vignola, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``If the Fed tightens policy and raises rates, it will incur the displeasure of the Administration, and risk upsetting a delicate but deteriorating international framework. ``More important, the Fed risks stifling economic growth, which has suffered from continued weakness in manufacturing and housing.'' As long-term rates rose to 9 percent, the stock market averages headed down. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 50.90 this past week to 2,645.05, on top of a 55.85-point loss the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.92 to 180.74; the American Stock Exchange market value index lost 5.32 to 342.64, and the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market was down 7.81 at 417.98. Volume on the Big Board averaged 135.59 million shares a day, against 149.02 million the week before. Whatever other negative possibilities it presents, the combination of slow growth and high interest rates makes for gloom among stock-market investors as they contemplate the outlook for corporate earnings. ``Unfortunately, the economy's slow-motion performance probably won't do much to bring inflation down any time soon,'' says the current edition of the Merrill Lynch Market Letter. ``That's because increases in labor costs show no signs of slowing and recent gains in productivity have been meager. ``Corporate profits are likely to remain under pressure for the foreseeable future as the economy plods along and inflation stays high.'' A good many optimists still hold out hope that today's high rates, by acting as a drag on business activity, might improve the chance for lower borrowing costs at some point later in the year. Talk of at least a return to 8 percent government bond yields by the fall is still prevalent on Wall Street. But upbeat interest-rate forecasts tend to meet with a lot of skepticism these days, if only because of the way the batch produced last winter turned out.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions April 28-29

DOC.HEAD: Is The Fed Watching The Wrong Figures?
DOC.TEXT: By some of the more conventional measurements, there is still plenty of credit available for American consumers and businesses, especially those most ``credit-worthy.'' As one economist, Edward Yardeni, puts it: ``Low-quality borrowers, who need to finance very risky activities, are being turned away by the bankers. But that leaves more lendable funds for high-quality borrowers.'' By another, less conventional definition, consumers, businesses and governmental units at all levels are snared in a credit trap, many of them destined for a long, painful experience and perhaps bankruptcy. By the conventional definitions, the economy should avoid recession in 1990 and conceivably grow faster than in 1989. By the other, it is already in the midst of a dangerous, destructive, credit-restraint recession. The more optimistic scenario comes from a revue of national statistics, including gross national product, incomes, short-term loan data, money in circulation and other figures used by government economists. The negative conclusion comes from discussions with heads of households, with folks who must meet the week-to-week bills. If they can't, it is assumed that the impact will spread, with sales, profits, tax receipts falling. The most common conventional definition of recession is two successive quarters of shrinking gross national product. It hasn't occurred, officially, since the last recession ended in 1982, the longest gap of the century. Albert Sindlinger's definition is the unconventional one, arrived at by talking directly to heads of households and asking them how their personal finances are holding up. They aren't, he says. Families are in trouble. How does he know? From Wallingford, Penn., his staff telephones heads of households in the 48 contiguous states, 1,000 different ones each week, a practice now approaching 13,000 consecutive days. The heads of households are asked these questions: _Is your total combined household annual income up or the same as it was six months ago? _Will the total combined household annual income for the next six months remain the same or be higher than now? _In the next six months, will there be more or the same number of jobs where you work? _In the next six months do you anticipate better or the same business conditions in your community? If the respondent answers any of the four questions with a negative response, that household is said to have negative household liquidity, roughly stated as inability or unwillingness to maintain current standards. Sindlinger tells his business clients that a state is declared to be in recession if household liquidity falls below 50 percent. Two states were in recession in January 1989, 29 by December, 34 in January and 41 in March. The only states solidly beyond recession in March were Illinois, Ohio and Michigan. Four others, Washington, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Indiana registered less than 55 percent, meaning they have avoided recession by a lesser margin. New England, says Sindlinger, is in the deepest recession, with a reading of only 38.4 percent. Five Rocky Mountain states and 12 Southeastern states are also listed in poor shape. The rest, except for the Midwest states and Washington, are in shallower recessions, Sindlinger says. Using more conventional yardsticks, Yardeni sees no sign of a credit crunch in the short-term loan data. Clearly, he says, short-term credit continues to expand. ``If there is a credit crunch out there, we should see it,'' he says. It would show up in the statistics. ``So far, we don't see it.'' But using information from another source, Sindlinger finds the credit crunch already is here, that households are severely pinched, and that as far as he's concerned, most of the nation is in a recession.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Change The Rules With The Regulators, Futures Group Pleads
DOC.TEXT: A trade association of futures fund managers has stepped into the turf battle for jurisdiction over stock-index futures with a simple plea: if there has to be a change in regulators, at least don't change the rules. The request made to members of Congress by the Managed Futures Trade Association may be a further indication that the futures industry is moving grudgingly toward acceptance of a change in the federal agency with authority over index futures. The Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates stock trading, has long sought jurisdiction over index futures, financial instruments that are derived from stock prices but regulated, like all futures contracts, by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Critics say the CFTC is too lax and too cozy with the futures industry to properly safeguard the public interest. The Managed Futures Trading Association is a Pittsburgh-based group representing 150 professional futures traders who manage an estimated $8 billion in public investment funds, said Jane Martin, executive director. In a letter sent earlier this month to key members of Congress, the group's chairman, Kenneth Tropin, said the association's first choice would be to leave index futures under the jurisdiction of the CFTC because it has expertise that the SEC lacks in the area of futures trading. But should Congress decide to transfer authority over index futures to the SEC, Tropin said, the SEC should not be allowed to change existing regulations that have been developed by the CFTC. ``Stock-index futures contracts should continue to be regulated as futures contracts and not as equity instruments, regardless of which regulatory agency is granted the responsibility to enforce such laws,'' Tropin said in his letter. Maintaining futures-trading rules as they currently exist, he said, ``will provide for a smooth regulatory transition and avoid the application of potentially duplicative, disruptive and inconsistent regulations.'' The next congressional hearing on the issue is a scheduled May 8 session before the Senate Agriculture Committee, according to CFTC spokesman David Gary. The jurisdictional issue has heated up since the 1987 stock market crash, which some experts believe was exacerbated by computer-driven program trading strategies involving rapid, simultaneous trades of huge amounts of both stocks and stock-index futures. Futures industry leaders contend index futures markets actually prevented an even steeper drop in stock prices on Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 508 points. SEC Chairman Richard Breeden and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady are urging Congress to give the SEC jurisdiction over stock-index futures, which are contracts to buy and sell baskets of stocks such as those represented by the Standard & Poor's 500 index. Chicago's world-leading futures exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, oppose the proposed regulatory change. But earlier this month, top officials of the Chicago exchanges indicated that if any change in jurisdiction occurs, they would prefer a proposal by Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., and Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, for a super-regulator that would have authority over all stock and futures trading.

DOC.HEAD: Impact of German Unification Small on Rest of World, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: The history unfolding in Eastern Europe could have far-reaching consequences for years to come and speculation about the impact has preoccupied investors in the world's financial centers. Currencies have been bought and sold based on theories about what will happen to various economies, particularly West Germany's. Stocks have gained and lost as traders assess which companies will benefit from business opportunities. The melding of the two Germanies, however, might not mean all that much outside their joined borders, a new study suggests. ``The impact of German economic unification on other countries is relatively modest, as the additional investment demand is not large relative to global investment and a disproportionate share of that investment demand is met by domestic German savings,'' says the study by two members of the Federal Reserve Board's staff in Washington. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany confirmed at a meeting last week that the two nations soon will share an economy. Although many details must still be worked out, there likely will be one German economy by July 2. West Germany's agreement to swap most East German marks for its own marks at a 1-to-1 rate cleared the way for the process to begin. A new currency is expected to go into circulation next autumn. The Fed analysts say the link ultimately will lead ``to an acceleration of investment and growth in a united Germany, a real appreciation of the Deutschmark, and a reduction in Germany's current account surplus.'' The boost in consumer demand expected to occur as the German economies blend is one of the outgrowths of unification that will directly affect the rest of the world. After plugging various assumptions into a statistical model, the study projects that the U.S. trade deficit will contract. But Joseph E. Gagnon, one of the authors, said the shrinkage will be small considering the magnitude of U.S. world trade. The annual improvement in the U.S. current account balance will peak at $15 billion a year after three years. The current account is the country's broadest measure of foreign trade and includes the exchange of goods and services as well as certain financial transactions. It ran a deficit of $105.9 billion in 1989. The mark's increased value in terms of other major currencies, particularly the dollar, also will affect Germany's trading partners. A stronger mark will lower the bill for the foreign goods that will be imported into Germany to satisfy the bigger consumer appetite. The dismantling of barriers to trade and investment and the enhanced efficiency of the East German economy will spur an economic boom as the integration proceeds. Domestic West German savings, though, are expected to be sufficient to support most of this investment surge. Changes elsewhere in Eastern Europe might have greater potential to influence economic variables in the United States. The study says, ``the ongoing liberalization of Eastern Europe can be expected to have additional consequences for the United States and other countries.'' But it added: ``While the potential demands for investment are much larger in the other Eastern European countries as a group, the reduction in barriers and improvement in efficiency will proceed more slowly in those countries than the pace assumed for East Germany in this paper. Thus, the immediate and medium-term impact of liberalization in Eastern Europe remains uncertain.'' The study, ``The Global Economic Implications of German Unification,'' is part of the Fed's international finance discussion series. It represents the opinions of the authors only and is not an official Fed view.
